summary: The UK has not banned international travel despite the emergence of coronavirus variants overseas.
headline2: Brazil variant: Why hasn't the UK banned all international flights?
summary2: Six people in the UK have tested positive for a concerning variant of coronavirus which was first found in the city of Manaus in Brazil. Most of them had flown from Brazil before UK border measures were tightened.

headline: The pain of being alone behind bars
summary: New York is bringing in solitary confinement reforms amid calls for changes throughout the US system.
headline2: Solitary confinement: New York bans prison isolation over 15 days
summary2: New York has adopted a law banning more than 15 days in solitary confinement, and is set to become one of the first US states to fall in line with the UN's Mandela Rules, which define extended solitary as torture.

summary2: The meeting between senior Biden administration officials and their Chinese counterparts marks the first face-to-face opportunity to gauge the dynamics of the relationship between the two most important global powers.

summary: Australia's love of beachside living will become more precarious as wave movements change, experts say.
headline2: Climate change: Coastal erosion 'to threaten more Australian homes'

Recent storms on Australia's coast have caused major erosion beneath beachfront homes in New South Wales.
Dr Hannah Power tells the BBC that erosion will be a worsening issue for coastal communities as sea levels rise.

headline: Stars ask Hollywood to act on disability inclusion
summary: Amy Poehler and Naomie Harris are among 80 actors and industry figures to have signed an open letter.
headline2: Stars urge Hollywood to take urgent action on disability inclusion
summary2: More than 80 actors and entertainment industry professionals including Amy Poehler, Naomie Harris and Jessica Barden have signed an open letter against prejudice and discrimination towards disabled talent in Hollywood.

headline: Radio drama used to stop the spread of coronavirus
summary: Young people from Rwanda are producing radio plays to educate people about the importance of hand-washing.
headline2: Coronavirus: Rwandan radio stars spread hygiene message
summary2: A group of young people in Rwanda have been writing and producing a series of radio dramas to teach listeners about the vital role hand-washing and sanitation play in preventing the spread of diseases such as Covid-19.

headline: Dying nurse told sister 'follow in my footsteps'
summary: Areema Nasreen was one of the youngest NHS workers to die of Covid-19 at the start of the pandemic.
headline2: Coronavirus: Dying nurse told sister 'follow in my footsteps'
summary2: Nurse Areema Nasreen was one of the youngest NHS workers to die from coronavirus at the start of the pandemic. Almost a year on from her death, her sister reveals how Areema's last words changed the course of her life.

headline: What happened after Facebook blocked news in Australia?
summary: The removal of news sites has led to concerns about the spread of disinformation.
headline2: Facebook in Australia: What happened after news was blocked?
summary2: Critics of Facebook say the company's ban on news appearing on its platform in Australia has made it more difficult for people to access reliable sources - and increased the influence of bad and misleading information.

headline: Should firms be more worried about firmware attacks?
summary: Microsoft says firmware cyber-attacks are on the rise, but enterprises are not paying attention.
headline2: Should firms be more worried about firmware cyber-attacks?
summary2: Computing giant Microsoft recently put out a report claiming that businesses globally are neglecting a key aspect of their cyber-security - the need to protect computers, servers and other devices from firmware attacks.

headline: Are freight exports to the EU back to normal?
summary: The government says freight volumes to the EU are back to normal. What do the figures show?
headline2: Brexit: Are freight exports to the EU back to normal?
summary2: The government says the volume of freight exports from Great Britain to the European Union has returned to normal, in spite of the new post-Brexit barriers to trade with the EU, and restrictions related to the pandemic.

headline: The island nation where cricket is changing women's lives
summary: Vanuatu's Women's Island Cricket Programme is using the sport to combat disease and domestic violence in the Pacific nation.
headline2: How Vanuatu is using traditional island cricket to change and save women's lives
summary2: Rachel Andrew is one of the leading cricketers in an island nation famous for its stunning beaches. She has scored more runs for the women's national team than anyone else and averages an impressive 11.50 with the ball.

headline: Vaccine supplies 'lumpy but on course'
summary: The health secretary was responding to a NHS letter warning of a "significant reduction" of vaccine supplies.
headline2: Hancock: Covid vaccine supplies 'lumpy but on course'
summary2:
Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said the UK remains on course to vaccinate those aged 50 and above by 15 April.
He was responding to a NHS letter warning of a "significant reduction" of vaccine supplies from 29 March.

headline: Bafta diversity recruit 'faced racist comments'

headline2: Bafta: Diversity scheme recruit 'faced racist comments'
summary2: An actress who took part in a Bafta initiative aimed at improving diversity in the film and TV industry has said she was subjected to racist comments while on the scheme and was not given appropriate disability support.

headline: Bans, barbs and boats: the town tackling Tunisian football

summary2: Tunisia's Football Federation (FTF) and its president Wadie Jary have knowingly misled sport's highest legal body, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), a club at the centre of a controversial suspension has alleged.

headline: Shoppers 'excited' to be back on the High Street

headline: What's it like to be on furlough for a year?

headline2: Covid: What's it like to be on furlough for a year?

headline: Doctor: Don't ask me which vaccine is best, please

summary: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 25 December and 1 January.
headline2: Your pictures of Scotland 25 Dec to 1 Jan
summary2: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 25 December and 1 January. Send your photos to scotlandpictures@bbc.co.uk. Please ensure you adhere to the BBC's rules regarding photographs that can be found here.

headline: We showed volunteers an anti-vax video. How did they react?
summary: We showed eight people a viral video filled with falsehoods. Did it change their minds?
headline2: Covid-19: How did a volunteer panel react when we showed them an anti-vax video?
summary2: Activists have been targeting people with fears about vaccines in a social media blitz. In an experiment, BBC Panorama showed a panel one video filled with falsehoods to see how it affected their willingness to get a jab.

headline: What next for Trump - and Trumpism?
summary: Stripped of presidential powers and silenced online, can Trump still make a political comeback?
headline2: What next for Trump - and Trumpism?
summary2: Donald Trump boarded Air Force One for the last time on Wednesday with a wave. As Frank Sinatra's My Way blared over the loudspeakers at Joint Base Andrews, the soon-to-be-ex-president took off for his new home in Florida.

headline: Your pictures of Scotland 30 October - 6 November
summary: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 30 October and 6 November.
headline2: Your pictures of Scotland 30 October - 6 November
summary2: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 30 October and 6 November. Send your photos to scotlandpictures@bbc.co.uk. Please ensure you adhere to the BBC's rules regarding photographs which can be found here.

headline: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
summary: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
headline2: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
summary2: France is one of the most vaccine-sceptical countries in the world - fertile ground for hard-line anti-vaccine activists spreading online misinformation, writes the BBC's specialist disinformation reporter Marianna Spring.

headline: Your pictures of Scotland: 27 December - 3 January
summary: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 27 December and 3 January.
headline2: Your pictures of Scotland: 27 December - 3 January
summary2: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 27 December and 3 January. Send your photos to scotlandpictures@bbc.co.uk. Please ensure you adhere to the BBC's rules regarding photographs which can be found here.

headline: Lockdown lessons: The firms adapting and thriving
summary: Three small businesses explain how they have adapted to cope with the pandemic over the past year.
headline2: Lockdown lessons: The firms adapting and thriving
summary2: It's an understatement to say the past year has posed a unique challenge for many businesses. The national lockdown introduced in March 2020, in response to the spread of coronavirus, forced thousands to close temporarily.

headline: Inner Light: The children surviving conflict in DR Congo
summary: Hugh Kinsella Cunningham documents the lives of children caught up in conflict in DR Congo.
headline2: Inner Light: The children surviving conflict in DR Congo
summary2: Photographer Hugh Kinsella Cunningham has travelled across the north-eastern province of Ituri in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with Save the Children, to document the personal stories of children caught up in conflict.

headline: How a rapper's social media posts got the FBI's attention
summary: A cash-flaunting rapper from Siberia came to the US to become a global star. Where did it go wrong?
headline2: Plinofficial: Russian rapper who loved dollars arrested by FBI
summary2: A court in Pennsylvania this week took up the case against a 29-year-old Russian rapper, known as Plinofficial, accused of cybercrimes. He once dreamt of becoming the biggest rap artist on the planet. Where did it go wrong?

headline: 'It's frozen inside my apartment'
summary: Texas is experiencing record low temperatures, with some places dipping to 0F (-18C).
headline2: Winter storm leaves millions without electricity in Texas
summary2:
Texas is experiencing record low temperatures, with some places dipping to 0F (-18C).
The sudden increase in electricity demand caused the state's power grid to fail.
Read more: Deadly winter storm sweeps US southern states

headline: Your pictures of Scotland 27 November - 4 December
summary: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 27 November and 4 December.
headline2: Your pictures of Scotland 27 November - 4 December
summary2: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 27 November and 4 December. Send your photos to scotlandpictures@bbc.co.uk. Please ensure you adhere to the BBC's rules regarding photographs which can be found here.

headline: Covid and suicide: Japan's 'disappearing' women
summary: For the first time in 11 years, suicide among women has gone up, and the pandemic is playing a part.
headline2: Covid and suicide: Japan's rise a warning to the world?
summary2: Japan reports suicides faster and more accurately than anywhere else in the world. Unlike most countries, here they are compiled at the end of every month. During the Covid pandemic the numbers have told a disturbing story.

headline: Fijian team sings moving tribute to quarantine staff
summary: The rugby league players performed the song from their balconies in hotel quarantine in Australia.
headline2: Fijian rugby league players sing tribute to Sydney quarantine staff
summary2:
After completing 14 days of hotel quarantine in Australia, a Fijian rugby league team has thanked staff by singing a touching tribute from their balconies.
The performance also delighted other guests at the hotel in Sydney.

headline: Salt harvesting: Turning sea water into 'white gold'
summary: The industry is to be revived in the coastal village of St Monans two centuries after it came to an end.
headline2: Salt harvesting: Turning sea water into 'white gold' in a Fife village
summary2: Salt harvesting is being revived in a Fife coastal village - 200 years after the industry ended in the area. The East Neuk Salt Company plans to produce two tonnes of artisan sea salt every month from February in St Monans.

headline: Brexit: What is the Internal Market Bill?
summary: How would the Internal Market Bill change the Northern Ireland protocol?
headline2: Brexit: Why is the Internal Market Bill controversial?
summary2: The government has said it is willing to drop parts of a controversial piece of legislation - the Internal Market Bill - which had the potential to further complicate the already tense trade talks between the UK and the EU.

headline: Your pictures of Scotland 25 September - 2 October
summary: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 25 September and 2 October.
headline2: Your pictures of Scotland 25 September - 2 October
summary2: A selection of your pictures of Scotland sent in between 25 September and 2 October. Send your photos to scotlandpictures@bbc.co.uk. Please ensure you adhere to the BBC's rules regarding photographs which can be found here.

headline: Five takeaways from this year's Bafta Film Awards
summary: Even with social distancing there was plenty of humour, glamour and surprises at the virtual event.
headline2: Bafta Film Awards 2021: Snobbery, pianos and other takeaways
summary2: With the nominees on Zoom, only a few stars in attendance to open the envelopes and a Royal Albert Hall as empty as your local picturehouse, it definitely wasn't business as usual at this year's British Academy Film Awards.

headline: Attenborough: 'We face the collapse of everything'
summary: Climate change could destroy "entire cities" in a matter of decades, says Sir David Attenborough.
headline2: Attenborough gives stark warning on climate change to UN
summary2:
Climate change could, within a lifetime, destroy "entire cities and societies", Sir David Attenborough has told the UN Security Council.
"I don't envy the responsibility that this places on all of you," the naturalist said.

headline: Keeping the faith: Christian chaplains in the time of Covid
summary: Photographer Louise Haywood-Schiefer meets Christian chaplains around London and discovers how they are coping with the pandemic.
headline2: Keeping the faith: Christian chaplains in the time of Covid
summary2: At times of great uncertainty, many people turn to faith leaders for support, but with the current social restrictions, it's more difficult than ever for ministers to offer pastoral and spiritual care to their congregations.

headline: Coronavirus and OCD: 'I spent 20 years preparing for this'
summary: How coping with OCD prepared one man for the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic.
headline2: OCD: 'I spent 20 years preparing for the coronavirus pandemic'
summary2: Coping with a life-long phobia of germs meant the BBC's Peter Goffin was ready for the coronavirus pandemic. He knew how to observe hygiene rules, and he had the skills needed to prevent his anxieties growing out of control.

headline: Which regions have been worst hit?
summary: Reality Check examines the weekly deaths figures for nations and regions across the UK.
headline2: Coronavirus: Which regions have been worst hit?
summary2: Weekly death registrations in London, which was the epicentre of the UK's coronavirus outbreak, have returned to the range that would normally be expected, as the country moves further beyond the worst weeks of the pandemic.

headline: Six coronavirus health myths fact-checked
summary: Garlic and taking hot baths are among the dodgy health advice for treating coronavirus being shared online.
headline2: Coronavirus: The fake health advice you should ignore
summary2: Coronavirus is emerging in more countries around the world and there's currently no known cure. Unfortunately that hasn't stopped a slew of health advice, ranging from useless but relatively harmless, to downright dangerous.

headline: The Duke of Edinburgh: A love for sport
summary: Prince Philip excelled at a range of sports from sailing and cricket to polo and carriage driving.
headline2: Prince Philip: Cricket, polo and carriage driving
summary2:
Prince Philip excelled at a range of sports from sailing and cricket to polo and carriage driving.
The Duke of Edinburgh became one of the country's top polo players before giving up the sport after suffering with arthritis.

headline: Libya's city of ghosts
summary: The BBC's Quentin Sommerville visits Tarhuna where the victims of years of civil war are being reburied.
headline2: Libya's city of ghosts
summary2: As the senior man in his family, in fact its only surviving adult male, it falls to Abdel Manaam Mahmoud to climb into the grave and lay his brother Esmail's body to rest. Though it may not be his brother he's burying today.

headline: Are US states reopening too soon?
summary: There is concern some states are relaxing restrictions prematurely. Are the guidelines being followed?
headline2: Coronavirus: Are states reopening ahead of White House guidelines?
summary2: After more than 40 state-wide lockdowns were put in place across the US throughout March and April, many states are now easing restrictions - but some are going against White House guidelines, worrying public health experts.

headline: Taylor Swift has finished re-recording Fearless
summary: The star hints that the new version of her biggest-selling album will come out in April.
headline2: Taylor Swift has finished re-recording Fearless - and it could be out in April
summary2: When Taylor Swift's back catalogue was bought in June 2019 by Scooter Braun's Ithaca Holdings, the superstar almost immediately announced she would re-record her first five albums in an attempt to regain control of her music.

headline: Queen makes her first appearance this year
summary: The Queen was visiting the Air Forces memorial in Surrey to mark the centenary of the Royal Australian Air Force.
headline2: The Queen makes her first face-to-face appearance this year
summary2:
The Queen was visiting the Air Forces memorial in Surrey to mark the centenary of the Royal Australian Air Force.
The monarch has been carrying out her official duties via video link during the lockdown in the United Kingdom.

headline: Clowns, culture and coronavirus in Latin America
summary: Caribbean and Latin American photography features in the third Annual Latin American Foto Festival.
headline2: Latin American Foto Festival: Culture and coronavirus
summary2: Clowns, culture and the coronavirus pandemic are some of the themes of the Bronx Documentary Center's third Annual Latin American Foto Festival, which features award-winning photographers from the Caribbean and Latin America.

headline: Is Russia preparing to invade Ukraine?
summary: What you need to know about Russia's troop build-up around eastern Ukraine.
headline2: Is Russia going to war with Ukraine and other questions
summary2: Sabre-rattling or preparations for war? Since mid-March, there have been many warnings from Ukraine and Western governments that Russia is massing troops in Russian-annexed Crimea and around the eastern Ukraine conflict zone.

headline: Can launderettes survive the coronavirus lockdown?
summary: Despite being an essential service, many launderette owners say their businesses are suffering during lockdown.
headline2: Coronavirus: How will launderettes come out in the wash?
summary2: Launderettes have been at the heart of communities for decades but despite being deemed an essential service during the coronavirus lockdown, many owners say their businesses are suffering. What does the future hold for them?

headline: 1988 v 2021: A tale of two Myanmar protests
summary: Student activists fight to end a hated military government in Myanmar. 2021? Or 1988?
headline2: Myanmar coup: What protesters can learn from the '1988 generation'
summary2: Student activists lead a movement to bring an end to a widely-hated military government in Myanmar. It grows into a nationwide uprising, a general strike, which is met with savage brutality by the armed forces. 2021? Or 1988?

headline: Israel stands still to remember Holocaust victims
summary: Traffic stopped and people stood in silence to honour the six million Jews killed by the Nazis during World War Two.
headline2: Holocaust Remembrance Day: Israel stops to remember victims
summary2:
All across Israel traffic stopped and people stood in silence to remember the victims of the Holocaust, on Thursday.
Holocaust Remembrance Day - Yom Hashoah - honours the six million Jews killed by the Nazis in World War Two.

headline: 'It took 32 years, but I finally found my kidnapped son'
summary: After Li Jingzhi's son went missing in 1988 she dedicated her life to searching for him. He was found in May this year.
headline2: 'It took 32 years, but I finally found my kidnapped son'
summary2: Li Jingzhi spent more than three decades searching for her son, Mao Yin, who was kidnapped in 1988 and sold. She had almost given up hope of ever seeing him again, but in May she finally got the call she had been waiting for.

headline: Death of a Zulu king: 'He is planted, not buried'
summary: Photos of Goodwill Zwelithini's funeral - an insight into how a powerful South African monarch is mourned.
headline2: Death of a Zulu king: 'He is planted, not buried'
summary2: Goodwill Zwelithini, the 72-year-old king of the Zulu nation in South Africa, was laid to rest at a private ceremony shrouded in secrecy and attended only by a select group of royal men in the early hours of Thursday morning.

headline: Saving a marsupial 'unique even to Australia'
summary: The numbat is one of the world’s most endangered animals, with about 1,000 left in the wild.
headline2: Numbats: Saving a marsupial 'unique even to Australia'
summary2:
The numbat - a small and little-known Australian marsupial - is one of the world's most endangered animals.
But conservationists are working hard to save them by building vast, predator-free sanctuaries.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: How big is the epidemic in care homes?
summary: Care homes now account for a large proportion of Covid-19 deaths in the UK.
headline2: Coronavirus deaths: How big is the epidemic in care homes?
summary2: About a quarter of known coronavirus deaths in Great Britain have happened in care homes, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson saying he "bitterly regrets" the epidemic and that the government is "working very hard" to tackle it.

headline: Confessions of a slaughterhouse worker
summary: A former abattoir worker describes her job and the effect it had on her mental health.
headline2: Confessions of a slaughterhouse worker
summary2: About 100 million animals are killed for meat in the UK every month - but very little is heard about the people doing the killing. Here, one former abattoir worker describes her job, and the effect it had on her mental health.

headline: Will the vaccine be a Budget recovery blueprint?
summary: As well as saving lives and helping reopen the economy, the shot in the arm could have a long-lasting economic impact.
headline2: Budget 2021: Will vaccine rollout be the blueprint for recovery?
summary2: It's going to be an historic Budget because of the numbers. But between the fiscal fireworks and the extension of rescue packages, Chancellor Rishi Sunak was always going to have to point the country towards a changed economy.

headline: No, the US Covid death toll has not been altered
summary: False claims about the Covid-19 death toll in the US have gone viral. Here's why they're wrong.
headline2: Coronavirus: The US has not reduced its Covid-19 death toll to 6% of total
summary2: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says it has been deluged with queries about false rumours the official tally of Covid-19 deaths is drastically lower than the publicised headline figure of about 185,000.

headline: The Duke of Edinburgh's service in the Royal Navy
summary: Prince Philip's Royal Navy years were a defining experience, and led to him meeting Princess Elizabeth.
headline2: Prince Philip: The Royal Navy years
summary2:
Prince Philip's years in the Royal Navy were a defining experience.
He met Princess Elizabeth when she visited the Dartmouth Naval College where he was a cadet, and he graduated just months after the outbreak of World War Two.

headline: Will there be security co-operation after Brexit?
summary: Ex-PM Theresa May says the government should not be resigned to no deal on security co-operation.
headline2: Brexit: Will the UK and the EU co-operate on security?
summary2: Former Prime Minister Theresa May has told Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove that the government "should not be resigned to the prospect of no deal" when it comes to post-Brexit police and security co-operation with the EU.

headline: Can one mile take 10 years off your life?
summary: Is Sir Keir Starmer right that Somers Town in London has life expectancy 10 years below somewhere a mile away?
headline2: Can one mile take 10 years off your life?
summary2: In an interview in which he talked about inequality, Labour leadership candidate Sir Keir Starmer told BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg: "Here in Somers Town, the life expectancy is 10 years less than a mile up the road."

headline: Photos of UK town win top international award
summary: Craig Easton wins Sony Photographer of the Year award with photos on community representation in Blackburn.
headline2: In pictures: 2021 Sony World Photography Awards
summary2: The winners of the professional category of the 2021 Sony World Photography Awards have been announced, with Craig Easton named as Photographer of the Year for his work on the representation of communities in northern England.

headline: How a rape suspect hid in plain sight for 22 years
summary: The case went cold after the man disappeared following a brutal 1999 gang rape in India.
headline2: 'Op Silent Viper': How an Indian rape suspect was caught after 22 years
summary2: Police in the eastern Indian state of Orissa (also called Odisha) have arrested a man wanted in a notorious 1999 gang rape. The accused hid in plain sight for more than two decades - until a few days ago when his luck ran out.

headline: Coronavirus: ‘It’s just anxiety, anxiety, anxiety’
summary: The coronavirus crisis is having a huge impact on young people with existing mental health conditions.
headline2: Coronavirus: ‘It’s just anxiety, anxiety, anxiety’
summary2: The coronavirus crisis is having a huge impact on young people with existing mental health conditions, a survey has found. The loss of routine, school closures and exam cancellations are all factors, as well as health concerns.

headline: Why campaigners want 'rough sex' murder defence ban
summary: Campaigners say men are increasingly using the defence to try to get away with murdering women.
headline2: Rough sex murder defence: Why campaigners want it banned
summary2: Campaigners say men are increasingly using the "rough sex" defence to try to get away with murdering women. They want the law changed to prevent such a defence and have the support of two MPs. But what difference would it make?

headline: 'I've only left my home five times this year'
summary: Michaela Hollywood led a jet-set lifestyle until coronavirus hit, then she had to shield.
headline2: Coronavirus and shielding: 'I've only left my home five times this year'
summary2: Within the month of September 2019 Michaela Hollywood flew across America eight times, such were the demands of a leadership programme she was on. Since coronavirus, however, she has only been able to leave her home five times.

headline: 'Why I stopped hiding my scars'
summary: Jayne, Emily, Laura and Aimee talk about their scars, and how they came to accept them.
headline2: 'Why I stopped hiding my scars'
summary2: Jayne, Emily and Laura have one thing in common - they all have scars. Aimee, for her part, has flare-ups of psoriasis that can leave her face covered in red patches. But all four have come to feel comfortable in their own skin.

headline: Should the hurricane season begin earlier?
summary: Significant storms have been forming earlier than usual in recent years.
headline2: Should the hurricane season begin earlier?
summary2: The Atlantic hurricane season officially begins on 1 June. But over the past six years, significant storms have been forming earlier than this. So does the hurricane season need to start earlier - and is climate change to blame?

headline: 'I made a ballgown out of 1,400 mangoes'
summary: Australian teenager Jess Collins grew up on a mango farm and says too many fruits are left to rot.
headline2: Mango dress: Teen makes 1,400-mango gown to highlight food waste
summary2:
Jessica Collins, 18, grew up on a mango farm in Queensland, Australia.
Frustrated by how many mangoes go to waste each year, she turned about 1,400 of the unwanted fruits into a dress for a school project.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Who is Elon Musk?
summary: Meet the meme-loving magnate who runs SpaceX and Tesla.
headline2: The many adventures of Elon Musk
summary2:
He runs a space exploration company and a futuristic car business, plays with flamethrowers and intervenes in international emergencies.
He also has beef with Jeremy Clarkson.
Who on Earth is Elon Musk?
Produced by James Wignall

headline: Britain's 'blindingly cool' engineering innovation
summary: Conceptual still-life photographer Ted Humble-Smith celebrates 50 years of world-beating technology.
headline2: Britain's 'blindingly cool' engineering innovation
summary2: Ted Humble-Smith is a conceptual still-life photographer. He's well known for his fashion work. Ted can take a lipstick or a watch and with his extraordinary vision and skill turn the beautiful into something even more gorgeous.

headline: The dead professor and the vast pro-India network
summary: A Harvard icon and fake media have been used in a global campaign to serve Indian interests, research reveals.
headline2: The dead professor and the vast pro-India disinformation campaign
summary2: A dead professor and numerous defunct organisations were resurrected and used alongside at least 750 fake media outlets in a vast 15-year global disinformation campaign to serve Indian interests, a new investigation has revealed.

headline: A sideways glance at the signs around us
summary: Photographer Kiki Streitberger takes a sideways look at the advertising on the streets of London.
headline2: Coronavirus: A sideways glance at the signs around us
summary2: On her daily walk during the lockdown due to the coronavirus, photographer Kiki Streitberger sees another meaning in some of the adverts and posters she finds on the streets of London. Here she recounts those that caught her eye.

headline: 'My MS has not left me excluded during pandemic'
summary: Wheelchair user Siân loves going to virtual events, but fears being excluded again as lockdown ends.
headline2: Covid: Trefor woman reveals lockdown's positive effects
summary2: "During this last week, I've been out every night - I've been to two lectures, a birthday party with old friends, a service in the chapel, a "healthy living" night, a seminar on Welsh poetry - all without taking my slippers off".

headline: Jeff Bezos did not say this about coronavirus
summary: Fact-checking the week's most popular dubious stories including a billionaire's fake quote and 5G myths.
headline2: Coronavirus: Bogus Jeff Bezos message and other misleading stories unpicked
summary2: BBC teams are fact-checking and verifying some of the most popular fake and misleading coronavirus stories on social media. Jack Goodman brings together what's been debunked this week by BBC Monitoring, Trending and Reality Check.

headline: What the collapse of Debenhams means for us
summary: At two stores 100 miles apart, customers share their sadness at the loss of a high street giant.
headline2: Debenhams closure: Norwich and Stevenage shoppers tell of 'huge loss'
summary2: For decades Debenhams has been a landmark store for towns and cities across the UK. The BBC visited two branches - one of the newest and one of its long-established stores - to hear customers' views on the retail giant's collapse.
contributor_name: Laurence Cawley, Mariam Issimdar and Kris Holland

headline: The ex-armed robber with a mission to make change
summary: His body on the ground, guns pointed at his back, John McAvoy was caught. His life sentence wasn't the end but a new beginning.
headline2: John McAvoy: The ex-armed robber who reformed through sport in high security prison
summary2: At half past eight on a warm September morning in 2005, 22-year-old criminal John McAvoy was ready. He and another man were planning to raid a security van making a delivery of around £100,000 in cash in Eltham, south-east London.

headline: Why bots will beat you to the hot-ticket gifts
summary: The Christmas shopping season is here - but it may be harder than ever to snag what you want.
headline2: Christmas shopping: Why bots will beat you to in-demand gifts
summary2: Black Friday is over, and the Christmas shopping rush is here. But any great deals on a new games console or hot-ticket piece of electronics will probably be snapped up by an army of bots working for those looking to make a profit.

headline: Leaving care: 'I fell through the cracks'
summary: Young care leaver Kim Emenike made it to university against the odds - then social services forgot about her.
headline2: Leaving care: ‘I made it to university, but then I fell through the cracks'
summary2: About 10,000 young people move out of the care system in the UK every year. For some there's a sudden cut-off with little support on the other side. Kim Emenike describes her experience of what has been described as a "care cliff".

headline: Greta Thunberg: 'I don't think I'll be going to COP'
summary: She told the BBC she was concerned about the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on attendance at COP26.
headline2: Greta Thunberg not planning on attending COP26 in Glasgow
summary2:
Environmental activist Greta Thunberg has said she isn't planning on going to the UN climate conference in Glasgow in November.
She told the BBC she was concerned about the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on attendance at COP26.

headline: The forgotten story of Britain's first black coach
summary: Roy Francis was a rugby revolutionary and the first black coach in elite British sport, yet his story has largely been forgotten.
headline2: Roy Francis: The black head coach who revolutionised rugby league
summary2: "Roy was the first person to come and see me after I had my daughter," says Anne Francis. "He snuck into the hospital about an hour after she was born. I think he wanted to see what colour she was. It was quite touching, I thought.

headline: Island where every adult has been vaccinated
summary: The remote island community of Fair Isle has had no cases of Covid-19 and every adult has had their second vaccine.
headline2: Remote island community where every adult has been vaccinated against Covid
summary2:
The remote island community of Fair Isle has had no cases of Covid-19 and every adult has had their second vaccine.
It is "probably one of the safest places in the country", says one resident.
*Filmed under strict Covid guidelines*

headline: 'I want to be a spark in the plug'
summary: The Our People, Our Poverty exhibition showcases the volunteers helping their struggling neighbours.
headline2: Photo exhibition showcases the people tackling poverty
summary2: The impact of poverty in 21st Century Britain is the focus of a new exhibition which showcases those trying to help their struggling neighbours. Four people making a difference in their communities explain how they became involved.

headline: Fears for democracy as buoyant Bangladesh turns 50
summary: Half a century after its birth, millions are no longer in poverty - but democratic space has shrunk.
headline2: Fears for democracy as buoyant Bangladesh turns 50
summary2: Bangladesh is held up by many as a model of development, but as it marks 50 years of independence critics say it risks becoming a one-party state intolerant of dissent, threatening the democratic principles on which it was founded.

headline: Fact-checking President Macron's vaccine claim
summary: France is one of a number of EU countries which is not recommending the jab for those over 65.
headline2: Covid-19: Fact-checking Macron's over-65s claim about the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine
summary2: On the day the European Medicines Agency (EMA) approved the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine on 29 January for use for all age groups in the EU, French president Emmanuel Macron claimed that it was "quasi-ineffective" for people over 65.

headline: 'I didn't know it was abuse until I nearly died'
summary: Abi Blake was nearly killed by her husband. Maybe a new police pilot programme would have helped her?
headline2: 'I didn't know it was abuse until I nearly died'
summary2: It was only when Abi Blake was nearly killed by her abusive husband that she decided to break up with him and press charges. A new policing pilot in Cheshire encourages women not to leave it so late, reports the BBC's Sue Mitchell.

headline: Fact-checking Biden's first month as president
summary: President Biden has made a series of claims during his first four weeks - are they right?
headline2: President Biden: Fact-checking his first month in office
summary2: During his first four weeks in the White House, President Joe Biden has been talking about the challenges facing the US - from coronavirus to the economy - and has contrasted his policies with those of his predecessor, Donald Trump.

headline: The secret life of museums during lockdown
summary: Museums and art galleries are closed but inside their walls, a select few people are busy at work.
headline2: Covid-19: The secret life of museums during lockdown
summary2: Museums and art galleries are closed but inside their walls, a select few people are busy at work. Curators, conservators, cleaners, art handlers and security guards are among those caring for the nation's treasures during lockdown.

headline: Waiting for the tourists to come back to Greece
summary: As Europeans wait to see if foreign holidays are possible this summer, Greece hopes to open up soon.
headline2: Covid Greece: Waiting for the tourists to come back
summary2: All over Europe, people are waiting and hoping to find out whether foreign summer holidays will be possible. Many countries are currently banning or strongly discouraging them, and returning travellers have to quarantine on arrival.

headline: How a little Ant became a financial giant
summary: China's Ant Group started life as part of the Alibaba colony but grew to establish its own empire.
headline2: Ant Group: How it became a financial giant
summary2:
Asia business correspondent Karishma Vaswani explains how China's Ant Group started life as part of the Alibaba colony and how it grew to establish its own empire as a financial technology giant.
Produced and edited by Christine Hah

headline: Firefighters tackle blaze at National Museum
summary: Firefighters have been tackling a fire in the dome of the National Museum in Cardiff.
headline2: National Museum Cardiff fire: Firefighters tackle blaze
summary2:
Firefighters have been tackling a fire at the National Museum in Cardiff.
Crews responded just after midday and extinguished a small fire in the building's dome.
No staff were hurt and collections were not damaged, the museum added.

headline: 'I was found wrapped in my mum's coat - but who am I?'
summary: For 70 years Tony May knew nothing about where he came from, except that he'd been left on the bank of the Thames.
headline2: 'I was found as a baby wrapped in my mum's coat – but who am I?'
summary2: Tony May was only a few weeks old when he was abandoned by the River Thames in London, in the middle of World War Two. He had no idea who his parents were for more than 70 years. Then a DNA detective dug up the truth about his past.

headline: What do you do with 86 tonnes of celeriac?
summary: With hospitality closed during lockdown, charities and apps are stepping in to help cut food waste.
headline2: Waste food: What do you do with 86 tonnes of celeriac?
summary2: Hundreds of thousands of tonnes of food is thrown away in the UK every year. With coronavirus lockdowns closing restaurants, cafes and pubs, there is even more food potentially going to waste. But charities and apps are stepping in.

headline: Whale death sparks conservation conversation
summary: The recent death of a humpback has raised interest and concerns for whales in the North Sea.
headline2: North Sea whale death raises by-catch safety fears
summary2: The recent death of a humpback whale off the Northumberland coast has raised interest in and concerns for the marine mammals in the North Sea. With the number of whale sightings in the area growing, what can be done to protect them?

headline: Could lab-grown meat help tackle climate change?
summary: Last year Singapore approved the sale of 'chicken' grown in a lab. What is it exactly - and could it be better for the planet?
headline2: Could lab-grown meat help tackle climate change?
summary2:
Last year, Singapore became the first country to allow the sale of lab-grown meat.
BBC Minute takes a look at what lab-grown meat is and whether it could help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the future.
Producer: Mora Morrison

headline: How Didier Drogba helped halt a civil war
summary: Didier Drogba was the figurehead for Ivory Coast's 'golden generation'. Their remarkable powers helped bring a damaged nation together.
headline2: Didier Drogba: How Ivory Coast striker helped to halt civil war in his home nation
summary2: Al-Merrikh Stadium, in Sudan's second largest city of Omdurman, is not one of the world's great gladiatorial arenas. Yet this small ground - known as the Red Castle - became the setting for one of football's most extraordinary tales.

headline: 'It is important that this is the last lockdown'
summary: The BBC speaks with businesses in Essex about the government's lockdown-easing measures.
headline2: Covid: 'It is important that this is the last lockdown'
summary2: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has unveiled a four-part plan to ease the current lockdown restrictions in England. BBC News spoke to people working in the hotel, beauty and gym industries to find out their reaction to the announcement.

headline: Michael Gove's Covid claims fact-checked
summary: We look at the Cabinet Office minister's assertions about the coronavirus lockdown measures.
headline2: Lockdown rules: Michael Gove's Covid claims fact-checked
summary2: The government has been setting out its case for tougher coronavirus measures. Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove has said England's second national lockdown was brought in to stop the health service being "physically overwhelmed".

headline: Swimming with sharks at Bondi Beach
summary: Two Grey Nurse sharks were feeding on a large school of salmon while swimmers had a morning dip.
summary2:
Two Grey Nurse sharks were feeding on a large school of salmon while swimmers had a morning dip.
The footage was captured by Drone Shark App. Its founder, Jason Iggleden, said the school of salmon were around Bondi for about an hour.

headline: Why do I need to be tested?
summary: BBC Reality Check breaks down what is coronavirus testing and why it matters.
headline2: Coronavirus: Why do I need to be tested?
summary2:
Countries across the world are approaching coronavirus testing differently. Reality Check's Chris Morris explains what testing is and why it matters.
Motion graphics by Jaqueline Galvin. Filmed by Myles Burke. Produced by Soraya Auer.

headline: In pictures: Scotland in the snow
summary: The good and bad effects of Storm Christoph as it causes a whiteout across the country.
headline2: In pictures: Scotland in the snow
summary2: Many parts of Scotland have been under a blanket of snow as Storm Christoph sweeps across the country. It hasn't been fun for drivers who have been hit with widespread travel disruption - but it has made for some striking photographs.

headline: The Mayday call from a Heathrow plane hit by toxic fumes
summary: Toxic fumes overcame a pilot landing at Heathrow in January. There's evidence that such events are not rare.
headline2: Fume events: The toxic gases that may be harming aircrew and passengers
summary2: An incident in January, when a pilot became unresponsive at the controls of a plane coming in to land at Heathrow, is just the latest in a string of potentially dangerous "fume events" going back decades, reports the BBC's Mike Powell.

headline: From she to he - and back to she again
summary: When two trans men fell in love they began to have second thoughts about their gender.
headline2: Ellie and Nele: From she to he - and back to she again
summary2: Studies suggest that most people who transition to another gender do not have second thoughts. But after two trans men met and fell in love, their personal gender journeys took an unexpected turn, to a destination neither had foreseen.

headline: Modi 'did not consult' before Covid lockdown
summary: A BBC investigation finds that key ministries and states were not consulted ahead of the Covid lockdown.
headline2: India Covid-19: PM Modi 'did not consult' before lockdown
summary2: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government did not consult key ministries and states while imposing the world's strictest coronavirus lockdown a year ago, according to an investigation by the BBC's Jugal Purohit and Arjun Parmar.

headline: Photographer, 91, set to light up London
summary: British-Ghanaian James Barnor's work is to be shown on Piccadilly Circus's big screens during April.
headline2: In pictures: Photographer James Barnor set for major retrospective
summary2: A British-Ghanaian photographer, whose images captured major social and political changes in London and Accra during the 1950s and 1960s, is having his work exhibited on Piccadilly Circus's big screens, as part of a major retrospective.

headline: Capitol riots: 'It was life or death'
summary: Photographer Mel D Cole was at the centre of the action when pro-Trump protests turned violent.
headline2: Capitol riots: 'It was life or death'
summary2:
Photographer Mel D Cole was at the centre of the action when pro-Trump protests turned violent at the US Capitol.
He told BBC World News about capturing the moment a police officer was dragged into the crowd and had his life threatened.

headline: Businesses despair at prospect of no-deal Brexit
summary: As we stand on the brink of no deal, businesses ask, “why are we doing this?” as Simon Jack reports.
headline2: Brexit: Businesses despair at prospect of no-deal
summary2: As a business journalist I spend most of my time with business leaders - most of who, regardless of the way they voted in the referendum, are holding their heads in their hands at the prospect of an economically damaging no-deal Brexit.

headline: 'I went from earning a good wage to zero overnight'
summary: Dozens of arts freelancers miss out on Covid support because of errors with their pay, Equity says.
headline2: Dozens of arts freelancers lose out on Covid support over tax 'error'
summary2: During more than a decade as an actress, Kya Garwood has had parts in films like Paddington 2 and Mamma Mia Here We Go Again, as well as being a stand-in and double for leading ladies like Meryl Streep, Michelle Pfeiffer and Lily James.

headline: The fake celebrity cash giveaway
summary: Unpicking the week's dubious claims including a fake cash giveaway and a Covid-19 "remedy".
headline2: Coronavirus: The celebrity cash giveaway and other stories fact-checked
summary2: BBC teams are fact-checking some of the most popular fake and misleading coronavirus stories on social media. Jack Goodman and Flora Carmichael bring together what's been debunked this week by BBC Monitoring, Trending and Reality Check.

headline: Is Facebook too powerful?
summary: Ros Atkins looks at the consequences of Facebook's power on events in Myanmar, Washington DC and Australia.
headline2: Ros Atkins on... Is Facebook too powerful?
summary2:
Amid growing calls to break up the social media giant Facebook, Ros Atkins looks at its power.
He considers its roles in Myanmar, the storming of the Capitol building in Washington, and the company’s decision to block news in Australia.

headline: An unexpected history of the Royal Albert Hall
summary: Rule Britannia has had its place - but so have Bovril, balls, Blackshirts and a bombastic celebration of the Bard.
headline2: Not just the Proms: An unexpected history of the Royal Albert Hall
summary2: Perhaps best known for classical music and the Last Night of the Proms, the Royal Albert Hall has a far from stuffy past. Rule Britannia has had its place - but so have Bovril, balls, Blackshirts and a bombastic celebration of the Bard.

headline: Kishan & Kohli hit fifties as India see off England
summary: India chase 165 to beat England in the second Twenty20 in Ahmedabad and level the series.
headline2: Kishan & Kohli hit fifties as India see off England
summary2:
India win with 13 balls to spare
Five-match series level at 1-1
Kohli 73* (49) - dropped on 10
Kishan 56 (32) on debut, Pant 26 (13)
England 164-6: Roy 46 (35)
Morgan 28 (20), Stokes 24 (21)
Sundar 2-29, Thakur 2-29
Second T20, Ahmedabad

headline: 'I am grieving for the person I used to be'
summary: A former health coach is blogging about her experience with the condition to help others get diagnosed.
headline2: 'Long Covid has destroyed me but I am fighting back'
summary2: Health coach Jasmine Hayer had to give up her life in London and move back in with her parents after catching Covid. Now she is focused on a twin goal - battling back to health while helping others get the right treatment for Long Covid.

headline: How many are really dying from coronavirus?
summary: BBC Reality Check explains why looking at 'excess deaths' reveals Covid-19's true death toll.
headline2: Coronavirus: How many more people are dying?
summary2:
BBC Reality Check's Chris Morris explains why looking at "excess deaths" proves to be one of the best measures of judging the death toll from coronavirus.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Filmed by Myles Burke
Produced by Soraya Auer

headline: Egyptian mummies relocated in dazzling Cairo parade
summary: Amid fanfare, 18 kings and four queens were transported on custom-made vehicles designed to minimise vibration.
headline2: Egypt mummies: Parade transports remains of pharaohs
summary2:
The mummified remains of 22 ancient Egyptian rulers have been transferred to a new museum in the south of the capital, Cairo.
Amid fanfare, 18 kings and four queens were transported on custom-made vehicles designed to minimise vibration.

headline: Four virus claims about school that parents should ignore
summary: Children will be weighed to check lockdown obesity and other misleading online claims debunked.
headline2: Back to school: Four virus claims that parents should ignore
summary2: Children are returning to classrooms, many for the first time in six months. As they do so, parents are having to wade through masses of guidance and advice about what to expect in a Covid-safe school. But not everything can be believed.

headline: When home is both prison and sanctuary
summary: Photographer Jo De Banzie records life during the coronavirus lockdown, using an antique camera.
headline2: Coronavirus: When home is both prison and sanctuary
summary2: Like most of us, photographer Jo de Banzie spent the spring of 2020 in lockdown, living at home with her family - a time that was overshadowed by the loss of her brother-in-law, who contracted the virus while working as an NHS paramedic.

headline: How does the US electoral college work?
summary: The president of the United States is not chosen directly by voters, but by what's known as the electoral college.
headline2: US election 2020: What is the electoral college?
summary2:
Voters in the US have already made their choice, but it's members of the electoral college who meet today to pick the next president.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Produced by Jake Horton and Sarah Glatte
Narrated by Marianna Brady

headline: How six brothers - and their lions - terrorised a town
summary: The Kani brothers presided over a reign of terror in the Libyan town of Tarhuna - now their crimes are being revealed.
headline2: How six brothers - and their lions - terrorised a Libyan town
summary2: They were the family from hell. For years, until last summer, the Kani brothers held a small Libyan town in their murderous grip, massacring men, women and children to maintain their authority. Now their crimes are slowly being uncovered.

headline: How will coronavirus change the way we live?
summary: Will life return to how it was once lockdown restrictions are eased, or will some things change for ever?
headline2: How will coronavirus change the way we live?
summary2: A return to how life was at the start of 2020 is some way off. Even when lockdown restrictions are eased, coronavirus will affect our lives in many ways. What will struggle to get back to how it was before, and what might change for ever?

headline: How to find love in lockdown
summary: Author and dating coach Haifa Barbari shares her top tips on how to find love in lockdown.
headline2: Dating coach Haifa Barbari shares her top tips on finding love in lockdown
summary2:
Coronavirus changed the world of dating and has left more people having to navigate the digital world in order to find love.
Author and dating coach Haifa Barbari shares her top tips on how to find love in lockdown.
Edited by Lorna Acquah

headline: 'I'd go back and have all the fun again'
summary: A dream Grand Slam, a lost medal and the mysterious phone call that sparked a new career. Sue Barker looks back on her life in tennis so far.
headline2: French Open: Sue Barker's 1976 win and a tennis story from a very different time
summary2: It was a dream Grand Slam title for a rising British tennis star. There might have been no TV cameras, no coach or parents watching either, but when she was lifting the trophy that didn't matter - this was supposed to be the first of many.

headline: Prince Philip: A life in London
summary: The capital was an important place for the Duke of Edinburgh throughout his long life.
headline2: Prince Philip: A life in London
summary2: Charities were an essential part of the Duke of Edinburgh's working life as a member of the Royal Family. Many of the 800 organisations he supported were in London and without his efforts, parts of the city could look very different today.

headline: 'Working poor' hardest hit by Covid in major UK city
summary: The disease arrived in the most affluent areas of Sheffield - but it's taken root in its poorest.
headline2: Covid: The 'working poor' are hardest hit, Sheffield study finds
summary2: The fact Covid infection rates have been higher in poorer communities has been well documented. But analysis from one major UK city reveals it is not the most deprived who have borne the greatest burden - rather the so-called working poor.

headline: Evidence suggests Ethiopian military behind massacre
summary: A BBC Africa Eye investigation uncovers the location of a massacre, and evidence linking it to the military.
headline2: Evidence suggests Ethiopian military carried out massacre in Tigray
summary2: An investigation by BBC Africa Eye has uncovered evidence that a massacre in northern Ethiopia was carried out by members of the Ethiopian military. It also reveals the precise location of the atrocity, in which at least 15 men were killed.

headline: Australian women protest gendered violence
summary: Rallies were held across the country in the wake of sexual assault allegations in parliament.
headline2: March 4 Justice: Watch thousands of Australian women protest sexual assault
summary2:
Thousands have gathered in marches across in Australia calling for gender equality and justice for assault victims.
The rallies come after a wave of discrimination, sexual assault and misconduct allegations in Australia's political offices.

headline: 'Mums at work don't take any nonsense'
summary: Louise O'Shea, head of Confused.com, shares her business advice for the CEO Secrets series.
headline2: CEO Secrets: 'Mums at work don't take any nonsense, there's no time'
summary2: Louise O'Shea is a firm believer that new mums make formidable employees. Like many working parents, the chief executive of price comparison site Confused.com, says lockdown is a challenge, but reckons it might bring benefits in the future.

headline: Obituary: DMX, the record-breaking rap star
summary: He was one of America's most successful rap stars, but his life was plagued by personal problems.
headline2: Obituary: DMX, the record-breaking rapper with bark and bite
summary2: Rapper DMX was one of America's most successful stars of the late 1990s and 2000s, whose achievements earned him a place in music history when he became the first artist to see his first five albums go to number one in the Billboard charts.

headline: Listen: India lead by 62 after Australia collapse
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary on day two of the opening Test between Australia and India in Adelaide.
headline2: Listen: India lead by 62 after Australia collapse
summary2:
15 wickets fall on day two
India led by 53 on first innings
India 244: Kohli 74, Starc 4-53
Aus 191: Paine 73*, Labuschagne 47
Ashwin 4-55, Yadav 3-40
India drop four catches
Day/night Test, Adelaide, day two
First Test of four-match series

headline: Critics Choice: Six key moments from the virtual ceremony
summary: Tears and triumphs for Hollywood's glitterati as they glam up for the virtual film and TV awards.
headline2: Critics Choice Awards: Six key moments from the virtual ceremony
summary2: There's nothing normal about this year's awards season. As the pandemic continues, red carpets and ceremonies have been put on hold or replaced by remote video acceptance speeches (accompanied by the usual shenanigans with the mute button).

headline: The Netflix show putting the spotlight on menopause
summary: The new Netflix show Bombay Begums puts the spotlight on menopause, but why aren't we talking about it?
headline2: The Netflix show putting the spotlight on menopause
summary2: Popular culture is generally associated with youth. But a new Netflix series that has a 49-year-old female lead, fighting the ravages of middle age, is being hailed for putting the spotlight on women's lifelong battle with their own bodies.

headline: 'We have won the war, America has lost'
summary: A BBC team meets the Taliban, a group that clearly sees itself as Afghanistan's government-in-waiting.
headline2: Afghanistan: 'We have won the war, America has lost', say Taliban
summary2: Driving to Taliban-controlled territory doesn't take long. Around 30 minutes from the northern city of Mazar-e-Sharif, passing large craters left by roadside bombs, we meet our host: Haji Hekmat, the Taliban's shadow mayor in Balkh district.

headline: England take it to the wire but India prevail - relive a thrilling third ODI
summary: Sam Curran scores 95 not out but England fall seven runs short against India in series-deciding third ODI in Pune.
headline2: England take it to the wire but India prevail - relive a thrilling third ODI
summary2:
India win by seven runs; take series 2-1
Curran almost takes England to victory with stunning 95 not out
England's bowlers restrict India to 329 all out
Three wickets for Wood and two for Rashid
Pant top-scores with thrilling 78 off 62 balls

headline: Is Iran covering up its outbreak?
summary: Iran has seen one of the worst coronavirus outbreaks but the true scale may be being downplayed.
headline2: Is Iran covering up its outbreak?
summary2: Iran is facing one of the largest coronavirus outbreaks in the world. Today, as families celebrate Persian New Year, Nowruz, there is concern the true scale of the virus is being downplayed by the government and could rapidly get much worse.

headline: Lung doctor describes Floyd's fight to breathe
summary: Dr Martin Tobin, a world renowned expert on breathing, testified on George Floyd's last moments.
headline2: Chauvin trial: Lung doctor describes George Floyd's fight to breathe
summary2:
Dr Martin Tobin, a world renowned expert on breathing, testified on George Floyd's last moments.
He told the court that Mr Floyd could be seen trying to use his fingers and knuckles to lift up the right side of his chest in order to breathe.

headline: 'I've been accused of kidnapping my white child'
summary: How one man went from being a “street kid” in Uganda, to adopting a white child in the US.
headline2: Transracial adoption: 'I've been accused of kidnapping my white child'
summary2: Stories of transracial adoption most often feature white families adopting black and Asian children. When the opposite happens, and black and Asian parents adopt white children, officials and members of the public can become very suspicious.

headline: ‘We were students negotiating for my father’s life’
summary: When Miles Hargrove’s dad was kidnapped by Colombian guerrillas, he asked a young friend to act as negotiator.
headline2: ‘We were students negotiating with armed guerrillas for my father’s life’
summary2: When Miles Hargrove's father Tom was taken hostage by armed guerrillas in Colombia, he put his trust in a 22-year-old friend to negotiate with the kidnappers and help bring his father home. Could these innocent young students possibly succeed?

headline: Why is the EU warning the UK over vaccines?
summary: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".
headline2: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
summary2: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, has said that if Covid vaccine supplies in Europe do not improve, the EU "will reflect whether exports to countries who have higher vaccination rates than us are still proportionate".

headline: Can digital clothes make fashion more sustainable?
summary: Some fashion companies are creating virtual clothes to reduce their environmental footprint.
headline2: Digital clothes: Could it make fashion more sustainable?
summary2:
Computer generated fashion models have been around for a few years, but some companies are now creating digital-only clothing for their virtual models to wear.
BBC Click’s Spencer Kelly finds out more.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: The friendly match that needed a no-fly zone
summary: Two years after their historic World Cup match, USA and Iran met again in 2000. It was supposed to build bridges - but not everything went to plan.
headline2: USA v Iran: The historic 2000 friendly match planned to bring countries together
summary2: Paris, 11 July 1998. On the eve of the World Cup final, in a first-floor room in a building on the Champs-Elysees, an idea for a football friendly was hatched that would lead to death threats, an FBI decoy and the closure of American airspace.

headline: Chinese study reveals Uighur 'assimilation' goal
summary: A high-level Chinese study says a massive work scheme is reducing Uighur population density in Xinjiang.
headline2: 'If the others go I'll go': Inside China's scheme to transfer Uighurs into work
summary2: China's policy of transferring hundreds of thousands of Uighurs and other ethnic minorities in Xinjiang to new jobs often far from home is leading to a thinning out of their populations, according to a high-level Chinese study seen by the BBC.

headline: Fire destroys historic factory in St Petersburg
summary: The former textile factory has been a St Petersburg landmark since 1841.
headline2: Nevskaya Manufaktura: Fire destroys historic factory in St Petersburg
summary2:
Two firefighters have been hurt, and one is missing after a massive blaze at an historic factory in St Petersburg.
The blaze started at about 12:30 local time on Monday, and quickly spread to all six floors of the Nevskaya Manufaktura building.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - second Test, day four
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day four of the second Test between Australia and India in Melbourne.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - second Test, day four
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
Australia 133-6 in second innings
Wade 40, Labuschagne 28, Jadeja 2-25
India 326 - first-innings lead of 131
Australia lead four-Test series 1-0
Second Test, MCG, day four

headline: 'We had a build-up of pigs after Brexit'
summary: Traders talk of "teething problems" and "obstruction" since the UK left the EU single market.
headline2: Brexit: Businesses find 'teething problems' trading with the EU
summary2: Three months on from the UK's departure from the EU and its single market, businesses are getting to grips with new rules and regulations. The BBC has spoken to three companies about their experience since 31 December and how they have adapted.

headline: Dog inherits $5m from deceased owner
summary: The will states that the new owner is to be reimbursed for Lulu's reasonable monthly expenses.
headline2: Lulu the dog inherits $5m from deceased US owner
summary2:
Lulu the border collie was left $5 million (£3.6 million) after her owner died last year.
Bill Dorris left the dog in the care of his friend, Martha Burton. The will states that Burton is to be reimbursed for Lulu's reasonable monthly expenses.

headline: Double mastectomy: 'I lost a large part of my identity'
summary: A social media personality has created a video about her BRCA2 gene test and upcoming surgery.
headline2: Double mastectomy: 'I lost a large part of my identity'
summary2:
Social media personality Lana Sophia created a video about her BRCA2 gene test and upcoming surgery.
She tested positive for a common mutation that increases the risk of cancer, and she's now decided to undergo a preventative double mastectomy.

headline: Uncovering the secrets of Australia's hidden reefs
summary: In the most extensive deep-sea study of two marine parks, scientists have found new and rare species.
summary2:
The most comprehensive deep-sea study of two marine parks off Australia has given a fascinating glimpse into what lives there.
Scientists have told the BBC how they used an underwater robot to make a host of discoveries.
Video by Isabelle Rodd.

headline: Haunting image of trapped sea turtle wins award
summary: Shane Gross captured the haunting photo while diving near the island of Eleuthera in the Bahamas.
headline2: Haunting image of trapped sea turtle wins underwater photo award
summary2:
Photographer Shane Gross captured a haunting photo of a turtle caught in a fishing line while diving near the island of Eleuthera in the Bahamas.
He hopes the image will bring more awareness of the effects of ghost fishing and plastic pollution.

headline: The Black Panther who hijacked a jet and made France home
summary: Melvin McNair hijacked a US airliner with his wife and children and then became a model French citizen.
headline2: The Black Panther who hijacked a jet to Algeria and started again in France
summary2: It was an unusual hijacking by a group of three men, two women and three young children. They commandeered a Delta airliner, flew across the Atlantic and the adults never set foot in the US again, four of them making France their permanent home.

headline: When the Queen was snapped 'giggling' at the duke
summary: A royal occasion descended into bewilderment and chuckles after a swarm of bees descended.
headline2: When the Queen was snapped 'giggling' at Prince Philip
summary2: Through his many years of service the Duke of Edinburgh attended thousands of official events with the Queen. Mostly they would work smoothly beside each other. But on one occasion, a swarm of bees derailed the normal efficient-running of events.

headline: How bad is the Covid crisis in US care homes?
summary: America's elderly are dying at an alarming rate in care homes, but the picture remains incomplete.
headline2: Coronavirus: How bad is the crisis in US care homes?
summary2: Elder care homes across the US have been hard-hit by the virus - though the true extent of the severity remains unclear, months in. One thing is certain, however - Covid-19 has yet again highlighted long-standing flaws in America's health system.

headline: The homeless addict who became a professor
summary: Jesse Thistle, a high school dropout, overcame addiction and homelessness to pursue an academic career.
headline2: The homeless drug addict who became a professor
summary2: Jesse Thistle spent more than a decade on the streets and in jail. But despite this he has managed to become an expert on the culture of his Indigenous Canadian ancestors - with the help of his mother, from whom he was separated as a young child.

headline: Aerial footage shows raging Australian bushfire
summary: The fire just outside of Perth has destroyed dozens of homes as the city remains in Covid lockdown.
headline2: Perth: Aerial footage shows Australian bushfire rage near city
summary2:
A bushfire just outside of Perth has destroyed dozens of homes as the Western Australian city remains in Covid lockdown.
Helicopter footage showed some of its trail of the destruction.
Read more: Homes lost as bushfire threatens locked-down Perth

headline: Relive Osaka's victory over Brady in Australian Open final
summary: How Naomi Osaka beat Jennifer Brady in the Australian Open women's final to land her fourth Grand Slam title.
headline2: Relive Osaka's victory over Brady in Australian Open final
summary2:
Naomi Osaka beats Jennifer Brady 6-4 6-3 to win Australian Open
Japanese third seed Osaka's fourth Grand Slam title
Osaka has won all four of her Grand Slam finals
7,477 fans allowed in Rod Laver Arena
Watch highlights from 14:15-15:45 on BBC One

headline: Putin vaccine memes flood social media
summary: False and misleading claims are made online after Russia announced the rollout of a vaccine.
headline2: Coronavirus: Putin memes flood social media
summary2: The announcement that Russia is forging ahead with its locally developed vaccine for Covid-19 has not only led to international concerns over its safety, but also generated a great deal of both misinformation and humour on social media platforms.

headline: The country treating psychosis without drugs
summary: People with psychosis are usually given powerful medication - in Norway they can now choose to go drug-free.
headline2: How Norway is offering drug-free treatment to people with psychosis
summary2: Most people with psychosis take powerful drugs to keep delusions and hallucinations at bay - but the side-effects can be severe. In Norway, a radical approach is now on offer via the national health system for patients who want to live drug-free.

headline: Can Asia help Myanmar find a way out of coup crisis?
summary: While Western sanctions may not help, China and South East Asia's influence may hold some sway.
headline2: Analysis: Can Asia help Myanmar find a way out of coup crisis?
summary2: The arrival of the Myanmar junta-appointed foreign minister, Wunna Maung Lwin, in Bangkok on Wednesday for an unannounced meeting with his Thai and Indonesian counterparts marked the start of a daunting diplomatic undertaking for South East Asia.
contributor_team: BBC News, South East Asia correspondent

headline: Traders hope shoppers return for Christmas
summary: Businesses hope for a positive few weeks before Christmas as they reopen after lockdown.
headline2: Covid-19: Traders hope shoppers return for Christmas after lockdown
summary2: Many businesses are getting ready to welcome back customers after four weeks of closure. When England's new tier system comes into force on Wednesday, shops, gyms and personal care services, like hairdressers, can reopen, if they are Covid-secure.

headline: 'Beaten and jailed for being a labour activist'
summary: Who is Nodeep Kaur, the young woman whose arrest has caused global outrage?
headline2: Nodeep Kaur: The jailed activist Meena Harris tweeted about
summary2: Earlier this month, Meena Harris, niece of American Vice President Kamala Harris, called for the release of Nodeep Kaur - a 25-year-old Indian labour rights activist who's been in prison for more than a month. Her arrest has caused global outrage.

headline: How a YouTube music channel became a mental health hub
summary: The Youtube channel that started as a musical diary but became a mental health hub.
headline2: Imlonely: How a YouTube music channel became a mental health hub
summary2: Among the thousands of music channels on YouTube there is one like no other. Imlonely started as a musical diary for one person but became a mental health community providing support to thousands of young people going through their toughest times.

headline: How Covid has changed South Africa's arts scene
summary: The permanent closure of a top venue symbolises the struggle many performers are facing.
headline2: South African artists struggle with Covid theatre closures
summary2: South Africa's once-thriving cultural scene is under threat because coronavirus restrictions have made it difficult to stage public events but some artists have found new ways to show off their creativity, as Mohammed Allie reports from Cape Town.

headline: The England disability cricketer who has become an elite-level gamer
summary: How England physical disability cricketer Liam O'Brien has become one of the best in the world at the Madden NFL computer game.
headline2: Madden NFL: The England cricketer who is starring in the gaming world
summary2: "It's bonkers, isn't it?" laughs Liam O'Brien. "The Americans probably think I'm some bloke who's played the game all his life. Imagine if they knew they were getting beaten by a skinny cricketer from Brighton who only recently learned the rules."

headline: Capturing 'flash rips' and the 'edge of the world'
summary: Dene Bingham photographs dangerous seas and wild places from a remote coast in Western Australia.
headline2: Photos from Australia: Capturing 'flash rips' and 'the edge of the world'
summary2:
A huge "flash rip" current and a bright pink lake are among the rarely seen phenomena captured by photographer Dene Bingham in remote Western Australia.
She tells the BBC about her favourite shots from hard-to-access places.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: The journey from black gold to green
summary: Two reports examine the tough choices that Scotland faces as it transitions away from oil and gas.
headline2: The journey from black gold to green
summary2: Claiming 150,000 jobs - direct and indirect - supporting high value exports, avoiding high cost imports, driving technology and productivity, and providing some energy security in an insecure world: the oil and gas industry in the UK is a big deal.

headline: Prince Andrew on the Queen's reaction to Philip's death
summary: Prince Andrew: the Queen says Prince Philip's death has left "a huge void in her life."
headline2: Prince Andrew says we've lost 'the grandfather of the nation'
summary2:
The Duke of York says the Queen has described Prince Philip's passing as leaving "a huge void in her life".
Prince Andrew attended a service at The Royal Chapel of All Saints along with other members of the Royal Family, and spoke about his father.

headline: Tennis tech to help if you are playing solo
summary: Jen Copestake tests out some gadgets which could help improve your game.
headline2: Tennis tech to help if you are playing solo
summary2:
Lockdowns have seen tennis courts remain empty but when restrictions are lifted in your area can technology help you brush up your game?
BBC Click’s Jen Copestake tests some of the latest tennis technology.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: The High Street hoping for 'booming summer trade'
summary: A £5bn scheme to help town centres is announced - but will it be enough to help a "struggling" town?
headline2: Budget 2021: Bedford's High Street hoping for 'booming summer trade'
summary2: Rishi Sunak has unveiled a £5bn scheme to help High Street shops and hospitality firms recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The BBC went to Bedford to speak to people about what they believe will help businesses survive and thrive after lockdown.

headline: The cost of speaking up against China
summary: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.
headline2: The cost of speaking up against China
summary2: Women who made allegations last month of rape and sexual abuse in Chinese detention camps have been harassed and smeared in the weeks since. Rights groups say the attacks are typical of an aggressive campaign by China to silence those who speak up.

headline: Coronavirus tales from Tom's Bench
summary: Jim Grover's pictures of people he met on Clapham Common who talked about their altered lives.
headline2: Coronavirus tales from Tom's Bench on Clapham Common
summary2: Throughout August, photographer Jim Grover photographed the people who sat on Tom's Bench on Clapham Common in London. The bench is in honour of the owner of Honest Tom's, a snack bar that has been there for 30 years, and who passed away last year.

headline: Looking for answers in the life of a killer
summary: Lisa Montgomery's lawyers argued she was a mentally ill victim of abuse who deserved mercy, but her victim's community said otherwise.
headline2: Lisa Montgomery: Looking for answers in the life of a killer
summary2: Lisa Montgomery - the only female inmate on federal death row in the US - has been executed for murder in the state of Indiana. Her lawyers had argued she was a mentally ill victim of abuse who deserved mercy. Her victim's community said otherwise.

headline: 'Could I have stopped my dad killing himself?'
summary: Kris Griffiths never imagined his father would take his own life. Now thinks he missed some red flags.
headline2: World suicide prevention day: 'Could I have stopped my dad killing himself?'
summary2: We think we know what suicidal behaviour looks like when someone is young, but when they are elderly the signs are often quite different. Kris Griffiths never imagined his father would kill himself, but now realises he missed a number of red flags.

headline: Listen: India beat Australia in controversial first T20
summary: India beat Australia by 11 runs in the opening match of the Twenty20 series in Canberra.
headline2: Listen: India beat Australia in controversial first T20
summary2:
India take 1-0 lead in T20 series
India 161-7: Jadeja 44* (23)
Henriques 3-22, Starc 2-34
Jadeja replaced as concussion sub
Aus 150-7: Sub Chahal takes 3-25
T20 debutant Natajaran 3-30
Canberra; three-match series
Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary

headline: Prince Philip 'widely respected' in Northern Ireland
summary: Northern Ireland's First Minister Arlene Foster has paid tribute to Prince Philip.
headline2: Prince Philip: Arlene Foster says the Duke was 'widely respected' in Northern Ireland
summary2:
Northern Ireland's First Minister Arlene Foster has paid to tribute to Prince Philip.
