She said she "had the privilege" of meeting the Duke on a number of his visits to the country and he had "a profound positive impact" on thousands of young people.

headline: Coronavirus testing: What is a false positive?
summary: Some commentators say rising cases are just because of false positive results. But that's not true.
headline2: Coronavirus testing: What is a false positive?
summary2: There has been a lot of talk on social media about "false positive" test results after several commentators suggested they might be seriously skewing the coronavirus figures - but that is based on a misunderstanding of the impact of false positives.

headline: Sturgeon: We should 'deeply appreciate' Prince Philip
summary: Scotland's First Minister sent her "deepest personal condolences" to the Royal Family.
headline2: Prince Philip: Nicola Sturgeon sends 'deepest personal condolences' to the Royal Family
summary2:
Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has paid tribute to Prince Philip, saying we should "deeply appreciate" his contribution to the country.
She added that the Duke of Edinburgh Award scheme had given "hope and inspiration" to countless children.

headline: She got ill when the pandemic hit - and still is
summary: For some people Covid just will not go away. One woman who thinks she had it has made an Instagram diary.
headline2: She got ill when the pandemic hit - and still is, six months later
summary2: Monique Jackson believes she caught Covid-19 early in the pandemic and nearly six months later she's still unwell. One of thousands in this position, she has been keeping an illustrated diary about her symptoms and her vain attempts to get treatment.

headline: 'We discuss food banks at school gates like it's normal'
summary: Stories of people struggling to eat in Oxford - from a jobless woman with an MA to a funeral director.
headline2: 'We discuss food banks at school gates like it's normal'
summary2: Six months after ex-Chancellor Sajid Javid announced an end to austerity, many families still rely on food banks to survive. The BBC's Chris Vallance has been spending time at a food bank in Oxford, hearing the stories of those who come seeking help.

headline: The friends who drove a bus behind the Iron Curtain
summary: The men and women who drove across Europe in a double-decker bus that was older than them.
headline2: The friends who drove a bus behind the Iron Curtain
summary2: In the summer of 1968, a group of friends adapted a double-decker bus and took it on a journey to Eastern Europe. Sponsored by two Scotch whisky-makers, they encountered Soviet tanks, a Romanian beer shortage and a perilous Yugoslavian mountain pass.

headline: Flying foxes 'among Earth's most mobile mammals'
summary: Australian species roam over massive distances and help the land recover from fire, research finds.
headline2: Australian flying foxes 'among Earth's most mobile mammals'
summary2:
Australian flying foxes are nomadic and roam over vastly larger distances than previously thought, research has found.
Scientist Justin Welbergen tells the BBC how their enormous journeys also help plants recover from bushfires.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Listen: Australia v India - third Test, day three
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day three of the third Test between Australia and India in Sydney.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - third Test, day three
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
India resume on 96-2 replying to Australia's 338
Shubman Gill dismissed for 50 yesterday, his maiden Test half-century
Third Test, day three, Sydney
Four-Test series level at 1-1

headline: Why popular YouTubers are building their own sites
summary: Some big YouTube names are building their own video sites on the side - just in case.
headline2: Why popular YouTubers are building their own sites
summary2: Whether he's showing off astronomically expensive computer gaming hardware or dumpster-diving for the cheapest PC builds possible, Linus Sebastian's videos always strike a chord, and have made him one of the most popular tech personalities on YouTube.

headline: Women's work during the pandemic
summary: On International Women's Day, how have women in the workplace been affected by Covid?
headline2: International Women's Day: Women's work during the pandemic
summary2: The pandemic has had widely varying effects on different generations, races, nations, sectors and genders. Nearly a year in, the data shows women in the UK have not been more likely to lose their jobs, but they have been harder hit in many other ways.

headline: Fighting to survive amid a pandemic
summary: With no clear path to reopening, New York's boxing gyms fear they may never return after the pandemic.
headline2: Coronavirus: The last-round fight for NYC's bastions of boxing?
summary2: Some of New York City's most iconic boxing gyms have been forced to close because of the coronavirus pandemic, and with no official guidance on how they can reopen, many gym owners fear the city will forever lose this sporting legacy, writes Ben Wyatt.

headline: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
summary: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.
headline2: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
summary2: More than 126,000 people in the UK who contracted coronavirus have lost their lives - with the pandemic claiming more than 2.6 million deaths worldwide. As the UK marks a year since the first coronavirus lockdown was called, it's a time for reflection.

headline: How risky is the route out of lockdown?
summary: Lockdown in England and Scotland will be lifted in stages - what are the risks associated with relaxing certain restrictions?
headline2: Lockdown review: What are the risks of schools, pubs and shops reopening?
summary2: The Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced a "roadmap" to lift England's lockdown restrictions in stages - starting with the reopening of schools. Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has said there will be a "progressive easing" of its rules.

headline: New fleece of life for sheep with 35kg coat of wool
summary: Baarack the sheep was taken in by a sanctuary after being found in a forest near Melbourne.
headline2: New fleece of life for Australian sheep with 35kg coat of wool
summary2:
A sheep with a 35kg (77lb) coat of wool has been given a new fleece of life after being found in a forest near Melbourne, Australia.
The ailing animal was taken in by Edgar's Mission Farm Sanctuary, who named him Baarack and relieved him of his burden.

headline: How does Westminster Budget affect Scots?
summary: What is the politics of direct spend in Scotland, and of Brand Rishi? Some questions answered.
headline2: How does the Westminster Budget affect Scots?
summary2:
How much of Rishi Sunak's Budget applies to Scots? What of business incentives?
What policy choices don't cross the border, and mean more funds for Holyrood?
What is the politics of direct spend in Scotland, and of Brand Rishi? Some questions answered.

headline: The dentist who helped a koala to walk
summary: Jon Doulman built a unique prosthetic after hearing about Triumph, a koala born without a foot.
headline2: The dentist who helped a koala to walk
summary2:
A koala - nicknamed Triumph - was born without a foot, meaning he had difficulty walking and climbing freely.
His vet nurse in Australia thought she had tried everything to help - until she mentioned Triumph to her local dentist.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: How does Welsh Parliament and government differ?
summary: Voters in Wales are going to the polls to elect members to the Welsh Parliament on 6 May.
headline2: Elections 2021: How does the Welsh Parliament and government differ?
summary2:
Voters in Wales are going to the polls to elect members to the Senedd in Cardiff Bay on 6 May.
Here's an explainer about differences between the Welsh Parliament and the Welsh government, courtesy of BBC Wales reporters Miriam Barker and Tyler Edwards.

headline: Coronavirus: All dressed up and nowhere to go
summary: Photographer Robin Sinha asked his neighbours in Walthamstow, London, to pose on their doorsteps.
headline2: Coronavirus: All dressed up and nowhere to go
summary2: As people across the UK continue to live in isolation we are all missing out on meeting up with friends, going for a meal or to the cinema, so photographer Robin Sinha asked his neighbours to pose on their doorsteps dressed as if ready for a night out.

headline: The racquet sport experiencing a pandemic boom
summary: Pickleball - a mash-up of tennis, badminton and ping-pong - saw a surge in participation last year.
headline2: Pickleball: The racquet sport experiencing a pandemic boom
summary2: If you've ever dinked in the kitchen, you probably already understand the allure of one of America's fastest growing sports. And if you haven't, you'd better paddle-up because sooner or later somebody is going to invite you to join a game of pickleball.

headline: Belly Mujinga's death: Searching for the truth
summary: A BBC investigation into the death of transport worker Belly Mujinga raises questions about the inquiries carried out by her employer and the police.
headline2: Belly Mujinga's death: Searching for the truth
summary2: The death of transport worker Belly Mujinga following reports she had been spat at by a customer, sparked calls for justice from millions of people. Now a BBC investigation raises questions about the inquiries carried out by her employer and the police.

headline: ITV boss on the future of Jeremy Kyle and Love Island
summary: The boss of ITV says she is not sure when or how hit TV show Love Island will return to the small screen
headline2: Dame Carolyn McCall on the future of ITV's Love Island and The Jeremy Kyle Show
summary2:
Love Island will return to the small screen, according to the boss of ITV.
But in what shape, form or year, Dame Carolyn McCall cannot confirm.
She has been speaking about the reality of reality TV In an interview with the BBC's media editor Amol Rajan.

headline: Protesting against a military coup... with shallots
summary: People are showing their opposition to Myanmar's military coup with shallots, shoe-tying and bicycle repairs.
headline2: Myanmar: Protesting against a military coup... with shallots
summary2:
People in Myanmar have been protesting against the military coup in perhaps their most creative way yet - by chasing shallots all over the streets of Yangon.
Other methods of showing opposition include shoe-tying, bicycle repairs and impromptu workouts.

headline: The dressmaker helping Australia with modified masks
summary: When Manmeet Kaur began giving away masks, she realised many would benefit from a new design.
headline2: Covid: The dressmaker helping Australia with modified masks
summary2:
When Covid-19 hit, Melbourne dressmaker Manmeet Kaur started making free masks for her local community.
But seeing her husband struggle to fit a mask over his turban, she came up with a solution that's become a huge help to many.
Video by Isabelle Rodd.

headline: Ancient Aboriginal art 'unlike anything seen before'
summary: The Maliwawa Figures offer a glimpse into life more than 6,000 years ago, scientists say.
headline2: Maliwawa Figures: Ancient Aboriginal art 'unlike anything seen before'
summary2:
A new style of ancient Aboriginal rock art in Australia has been documented for the first time.
Professor Paul Tacon explains how the 572 paintings known as the Maliwawa Figures offer a glimpse into life more than 6,000 years ago.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Queensland drenched as ex-cyclone sweeps state
summary: The first cyclone of Australia’s season has been downgraded but continues to cause danger.
headline2: Cyclone Imogen: Downgraded storm brings flood warnings to Queensland
summary2:
Queensland in Australia has seen heavy rainfall as an ex-tropical cyclone crosses the state, bringing warnings of “life-threatening" flash flooding.
Meteorologists say cyclones are more likely in Australia this year because of La Nina weather conditions.

headline: Should firm be allowed on wards to snap newborns?
summary: Thousands of new mums and babies are photographed in hospital each year - good service or intrusion?
headline2: Baby photos: Should Bounty be allowed to snap newborns?
summary2: Mothers-to-be can be served up an overwhelming amount of information and advice prior to giving birth. What many are not told about, however, is they could get a visit from a professional photographer while on the maternity ward recovering from delivery.

headline: The Syrians used as 'cannon fodder' in Nagorno-Karabakh
summary: Four Syrians say they enlisted for sentry duties in Azerbaijan and were sent to the Nagorno-Karabakh front line.
headline2: The Syrian mercenaries used as 'cannon fodder' in Nagorno-Karabakh
summary2: Turkey and Azerbaijan deny that Syrian mercenaries were used in the recent offensive in Nagorno-Karabakh but four Syrians have told the BBC that after enlisting for sentry duties in Azerbaijan, they were unexpectedly thrown into battle on the front line.

headline: Ecuador picks president in the shadow of Covid
summary: The young left-wing candidate Andrés Arauz faces pro-market former banker Guillermo Lasso.
headline2: Ecuador picks president under the shadow of Covid
summary2: As Ecuador grapples with the crippling social and economic impacts of Covid-19, its voters are choosing whether a left-wing technocrat and economist or a conservative banker-turned-politician is the most suitable president to lead them out of the crisis.

headline: Britpop's fights, flags and fall from grace
summary: The music scene's heady days are chronicled in a new book by former NME photographer Kevin Cummins.
headline2: Britpop: Photographer Kevin Cummins revisits the 90s
summary2: Twenty-five years since Blur and Oasis battled for chart supremacy, renowned music photographer Kevin Cummins has put the heady days of Britpop centre stage in a new book. The Manchester-born snapper recalls fights, flags and the scene's fall from grace.

headline: The manager who joined the club that hates him most
summary: For years Mircea Lucescu was enemy number one among fans of Dynamo Kyiv. This summer, he became the Ukrainian club's new manager.
headline2: Mircea Lucescu: The manager who joined the club that hates him most
summary2: Imagine Sir Alex Ferguson taking over at Liverpool. Sounds impossible? That is roughly the scenario that unfolded in Ukraine this summer, when Dynamo Kyiv decided to gamble on Mircea Lucescu, the ultimate symbol of their fiercest rivals, Shakhtar Donetsk.

headline: The 'surfing duck' causing delight in Australia
summary: The duck - called Duck - has become renowned locally for his daily forays into the sea.
headline2: Surfing duck: Pet becomes local celebrity at Australian beach
summary2:
When Australian woman Kate Miller decided to get a pet duck last year, she had no idea he'd become a local beach celebrity too.
Affectionately named Duck, he follows her into the water each day and delights onlookers by bodysurfing.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: What will happen to pet passports after Brexit?
summary: Will you still be able to take your pet to the EU after Brexit transition ends?
headline2: Brexit: Will I still be able to take my pet to the EU?
summary2: When the UK was part of the EU, you were able to take your dog or cat from the UK to the EU and back again without them having to go into quarantine, provided that certain conditions - such as having a pet passport and getting them microchipped - were met.

headline: A behind-the-scenes peek into Trump diplomacy
summary: A new BBC series explores former President Donald Trump's foreign policy through firsthand accounts.
headline2: A behind-the-scenes peek into President Trump's diplomacy
summary2: Before their first meetings with President Trump, world leaders were curious about which Trump would turn up at the negotiating table. Tim Stirzaker, director of a new BBC series, takes us through moments when the unconventional statesman revealed himself.

headline: Will we ever shake hands again?
summary: Will Covid-19 make handshakes a relic of the past? If so, what might that mean about the future of human touch and interaction?
headline2: Coronavirus: Will we ever shake hands again?
summary2: Around the world, humans are struggling to ignore thousands of years of bio-social convention and avoid touching another. Shaking hands might be one of the hardest customs to lose in the post-pandemic world but there are alternatives, writes James Jeffrey.

headline: Maximo Park on Grenfell and the Bataclan
summary: The North East indie-pop band say music can both "celebrate life" and ask "difficult questions".
headline2: Maximo Park on Grenfell, the Bataclan and fatherhood
summary2: On the day of the Grenfell Tower fire in 2017, North East indie icons Maximo Park were in London to perform a radio session. They turned on the television just beforehand and, says singer-songwriter Paul Smith, saw images they knew they would never forget.

headline: Conversation apps: 'It's given me a lift in life'
summary: The coronavirus lockdowns have been particularly isolating for many people who live alone.
headline2: Conversation apps: 'It's given me a lift in life'
summary2:
The coronavirus lockdowns have been particularly isolating for many people who live alone. But a number of apps have helped people make new friends and find new companions.
BBC Click's Lara Lewington finds out more.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: Why a $30m scheme failed to stop school abductions
summary: The 2014 student abductions led to a plan backed by the UK but little has come of it seven years on.
headline2: Why $30m didn't protect Nigerian pupils after Chibok
summary2: The kidnapping of hundreds of Nigerian schoolgirls from Chibok seven years ago led to the launching of a multi-million dollar plan, backed by a former UK prime minister, to bolster security at schools - but it failed to stop abductions and protect children.

headline: Australian Open: Relive all the action as Djokovic eased past Karatsev to reach final
summary: Relive all the action and reaction as world number one Novak Djokovic beats qualifier Aslan Karatsev in straight sets to reach the Australian Open final.
headline2: Australian Open: Relive all the action as Djokovic eased past Karatsev to reach final
summary2:
Top seed Novak Djokovic beats qualifier Karatsev 6-3 6-4 6-2 to reach men's final
Naomi Osaka beats Serena Williams 6-3 6-4 to reach final
Jennifer Brady reaches final after 6-4 3-6 6-4 win over Karolina Muchova
Click audio icon to listen to live commentary

headline: The human cost of India's coronavirus fake news
summary: False and misleading reports have surged in the country during the coronavirus pandemic.
headline2: Coronavirus: The human cost of fake news in India
summary2: Fake or misleading news can have a real impact on those who find themselves the targets. This has been a particular problem in India during the coronavirus pandemic, where reliable sources of news are frequently drowned out by unverified information online.

headline: 'I miss my weekly fish and chips'
headline2: Life in lockdown on one of UK's biggest estates
summary2:
More than 13,000 people live on the Alton Estate in Roehampton, making it one of the biggest in the UK.
Many of the residents have struggled with isolation and loneliness during the pandemic and have come to rely on community groups for support and company.

headline: The TikTok loving teen and others killed in Myanmar
summary: Hundreds have been killed since February. Now, their families are telling their stories.
headline2: Myanmar coup: The people shot dead since the protests began
summary2: More than 700 people have been killed by security forces since Myanmar's military grabbed power in a coup on 1 February, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma). The BBC has spoken to loved ones of three people who have died.

headline: Then and now: Rising temperatures threaten corals
summary: In a monthly feature, we explain how warming waters threaten the survival of a wonder of the seas.
headline2: Then and now: Rising temperatures threaten corals
summary2: In our monthly feature, Then and Now, we reveal some of the ways that planet Earth has been changing against the backdrop of a warming world. Here, we look at coral bleaching, and how warming waters are threatening the survival of a true wonder of the seas.

headline: Why a young former mayor is surging in US election
summary: Pete Buttigieg has leapt to the top of the pack ahead of the first Democratic primary. Can it last?
headline2: New Hampshire: Why young ex-mayor Buttigieg is surging
summary2: Pete Buttigieg has surged towards the top of the pack ahead of New Hampshire's Democratic primary on Tuesday. He's drawing more attention from voters - and more attacks from presidential rivals who view this newcomer to national politics as a serious threat.

headline: Oscars 2021: The female directors tackling tough truths
summary: Two international film nominees on the personal trials they faced making their hard-hitting films.
headline2: Oscars 2021: The female directors tackling tough truths
summary2: The inclusion of two female film-makers - Chloe Zhao and Emerald Fennell - in the nominations for best director at this year's Oscars has been hailed as historic. But two other women directors are also competing at the 2021 ceremony with their feature films.

headline: Tiny rare mouse-deer born at Marwell Zoo
summary: A rare Javan chevrotain, also known as a deer mouse, has been born at Marwell Zoo.
headline2: Marwell Zoo welcomes arrival of tiny baby mouse-deer
summary2:
Staff at Hampshire's Marwell Zoo have welcomed the arrival of a tiny mouse-deer.
The rare Javan chevrotain was born to parents Gus and Gwen, weighing about 370g (13oz).
The species originates from Java in Indonesia and the calf is currently the size of a rat.

headline: A look inside a US child migrant facility
summary: More than 3,400 unaccompanied children are held in the processing centre in Texas, four times the recommended amount.
headline2: US border crisis: A look inside a US child migrant facility
summary2: More than 3,400 unaccompanied children are being kept in the Texas processing centre. The Biden administration has allowed reporters to tour the facility following demands for greater access as the migrant crisis at the US-Mexico border continues to escalate.

headline: Why the unique ‘drumming’ bird is in peril
summary: The palm cockatoo is thought to be the only bird to use tools musically to attract a mate.
summary2:
The palm cockatoo is thought to be the only bird species to use tools musically – drumming wood to attract a mate.
Found only in Australia and neighbouring New Guinea, the species is facing a dramatic population decline, scientists say.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Listen: Pant guides India to thrilling series win over Australia
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day five of the fourth Test between Australia and India in Brisbane.
headline2: Listen: Pant guides India to thrilling series win over Australia
summary2:
India win fourth Test by three wickets
Pant hits unbeaten 89 to guide tourists to victory
India win series 2-1 to retain Border-Gavaskar trophy
Australia's first Test defeat at Gabba since 1988
Fourth Test, day five, Brisbane
Listen: ABC Grandstand commentary

headline: 'We are still here on the High Street'
summary: Business owners tell how they have adapted to maintain an income during the Covid pandemic.
headline2: High Streets: How businesses in Bedford are adapting to stay 'relevant'
summary2: Lockdown, the growth of online shopping and a general decline in High Street trade has combined to make it a tough time for retailers. As a new report predicts the loss of thousands of jobs and long term home-working, how are people adapting to make a living?

headline: Buildings shake as quake hits Japan's east coast
summary: The epicentre of the earthquake was off the coast of Fukushima Prefecture, 37 miles (60km) below surface.
headline2: Strong 7.3 magnitude earthquake strikes eastern coast of Japan
summary2:
A 7.3 magnitude earthquake has struck off the coast of eastern Japan.
The epicentre of the earthquake was off the coast of Fukushima Prefecture, 37 miles (60km) below surface.
Buildings shook but no damage has been reported, and no tsunami warning was issued.

headline: 'She is very beautiful and intelligent but she is Indian'
summary: Dorothy Bonarjee was Indian by birth, English by upbringing, French by marriage - and Welsh at heart.
headline2: 'She is beautiful but she is Indian': The student who became a Welsh bard at 19
summary2: An Indian student won acclaim in Wales as a bard and became the first woman to get a law degree from University College London. And although racial prejudice brought a heartbreaking end to a three-year relationship she never went home, writes Andrew Whitehead.

headline: The story behind Firmino's smile
summary: Roberto Firmino was a shy young boy. His smile did all the talking. But he was "football crazy" - and that sparked a remarkable journey.
headline2: Roberto Firmino: Liverpool forward's journey from humble origins to starring Anfield role
summary2: With giant palm trees stooping towards turquoise water, high-rise hotels glimmering in the sun, and opulent beachside restaurants selling lobster and expensive liqueurs, it's easy to see why Maceio, the capital of Alagoas state, is known as Brazil's Caribbean.

headline: 'If Covid didn't kill me, nothing ever will'
summary: Jake Vujovic spent three weeks on a ventilator last May and is still battling symptoms ten months on.
summary2:
The BBC first met Jake Vujovic last May, when he was recovering from three weeks on a ventilator in an ICU.
Ten months on he is still suffering symptoms, with chronic fatigue and requiring crutches to walk, but he says he is determined to make a full recovery.

headline: Capturing isolation on a remote New Zealand island
summary: As the country emerges from lockdown, a photographer has documented life on rugged Stewart Island.
headline2: Coronavirus: Capturing isolation on New Zealand's Stewart Island
summary2:
On the far southern tip of New Zealand, sparsely populated Stewart Island has been closed off from the world during the coronavirus pandemic.
As the country emerges from lockdown, photographer Laire Purik has documented how locals coped.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Explorers film the world's deepest known shipwreck
summary: US Navy destroyer USS Johnston has been re-located and surveyed at a depth of 6,456m in the Philippine Sea.
headline2: USS Johnston: Explorers film the world's deepest known shipwreck
summary2:
A privately funded expedition has successfully relocated, surveyed, and filmed the world’s deepest known shipwreck.
US Navy destroyer the USS Johnston lies at a depth of 6,456m (21,180ft) after sinking during the Battle off Samar in 1944, in the Philippine Sea.

headline: A turbulent childhood stalked by exile, illness and death
summary: In marrying, Philip was able to regain the "simple pleasures" of family life he had lost aged eight.
headline2: Prince Philip: A turbulent childhood stalked by exile, mental illness and death
summary2: Prince Philip is being remembered as the longest-serving consort in British history, who sacrificed a naval career to give steadfast support to his wife. But it is easy to forget he had endured an exceptionally turbulent childhood, writes historian Philip Eade.

headline: India beat England by eight runs to level series - relive thrilling finish
summary: India beat England by eight runs in the fourth Twenty20 to set up a series decider in Ahmedabad.
headline2: India beat England by eight runs to level series - relive thrilling finish
summary2:
India win by 8 runs to level series
Five-match series level at 2-2
India 185-8: Suryakumar 57 (31)
Iyer 37 (18), Pant 30 (23); Archer 4-33
Eng 177-8: Stokes 46 (23), Roy 40 (27)
Pandya 2-16, Thakur 3-42
Fourth T20, Ahmedabad
Final match on Saturday at 13:00 GMT

headline: The reasons why football is set for major change
summary: The "toxic" plans to reform football detailed in 'Project Big Picture' have not been dismissed and "change is coming". This is why.
headline2: Why football is facing major change, despite 'toxicity' of Project Big Picture plan
summary2: When Premier League chief executive Richard Masters addressed a parliamentary hearing on 10 November, he delivered a line all English football could agree on, despite the fierce opposition that followed Project Big Picture's unexpected unveiling a month before.

headline: Students 'see the beauty in the ordinary'
summary: First-year photography students at the University for the Creative Arts show off their work.
headline2: Students 'see the beauty in the ordinary'
summary2: It has been a tough year for all of us but for those starting their university life it has meant adapting to a new way of studying - not only remote learning but also finding new ways to explore creative ideas with other students, having never met in real life.

headline: Kangaroos can 'communicate' with humans
summary: Their behaviour challenges a notion that such abilities come only from domestication, a study finds.
headline2: Kangaroos can 'communicate' with humans, study finds
summary2:
Kangaroos are able to intentionally communicate with people and "ask for help", a study has found.
The research challenges the notion that only domesticated animals display this behaviour, co-authors from the UK and Australia tell the BBC.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: The nation that doesn't know its Premier League star
summary: Onel Hernandez is Cuba's most successful footballer, but many fans in his homeland have never even heard of him.
headline2: Onel Hernandez: Norwich City winger and his country's curious football scene
summary2: It is a typically sweltering Saturday morning in central Cuba, and in the sleepy town of Moron, where rickshaw drivers seek shade and pigs are read their last rites amid growling motorbikes, a gentle-faced mother-of-four sits near the town square, phone in hand.

headline: Photos capture Cruden Bay life in lockdown
summary: Doorstep photos give insight into the lives of people during lockdown who live in a small village in Aberdeenshire.
summary2:
Residents of Cruden Bay have been photographed living life in lockdown.
Some people put on fancy dress and used props for the snaps, while others just waved at the camera.
The project was the idea of hotel owner Lucy Taylor and local photographer Lynda Thompson.

headline: How ready is Scotland to unlock?
summary: With the country opening up a little more on Friday, here are five things about the state of the pandemic.
headline2: Covid: How ready is Scotland to unlock?
summary2: Covid travel restrictions around Scotland are due to be eased on Friday, earlier than expected, but there will be a much more significant relaxation in the rules from 26 April. As Scotland prepares to unlock, here are five things about the state of the epidemic.

headline: The 12-year-old girl who cleans graves
summary: Tj Kleeman began cleaning an Australian cemetery eight years ago, and says "it feels amazing".
headline2: Why this Australian girl has cleaned graves for eight years
summary2:
Australian Tj Kleeman was four when she moved with her family into a house next to a cemetery.
Scared of ghosts, she began cleaning graves to overcome her fear.
Eight years on, Tj is still cleaning graves - but for a very different reason.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Bright meteor lights up sky over England
headline2: UK meteor lights up sky over parts of England
summary2:
People across England have reported seeing a large light streak across the sky on Sunday.
The meteor was spotted shortly before 22:00 GMT and was visible for around seven seconds.
It was filmed on cameras across the country including in Bath, Wigan and Yorkshire.

headline: Shooting celebrities: Thirty years behind the lens
summary: Celebrity portrait photographer Andy Gotts celebrates 30 years behind the camera.
headline2: Shooting celebrities: Thirty years behind the lens
summary2: Andy Gotts' photographic career began 30 years ago when, as a student, he persuaded Stephen Fry to pose for him. Since then he has photographed the biggest names in the entertainment business. Here, he remembers a few of those who have been captured by his camera.

headline: 'I’ll buy five items and only keep one of them'
summary: With online returns soaring during the pandemic, tech firms are helping retailers deal with the rise.
headline2: 'I’ll buy five items and only keep one of them'
summary2: Online shopping has risen strongly during the pandemic, but this has also meant a big increase in the number of items being sent back because they don't fit, or aren't as expected. A number of tech firms are helping retailers deal with these higher returns levels.

headline: Go behind the scenes with the Drag Race UK finalists
summary: Bimini, Tayce, Lawrence and Ellie on what it’s like to be a finalist on Drag Race UK.
headline2: Drag Race UK finalists reveal their best and worst moments
summary2:
This year's Drag Race UK finalists reveal their best and worst moments from the show, how they’ve dealt with the public’s reaction and they share their pearls of wisdom before the final tonight on BBC Three.
Producer: Eleanor Lawrie
Video Journalist : Lorna Acquah

headline: 'I want it to be normal for women to take photos'
summary: A photography exhibition in Somalia by two women challenges the way the country is seen.
headline2: Somalia photography: 'I want it to be normal for women to take photos'
summary2: Somalia often conjures up images of violence and destruction but a photography exhibition in the capital, Mogadishu, sets out not only to challenge that perception but also to recast who is defining those images in the first place, as the BBC's Mary Harper reports.

headline: The England kit the media hated - and the fans adored
summary: First worn 40 years ago, why was England's red, white and blue kit given a kicking by the pundits?
headline2: Why Admiral's 'flashy' England strip now commands respect
summary2: It is 40 years since England's footballers first took to the field in Admiral's colourful reinterpretation of the national kit. Derided as garish and tacky, and almost abandoned after just a handful of games, how has it become one of the most-loved football strips?

headline: World-famous cellist's impromptu vaccine centre concert
summary: Yo-Yo Ma performs in a waiting room after receiving his second dose of Covid-19 vaccine.
headline2: Yo-Yo Ma: World-famous cellist's impromptu vaccine centre concert
summary2:
Cellist Yo-Yo Ma put on an impromptu concert in a waiting room after he received his second dose of a Covid-19 vaccine.
He played Ave Maria at the Berkshire Community College in Massachusetts, where vaccine recipients wait and are monitored after getting their jab.

headline: 'Optimistic' Malala signs deal with Apple TV+
summary: The Nobel Prize laureate on why she is hopeful about change and representation on screen.
headline2: Malala Yousafzai signs production deal with Apple TV+
summary2:
Activist Malala Yousafzai has signed a multi-year deal with Apple TV+, to produce programming including documentaries, dramas, comedies and films.
The Nobel Prize laureate said she wanted to inspire women and girls to "make the change that they want to see happen".

headline: The dying teenager who wanted world peace (and love)
summary: An American teen with cancer went to Moscow in 1988 hoping to meet Gorbachev and rid the world of nukes.
headline2: The dying teenager who wanted world peace (and love)
summary2: When Californian teenager Jeff Henigson was diagnosed with brain cancer and given two years to live, a children's charity granted him the wish of a lifetime. But Jeff didn't choose to go to Disneyland or meet his favourite footballer - Jeff just wanted world peace.

headline: Meet the Aussie skateboarding an 'insane' 4,000km
summary: Gordy says he is skating from Melbourne to Cairns but 'didn't realise how big Australia was' when he took on the trip.
summary2:
During lockdown last year, Tom Dury hatched a plan to skateboard 4,000km (2,500 miles) from Melbourne to Cairns.
The Australian - who goes by the name Gordy - is now nine weeks into the trip and says he "didn't realise how big Australia was".
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Saving an Australian paradise's 'cloud forest'
summary: A rare environment on Australia's Lord Howe Island has faced a complex battle for survival.
headline2: Lord Howe Island: Saving an Australian paradise's 'cloud forest'
summary2:
Australia's Lord Howe Island is famous for its beauty and unique mix of plants and animals.
Nowhere is this more evident than in a rare cloud forest atop the island's two southern mountains.
But its environment has faced a battle for survival.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Rohit hits fifty after Axar takes 6-38 for India - reaction & analysis
summary: India reach 99-3 in reply to England's meagre 112 on the opening day of the third day-night Test in Ahmedabad.
headline2: Rohit hits fifty after Axar takes 6-38 for India - reaction & analysis
summary2:
Rohit 57*, Rahane 1*
Kohli 27 - falls in final over of day
England slip from 74-2 to 112 all out
Nine England wickets fall to spin
Axar 6-38, Ashwin 3-26; Crawley 53
England pick one spinner, India three
Day-night third Test, Ahmedabad
Four-match series level at 1-1

headline: The woman who refuses to be defeated by Covid
summary: Kenyan Josephine Muchilwa lost her chef's job and then her business but is now trying something else.
headline2: Covid in Kenya: The woman who refuses to be defeated by the virus
summary2: At the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, Josephine Muchilwa was working as a cook, but like many others in Kenya and around the world, she lost her job. Over the past year, BBC World Service Business Daily presenter Ed Butler has been hearing how she has coped.

headline: The neo-Nazi who became an anti-Nazi
summary: Christian Picciolini became a Nazi skinhead as a teenager but now he fights extremism.
headline2: Christian Picciolini: The neo-Nazi who became an anti-Nazi
summary2: Just one conversation was enough to recruit Christian Picciolini into the neo-Nazi movement, but it took him years to get out. To make amends for his wrongdoing, he has spent the last quarter of a century persuading hundreds of others to make a break with extremism.

headline: Whatever happened to local TV?
summary: A decade ago, the government set out a plan for channels to be "a new voice for local communities".
headline2: Whatever happened to local TV?
summary2: A decade ago, a plan for new local TV channels to provide "a new voice for local communities" was set out by the government. Since they launched, the local identities and ambitions of many have eroded, but their operators insist they have fulfilled the original aim.

headline: The fans putting it all out there on YouTube
summary: BBC Sport meets some of the supporters going through the emotional extremes of following their side on YouTube and asks them why they do it.
headline2: Who needs Soccer Saturday? The fans putting it all out there on YouTube
summary2: "Lanzini!" exclaims Simeon Daniel before his face crumples in horror. His hands move to his head, flicking his headphones from his ears in grim acceptance. His brother, Ben, breaks the subsequent stunned silence. "Oh no, no, no," he mutters, turning away in disgust.

headline: The remote island where jumpers are always in fashion
summary: Photographer Chris Morphet travelled to Fair Isle 50 years ago to document designs which are still influencing fashion.
headline2: Fair Isle: The remote island where jumpers are always in fashion
summary2: Fifty years ago, the allure of Fair Isle knitwear inspired freelance photographer Chris Morphet to travel to the UK's most remote community. His pictures documented the lives of Shetland islanders and the distinctive designs which are still influencing fashion today.

headline: Has Thomas Becket's treasured 'little book' been found?
summary: Thomas Becket, killed in Canterbury in 1170, was attached to a "little book", which may now have been found in Cambridge.
headline2: Has Thomas Becket's treasured 'little book' been found?
summary2: More has been written about Thomas Becket, the archbishop hacked to death in Canterbury Cathedral exactly 850 years ago, than any other non-royal English person of the Middle Ages. And yet it seems it's still possible to discover new things about his remarkable life.

headline: Stories of 'solidarity and survival' from the steel city
summary: A streamed play marries monologues about "strength" with songs by Sheffield's musical heroes.
headline2: 'Solidarity and survival': Streamed play has Sheffield songs and steel
summary2: An award-winning musical featuring songs by Sheffield guitar hero Richard Hawley was meant to be on stage at the National Theatre around now. When the pandemic put paid to that, its co-writer penned a new online play featuring some of the city's other musical greats.

headline: Academy Museum: Why this could be a mecca for movie fans
summary: After decades of wrangling this ambitious venue devoted to cinema is finally set to open.
headline2: Academy Museum: Why this could be a mecca for movie fans
summary2: Plans for something like it have been around for decades - and Hollywood has seen several planned opening dates come and go. But in Los Angeles this September the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures is finally to open, with some online programmes kicking in next month.

headline: 'I'm afraid to go to school after being kidnapped'
summary: Hundreds of students have been abducted in northern Nigeria, leading many schools to close.
headline2: Nigeria kidnappings: 'I'm afraid to return to school'
summary2:
More than 800 students have been abducted from their schools in northern Nigeria since December.
In most cases they have been freed after ransoms were believed to have been paid - although the authorities rarely admit that.
The BBC’s Ishaq Khalid reports from Kaduna.

headline: The unsung hospital heroes of the pandemic
summary: People working behind the scenes at a hospitals trust reflect on the lessons they have learned.
headline2: Covid-19: Ipswich and Colchester hospitals' unsung heroes of the pandemic
summary2: Doctors and nurses in intensive care departments have shared their experiences throughout the pandemic, but what of the army of staff who have worked behind the scenes to keep hospitals running? The BBC spoke to three people about the highs and lows of the past year.

headline: 'We are first-hand witnesses of this devastation'
summary: Four nurses describe the pressure they are under as the second coronavirus wave gathers force.
headline2: Coronavirus doctor's diary: 'We are first-hand witnesses of this devastation'
summary2: The second coronavirus wave has already put many hospitals under great pressure, and it's nurses and physios who bear the brunt of it, writes Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary (BRI). Here he introduces four nurses, who describe the strain they are now under.

headline: Cliff collapses on to Sussex beach
summary: Tyler Vacher captured the aftermath of a large-scale cliff fall which left a big mound of rubble at the base.
headline2: Seaford Head: Cliff partially falls on to Sussex beach
summary2:
A large-scale cliff fall left a big mound of rubble on a Sussex beach.
The collapse at Seaford Head, near Eastbourne, was reported to coastguards on Monday afternoon.
Several warnings have been issued about the dangers of cliff collapses in the area in recent months.

headline: Pubs and restaurants 'thrown to the wolves'
summary: The hospitality sector gives its reaction to the tier three announcement.
headline2: Covid: Tier 3 status means dining pubs 'thrown to the wolves' in Beds and Herts
summary2: With much of England moving into tier three of coronavirus restrictions, pubs and restaurants in these "very high alert" areas can now only offer a takeaway and delivery service. How will hospitality businesses in Hertfordshire and Bedfordshire cope with the changes?

headline: On patrol: Night vision in DR Congo
summary: Photographer Hugh Kinsella Cunningham goes out with UN peacekeepers.
headline2: On patrol: Night vision in DR Congo
summary2: With the world focused on the Covid-19 pandemic, humanitarian crises and conflicts are still unfolding at a rapid pace. Photographer Hugh Kinsella Cunningham has been to the Democratic Republic of Congo where he took pictures of UN peacekeepers during a night patrol.

headline: Locked out: Mid-Pacific with nowhere to land
summary: A group of performers were halfway across the ocean in a 75ft boat when the pandemic erupted - leaving them with nowhere to go.
headline2: In mid-Pacific with nowhere to land
summary2: A group of performers were halfway across the Pacific Ocean in a 75ft sailing boat when the coronavirus pandemic erupted. Suddenly countries began closing their sea borders - leaving the vessel with no guarantee of a safe haven before the start of the typhoon season.

headline: Martin Luther King in colour
summary: Jordan J Lloyd has added digital colour to black-and-white photos of Dr King and the civil rights movement.
headline2: Colourising historical photos of the civil rights movement
summary2: Friday is the 92nd anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther King - and, after extensive historical research, Jordan J Lloyd has added digital colour to black-and-white photographs of Dr King and other public-domain images of the US civil rights movement in the 1960s.

headline: Chinese orbiter's first close-up view of Mars
summary: The Chinese mission had cameras that recorded its orbit insertion at the Red Planet on Wednesday.
headline2: Chinese Tianwen-1 orbiter's first close-up view of Mars
summary2:
of the planet as it made its big braking manoeuvre. In this short movie, Tianwen-1's large solar wing dominates the view, but the Martian atmosphere and surface topography are clearly visible.
Courtesy of CNSA
Read more: China succeeds in putting a probe in Mars orbit

headline: Line of Duty stars sponsor football teams
summary: The stars of BBC One's Line of Duty have taken time out from their duties tackling police corruption to help a Belfast football club.
headline2: Line of Duty stars sponsor football teams
summary2:
The stars of BBC One's Line of Duty have taken time out from their duties tackling police corruption to help a Belfast football club go undercover.
Three of the actors in the drama series have come together to buy new kits for two of the girls' teams at Belfast Celtic.

headline: Five takeaways from Biden's White House cabinet
summary: After delays, Biden's team of top White House aides at now steering the US federal government.
headline2: Five takeaways from Biden's White House cabinet
summary2: It's been a long three months, but US President Joe Biden has now finalised his White House cabinet - the top aides that will guide his administration's oversight of the federal government. On Thursday, the president sat down for the first time with his assembled team.

headline: Bringing Mars back to Earth
summary: An audacious mission to bring rock samples from Mars back to Earth is about to begin - find out more with our illustrated guide
headline2: Nasa Perseverance rover: Bringing Mars back to Earth
summary2: Nasa's Perseverance rover will land on Mars this Thursday to begin an audacious effort to bring samples of Martian rock and soil back to Earth. It will involve two robotic rovers to collect the best specimens, and an elaborate delivery system to get this material home.

headline: Listen: India beat Australia to win Twenty20 series
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from the second of three T20s between Australia and India at the SGC in Sydney.
headline2: Listen: India beat Australia to win Twenty20 series
summary2:
Use audio icon to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
Second of three T20s
Australia 194-5: Wade 58, Smith 46, Natarajan 2-20
India win toss and choose to bowl
Wade captains Australia with Finch injured
Sams makes T20 debut for Australia
India won first game by 11 runs

headline: 'There is a pandemic but we still need to be open'
summary: How different is the current lockdown to previous ones in 2020 for businesses?
headline2: Covid-19: 'There is a pandemic but we still need to be open'
summary2: On Monday, the prime minister announced the return of a national lockdown and tougher coronavirus restrictions. Many businesses have had to close again but, for those who can stay open, what differences are they seeing this time compared to the lockdown of spring 2020?

headline: 'I left her as a baby - 16 years later she saved my life'
summary: When Matjames Metson hit rock bottom after Hurricane Katrina, it was the daughter he hadn't seen for 16 years who turned his life around.
headline2: 'I left her as a baby - 16 years later she saved my life'
summary2: After losing everything in the horror of Hurricane Katrina, artist Matjames Metson was broke, traumatised and "braced for the end" when he received an unexpected phone call. It was from the daughter he hadn't seen since she was a baby, and it gave him a reason to live.

headline: Have any two words become more weaponised?
summary: What do a series of recent controversies tell us about the politics around "cancel culture"?
headline2: Cancel culture: Have any two words become more weaponised?
summary2: A US president is banned from social media. A long-time national science reporter resigns in disgrace after repeating a racial slur. A school district drops the names of famous Americans from its buildings. A congresswoman is punished for spreading conspiracy theories.

headline: Dutch crew rescued from 'near-capsize'
summary: The crew were forced to abandon ship when the sea got really rough.
headline2: Dutch crew rescued from 'near-capsize'
summary2:
A crew heading to Norway were forced to abandon ship when the sea got really rough.
The cargo ship began to list during the bad weather, with the captain concerned it may capsize.
Norwegian Coast Guards filmed the dramatic rescue, even lifting one person out of the sea.

headline: 'We haven't seen our families in over a year'
summary: Foreign students and workers on the difficulties of a year of UK lockdowns and travel restrictions.
headline2: Covid-19: Foreign nationals in the UK on lockdown isolation from family
summary2: When England went into its first lockdown in March 2020, it meant many people from abroad who were working or studying in the country were unable to go home to see their families. What effect have travel restrictions had on people not being able to see their loved ones?

headline: Brexit: A month of 'hell' or 'teething problems'?
summary: A month on since the UK's deal with the EU, how are businesses faring under the new regulations?
headline2: Brexit one month on: Firms describe hold-up 'hell' and' teething problems'
summary2: It's been a month since the UK and the EU began trading under the terms of a new post-Brexit trade deal. The new arrangements mean changes for many businesses which deal with Europe - so how has the last month been for them, and how are they feeling about their futures?

headline: Thousands of mice plague Australian town
summary: This video has been removed for rights reasons.
headline2: Thousands of mice plague Australian town
summary2:
Thousands of mice have infested a town in south-east Australia.
Locals in Gilgandra, New South Wales, say it is their worst mouse infestation in decades.
Video filmed on a farm in the area showed the extent of the problem.
This video has been removed for rights reasons.

headline: Riot police break up fake festival in Brussels
summary: The crowd of thousands gathered for a concert announced on social media as an April Fool's Day prank.
headline2: Riot police break up fake festival in Brussels
summary2:
Police horses and a water cannon were used to disperse a fake concert in Brussels announced on social media as an April Fools' Day prank.
Police moved to enforce Belgium's strict Covid-19 social-distancing rules that prohibit gatherings of more than four people outdoors.

headline: Shops need 'total clarity' as to when they can reopen
summary: Scottish Retail Consortium director David Lonsdale outlines what shops need as they face another lockdown.
summary2:
Shops need "total clarity" as to when they can reopen, according to the director of the Scottish Retail Consortium (SRC).
David Lonsdale said closing shops could see retailers facing £135m per week of lost revenue.
READ MORE: Looming lockdown a 'hammer blow' for business

headline: Covid on campus: Partying, isolating - and sometimes both
summary: How students are making the best of the opportunities to study and socialise in a pandemic.
headline2: Covid on campus: Partying, isolating - and sometimes both
summary2: Anoushka Mutanda Dougherty was in the first year of her degree at Manchester University when the pandemic began and all students were sent home. Now she's back and has been finding out from friends and first-year students how the pandemic is affecting their social lives.

headline: Health claims debunked
summary: Beware of false claims about 5G, inhaling steam, skin colour and vaccines.
headline2: Coronavirus: Health claims debunked
summary2:
5G does not spread Covid-19, steam inhalation is not a cure and skin colour can't protect from catching the virus. Reality Check's Chris Morris tackles the latest false claims about coronavirus circulating online.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Filmed by Myles Burke

headline: Tim Peake's tips on how to become an astronaut
summary: The European Space Agency is on the search for new astronauts and will be accepting applications in March.
summary2:
Tim Peake was the first British European Space Agency (Esa) astronaut to visit the International Space Station.
Esa will be accepting applications in March to fill four to six vacancies in its astronaut corps and it wants this draft process to be as inclusive as possible.

headline: The view from my window
summary: Jemima Yong's pictures record the comings and goings on a patch of land outside her London home.
headline2: Coronavirus: The view from my window
summary2: Like many of us, photographer Jemima Yong is spending a lot of time indoors due to the restrictions caused by the spread of coronavirus. But she has been drawn to document a small piece of land outside her London home. Here, Yong talks about her work, entitled Field 2020.

headline: ‘I was raped at 14 - the video ended up on a porn site’
summary: When Rose Kalemba was raped, it took her months to persuade a porn website to remove the video.
headline2: ‘I was raped at 14, and the video ended up on a porn site’
summary2: Last year Rose Kalemba wrote a blog post explaining how hard it had been - when she was raped as a 14-year-old girl - to get a video of the attack removed from a popular porn website. Dozens of people then contacted her to say that they were facing the same problem today.

headline: Zahawi: 'Looking at options' on vaccine passports
summary: Vaccines Minister Nadhim Zahawi explains the government's Covid position on vaccine passports.
headline2: Zahawi: 'Looking at options' on Covid vaccine passports
summary2:
The government is considering the ethical issues raised by Covid passports, Vaccines Minister Nadhim Zahawi has said.
"It would be remiss" of ministers not to "look at all the options that are available to us to take our lives back" but that no decision had yet been made.

headline: In pictures: May Day protests around the world
summary: Despite pandemic-related restrictions on daily life, some people are taking part in demonstrations.
headline2: In pictures: May Day protests around the world
summary2: Every year May Day is used to mark many things - from the coming of spring in the Northern Hemisphere to the fight for workers' rights. This year many rallies have been scaled back because of coronavirus lockdowns, although some have taken place on the streets and online.

headline: ‘No Fizzy Drink Guy’ gets unexpected TikTok fame
summary: An Australian man documenting his addiction to soft drinks goes viral.
headline2: TikTok: New-found fame for ‘No Fizzy Drink Guy’
summary2:
Over the past 35 years Melbourne man Rohit Roy has battled a fizzy drink addiction. Despite many failed attempts to kick the two-can-a-day habit, it wasn’t until he started documenting his journey on TikTok, that he found real motivation and support.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Ashworth: 'PM needs to be honest'
summary: The shadow health secretary says he's "sceptical" about the idea of "digital ID cards".
headline2: PM 'needs to be honest' about vaccine passports
summary2:
The Labour Party is "sceptical" about the idea of "digital ID cards", shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth has said.
"Boris Johnson needs to be clear and honest with the British people as to exactly what it is he is proposing," with regard to Covid passports, he said.

headline: 'I am a gay!'
summary: Stephen Thomas Smith, 24, says people assume he can't be gay due to his disability.
headline2: Disability: 'I am a gay!'
summary2:
Stephen Thomas Smith, 24, uses Tik Tok to raise awareness and break down the stigmas surrounding LGBT and disability issues.
The 24-year-old, who has cerebral palsy, says he often experiences "ableism" in society and people assume he can't be gay because of his disability.

headline: 'Each one of these people mattered'
summary: A visual artist in Washington, DC wants people to stop viewing the death toll as simply a number.
summary2:
As the US Covid death toll approaches 500,000, Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg is working to commemorate each life lost through an elaborate art installation 'In America: How Could This Happen?', featuring thousands of white flags.
Video by Hannah Long-Higgins and Chelsea Bailey

headline: Zuckerberg's Biden problem
summary: President Biden's open dislike of Facebook could spell problems for the social network.
headline2: Zuckerberg's Biden problem
summary2: Before the Cambridge Analytica story had broken. Before Facebook's acknowledgement that its platform had been used to help incite ethnic cleansing in Myanmar. Before the WhatsApp lynchings in India. Before QAnon and the Proud Boys - Mark Zuckerberg had the world at his feet.

headline: Haunting images of America's painful past
summary: Rich Frishman has travelled the United States, documenting the vestiges of racial oppression that are all around us.
headline2: Haunting images of America's painful past
summary2:
Rich Frishman has travelled across the US, photographing the vestiges of racial oppression in smalltown America.
From bricked-over segregated entrances to the gravesites of lynching victims, "these places surround us and we don't realise it," he says.
Video by Joaquim Salles

headline: The 'climate doomers' preparing for society to fall apart
summary: Few scientists think climate change will cause society to collapse any time soon - but some people are getting ready anyway.
headline2: The 'climate doomers' preparing for society to fall apart
summary2: An article by a British professor that predicts the imminent collapse of society, as a result of climate change, has been downloaded over half a million times. Many mainstream climate scientists totally reject his claims, but his followers are already preparing for the worst.

headline: Listen: Australia add to lead after spirited India fightback
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary on day three of the decisive fourth Test between Australia and India in Brisbane.
headline2: Listen: Australia add to lead after spirited India fightback
summary2:
India 336 - trail by 33 on first innings
Thakur 67, Sundar 62, Hazlewood 5-57
Thakur & Sundar add 123 from 186-6
Sundar on debut, Thakur's 2nd Test
Australia 369: Labuschagne 108
Fourth Test, day three, Brisbane
Four-match series level at 1-1
Listen: ABC Grandstand commentary

headline: 'My fatigue was like nothing I've experienced before'
summary: Thousands of Long Covid patients are waiting for help but the health service is struggling to cope.
headline2: Long Covid: 'My fatigue was like nothing I've experienced before'
summary2: Thousands of coronavirus patients, including many who were not ill enough to be hospitalised, have been suffering for months from fatigue and a range of other symptoms. While professionals struggle to support them, what can they learn from those living with chronic illnesses?

headline: Greece earthquake collapses buildings
summary: The 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near the city of Larissa, but was felt across the country.
headline2: Greece earthquake shakes shop and collapses buildings
summary2:
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near the Greek city of Larissa on Wednesday morning, and was felt across the country.
An elderly man had to be rescued from his home in the village of Mesochori, which had partially collapsed, but there have been no reported serious injuries.

headline: Why 'stay-at-home parent' is a job title
summary: LinkedIn now gives parents a way to reflect a career gap. Can it help the return-to-work challenge?
headline2: Why 'stay-at-home parent' is a job title
summary2: Many women returning to the workforce after having children say they face a challenging welcome back. Professional networking site LinkedIn recently added a new feature, allowing parents to use "stay-at-home mom" or "stay-at-home dad" as a job title. Will it make a difference?

headline: Why Texas is saying 'no' to all new refugees
summary: Texas' longstanding reputation for hospitality has taken a hit as it embraces a new Trump refugee plan.
headline2: Why Texas is saying 'no' to all new refugees
summary2: Texas wants to halt admission of all new refugees, saying the needs of Texans must be prioritised over others. But aid workers in Texas say there is sufficient help for the state's growing homeless population as well as newly arriving refugees, writes journalist James Jeffrey.

headline: Denmark official faints during Covid conference
summary: Tanja Erichsen collapses during a press conference and is taken to hospital as a precaution.
headline2: Denmark official Tanja Erichsen faints during a Covid conference
summary2:
This video has been removed for rights reasons.
The head of Denmark's medicines agency, Tanja Erichsen, fainted during a press conference on the decision to stop using the Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid vaccine.
She was taken to hospital as a precaution and has reportedly recovered.

headline: How bushfires almost wiped out a 'cryptic' species
summary: Already critically endangered, Australia's Kangaroo Island dunnart has lost most of its tiny habitat.
headline2: Kangaroo Island dunnart: Saving a bushfire-ravaged marsupial
summary2:
The Kangaroo Island dunnart was already critically endangered when its habitat was ravaged by Australia's bushfires last year.
Now ecologists are desperate to protect the "cryptic and mysterious" marsupial.
The BBC visited Kangaroo Island to learn more.
Video by Simon Atkinson

headline: The South Koreans enslaved in the North's mines
summary: A report describes how prisoners of war are used as slave labour to generate money for the regime.
headline2: North Korea enslaved South Korean prisoners of war in coal mines
summary2: Generations of South Korean prisoners of war are being used as slave labour in North Korean coal mines to generate money for the regime and its weapons programme, according to a report released by a human rights organisation. The BBC has taken a closer look at the allegations.

headline: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
summary: Jang Yeong-jin fled North Korea to escape a loveless marriage. Now he is engaged to his boyfriend.
headline2: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
summary2: Jang Yeong-jin's remarkable story as North Korea's only openly gay defector was covered by the international media after he published his autobiography. Now, almost a quarter of a century after fleeing the country, he tells the BBC that he plans to marry his American boyfriend.

headline: How 'lockdown birdwatching' is aiding bushfire recovery
summary: Birdwatching has boomed during Australia's Covid-19 lockdown - and it's having an unexpected benefit.
headline2: How 'lockdown birdwatching' is helping Australia's bushfire recovery
summary2:
Birdwatching has boomed during the Covid-19 lockdown in Australia, and it's having an unexpected benefit.
Scientists have been using an increase in data on bird identification apps to help with conservation efforts after Australia's devastating bushfires.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Then and now: A 'megadrought' in California
summary: See how extreme weather has affected an vital reservoir in California.
headline2: Then and now: A 'megadrought' in California
summary2: In our monthly feature, Then and Now, we reveal some of the ways that planet Earth has been changing against the backdrop of a warming world. Here, we look at the effects of extreme weather on a crucial reservoir that supplies water to millions of people in northern California.

headline: 'Until I met my debt mentor I couldn't always feed my kids'
summary: Audie was in debt and losing hope. But Jeannette, who'd once been in debt herself, was able to help.
headline2: 'Until I met my debt mentor, I couldn't always feed my kids'
summary2: When her oldest daughter left home, Audie had to go part-time in order to be there for her two younger children after school. Previously, she'd made ends meet by working long and unsociable hours. Now she was sinking into debt - and at first there didn't appear to be a solution.

headline: The three key arguments used by Chauvin's defence
summary: Derek Chauvin's defence team started making the case that he is not at fault for George Floyd's death.
headline2: George Floyd death: The three key arguments used by Chauvin's defence
summary2: Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin's defence team began to make their case on day 12 of the trial. An expert witness testified that Chauvin's use of force on George Floyd was "justified". Here are the three key arguments the defence is using to try and win the case.

headline: 'Getting married is the most important thing'
summary: What will the lifting restrictions on weddings mean to couples and those in the industry?
headline2: Covid-19: 'Getting married is the most important thing'
summary2: Covid lockdowns and restrictions have thrown many wedding plans into disarray over the past year. Following the prime minister's announcement on Monday, there is hope that they can go ahead later in 2021. What does this mean for the industry and to those waiting to tie the knot?

headline: From boom to bust - why lockdown hasn't led to more babies
summary: Research shows that the US and parts of Europe are facing slumps in birth rates.
headline2: Covid: From boom to bust - why lockdown hasn't led to more babies
summary2: For those who thought that lockdown would leave couples with little else to do than procreate, there was a surprise - not a baby boom but a baby bust. Research shows that the US is facing the biggest slump in births in a century and in parts of Europe the decline is even steeper.

headline: Did we see a Christmas coronavirus spike?
summary: Christmas gatherings were cut back but was there still an impact on Covid cases?
headline2: Did we see a Christmas coronavirus spike?
summary2: It is almost a month since Christmas was "downsized" across the country. But in many parts of the UK, people were allowed to meet in Christmas "bubbles" - if only for just one day. So what impact did this have? The overall picture shows a sharp increase in cases around this time.

headline: China says US cannot speak from 'a position of strength'
summary: The country's most senior diplomat, Yang Jiechi, said both the Americans and Chinese are "great people."
headline2: China says US cannot speak from 'a position of strength'
summary2:
China's most senior foreign policy official, Yang Jiechi, has told the US that it isn't qualified to "speak from a position of strength" when criticising China.
The exchange took place in the first high-level talks between the Biden administration and China, being held in Alaska.

headline: 'My husband’s ashes are still unscattered, but we’re OK’
summary: Sophie Townsend lost her husband - and father of her children - to cancer. But in time their lives returned to an even(ish) keel.
headline2: ‘My husband’s ashes are still unscattered, but we're doing OK’
summary2: When Sophie Townsend's husband, Russell, died in 2012 she was overcome with grief, but as the mother of two young children she had to keep going. Here she describes the new life she began at the age of 39, a single parent and widow slowly "re-entering the world" - and becoming OK.

headline: Priyanka Chopra Jonas locked down in London
summary: Speaking as her autobiography is published, the actress talks about lockdown in the UK.
headline2: Priyanka Chopra Jonas locked down in London
summary2:
Hollywood star Priyanka Chopra Jonas has released her autobiography, Unfinished.
Chopra writes about attending a boarding school and speaks to the BBC's Sophie van Brugen about her marriage to Nick Jonas.
The White Tiger star is currently in London filming a new television series.

headline: 'The night-time industry needs to come back'
summary: How will businesses serving nightlife in a rural market town fare when venues are able to reopen?
headline2: Covid-19: 'The night-time industry needs to come back'
summary2: Nightclubs were some of the first businesses to close at the start of the coronavirus pandemic and haven't been able to open since. More than a year on, their wait continues. How is the night-time economy in a rural market town hoping to bounce back when venues can finally reopen?

headline: Hospital staff relieved as Covid case numbers fall
summary: There are just four people with Covid left at Royal Bournemouth Hospital and staff are feeling relieved.
headline2: Royal Bournemouth Hospital staff relieved as Covid case numbers fall
summary2:
Staff on the Covid ward at Royal Bournemouth Hospital have said they are relieved to see fewer cases coming into the hospital.
University Hospitals Dorset bosses say it is now time to prepare for the backlog of elective work, as well as the possibility of a third wave of the virus.

headline: Amazon's new till-less shop in London
summary: Amazon Fresh, a till-less grocery store, opens in London
headline2: Amazon opens till-less grocery store in London
summary2:
Amazon has opened a till-less grocery store in London.
It is the first of its "just walk out" stores outside the US. At Amazon Fresh, shoppers scan a smartphone app when they enter and are billed automatically when they leave.
The BBC's Emma Simpson shows us how it works.
Read more

headline: 'Ant and Dec are getting on a bit'
summary: Ollie and his best mate, Jacob, have become the comedy duo everyone's talking about on TikTok.
headline2: Schoolmates Ollie and Jacob on TikTok fame
summary2:
If you haven't heard the catchphrase "It's Ollie Ball here" then where have you been?
Ollie and his best mate, Jacob, have become the comedy duo everyone's talking about on video sharing platform, TikTok.
Newsround caught up with the lads at their school in Bolton to find out more.

headline: ‘The painful call that helped me break free from my mum’
summary: When Farah Sayeed told her mother she wasn't coming home after university, it caused a painful rift.
headline2: 'The phone call that brought me freedom - but broke my mother's heart'
summary2: In the 1990s many second-generation British Asians were coming of age and breaking free - they had grown up in a different country from their parents and were forging their own path. For Farah Sayeed, it meant making a difficult phone call which left her mother, Runi, heart-broken.

headline: Smart glasses help to find your makeup palette
summary: Jen Copestake tries out some of the latest augmented reality beauty technology.
headline2: Smart glasses help to find your makeup palette
summary2:
The coronavirus pandemic has seen makeup counters around the world temporarily close, but there are some tech solutions which can help if you need some advice or want to try a new shade of lipstick.
BBC Click’s Jen Copestake finds out more.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: 'I prayed to God to make me a girl'
summary: Growing up as a Hasidic Jew, Abby Stein had no idea trans people existed - she just felt sure she was a girl.
headline2: Ultra-Orthodox and trans: 'I prayed to God to make me a girl'
summary2: When Abby Stein came out as trans, she sent shock waves through the ultra-Orthodox Hasidic community. A direct descendant of Hasidic Judaism's founder, The Baal Shem Tov, Abby's parents considered her their first-born son and a future rabbi - but she was adamant that she was a girl.

headline: Catch-up: Formula E - Rome E-Prix
summary: Watch live coverage of the third E-Prix of the season in Rome, Italy.
headline2: Catch-up: Formula E - Rome E-Prix
summary2:
Use play icon to watch live coverage
Jean-Eric Vergne wins round three
Briton's Sam Bird in second with Mitch Evans in third
Third race of season - fourth takes place on Sunday
Nyck de Vries and Briton's Sam Bird won opening two races of the season respectively
All races live on BBC

headline: 'It takes strength to be a Nigerian woman'
summary: Etinosa Yvonne's photographs challenge stereotypical representations of women during the pandemic.
headline2: Coronavirus in Nigeria: Changing women's representation through photography
summary2:
Visual artist Etinosa Yvonne works with women in rural communities in Nigeria to change the way women are represented in the country.
Her recent work with international charity ActionAid in Abuja captures how women have been affected by the coronavirus.
Video journalist: Adenike Oke

headline: 'I feel just as Indian as I feel black'
summary: Three women who share Kamala Harris' mixed parentage talk about balancing the two sides of their lives.
headline2: Being mixed race like Kamala Harris: 'I feel just as Indian as I feel black'
summary2:
Kamala Harris made history when she became the first female, black and South Asian vice-president of the United States in January.
Three women who share Ms Harris' mixed parentage open up about balancing the two sides of their lives.
Produced by Nalini Sivathasan, BBC Asian Network.

headline: Buttler's unbeaten 83 helps England thrash India
summary: England chase 157 to beat India by eight wickets in the third Twenty20 in Ahmedabad to take a 2-1 lead in the series.
headline2: Buttler's unbeaten 83 helps England thrash India
summary2:
England win with 10 balls to spare
England lead 2-1 in five-match series
Buttler 83* (52), Bairstow 40* (28)
Kohli drops Buttler on 76
Bairstow dropped by Chahal on 21
India 156-6: Kohli 77* (36)
Kohli scores 49 off last 17 balls
Fit-again Wood 3-31, Jordan 2-35
Third T20, Ahmedabad

headline: 'I was painting when I heard I won'
summary: Hearing his neighbours' cheers was how Sir Anthony Hopkins found out he'd won Best Actor.
headline2: Sir Anthony Hopkins on finding out Bafta Best Actor win
summary2:
Sir Anthony Hopkins said he heard his neighbours cheering following his win, and thought they were watching football.
He didn't attend the ceremony and was holidaying in Wales when he received the news whilst painting.
Sir Anthony became the oldest winner of the Best Actor category.

headline: Covax vaccine plan: What is it and how will it work?
summary: A global scheme aims to ensure people in poorer countries get vaccinated against Covid.
headline2: Covax vaccine plan: What is it and how will it work?
summary2:
Vaccines are one of the solutions to end the coronavirus pandemic, according to health experts.
But there are fears that richer countries could hoard jabs at the expense of poorer ones.
A global plan called Covax is trying to share vaccines fairly among all nations - can it succeed?

headline: Forests the size of tennis courts
summary: Micro-forests are being planted in towns and cities around the world.
headline2: Forests the size of tennis courts
summary2:
Hundreds of tiny forests are being planted in towns and cities around the world.
The British government has announced funding for 12 of them in the UK. But what's the point of a forest the size of a tennis court?
A film for People Fixing the World by Richard Kenny and Anna Holligan.

headline: 'Getting the vaccine in Ramadan helps others'
summary: Many Muslims are welcoming pop-up clinics to support the vaccination programme during Ramadan.
headline2: Covid: 'Getting the vaccine in Ramadan helps others'
summary2: A series of pop-up vaccination centres in mosques have been set up to support Muslims to get a Covid vaccination during Ramadan, after concerns from Islamic scholars and NHS leaders that the fasting period may discourage some. BBC News meets people who are welcoming the new services.

headline: Will Emily be allowed to keep her baby?
summary: All Emily's previous children have been taken into care. Social services now have to make a decision on her 10th.
headline2: Will Emily be allowed to keep her baby?
summary2: When a mother has a child taken from her by the courts and social services the chances are that her next baby will be removed as well - in the baby's own interests. But social workers may give the mother and her partner a chance to show that the new child will be safe in their hands.

headline: How a Holocaust survivor is changing US policing
summary: Training based on Ervin Staub's idea of bystander intervention is driving police reform in the US.
headline2: Ervin Staub: A Holocaust survivor’s mission to train ‘heroic bystanders’
summary2: A training programme designed to discourage police misconduct is being adopted across the US after months of protests over the use of excessive force. The Holocaust survivor behind the training believes that, after initial success in one city, it can change police culture nationwide.

headline: Kim and Kanye split 'cordial and co-ordinated'
summary: Celebrity blogger Perez Hilton says reports suggest Kim "had been over the marriage for a long time".
headline2: Kim Kardashian and Kanye West split 'cordial and co-ordinated' - Perez Hilton
summary2:
Kim Kardashian has filed for divorce from rapper Kanye West after seven years, according to reports in the US media.
Celebrity blogger Perez Hilton comments on the news and why the reality TV star didn't file for divorce sooner.
Read more: Kim Kardashian 'files to divorce Kanye West'

headline: Is it worth tracking your carbon footprint?
summary: Apps that offer to track your carbon footprint are becoming more common, but are they any good?
headline2: Is it worth tracking your carbon footprint?
summary2: Increasingly concerned about the environment, for the past few years Alya Annabi, 26, has taken steps to live a more sustainable lifestyle, with the digital learning manager refilling goods at plastic-free stores, making her own skincare from scratch and composting her kitchen waste.

headline: Thousands flee Caribbean volcano
