summary: La Soufrière on St Vincent island spews ash 6km into the air as thousands are evacuated.
headline2: La Soufrière: Thousands flee Caribbean volcano
summary2:
Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes on the Caribbean island of St Vincent after a volcanic eruption blanketed the island in smoke and ash.
La Soufrière, which has been dormant for decades, first started showing volcanic activity in December, which picked up this week.

headline: How Dean Jones 'captivated' a cricket generation
summary: The Australian came to represent "an upbringing in the game" for many fans, says writer Gideon Haigh.
headline2: Dean Jones: 'Audacious' Australian cricketer who captivated a generation
summary2:
Fans around the world are mourning former Australia cricketer Dean Jones, who has died aged 59.
Cricket writer Gideon Haigh explains why he became "a kind of upbringing in the game" for so many people.
READ MORE: Dean Jones: Former Australia batsman dies aged 59
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: The bleached Australian reef and a Covid challenge
summary: When coral bleaching was suspected in a pristine reef, scientists turned to some unlikely surveyors.
headline2: Rowley Shoals: The bleached Australian reef and a Covid challenge
summary2:
Coral bleaching was detected in a usually healthy reef off Australia's north-western coast earlier this year.
But due to Covid lockdown rules, the discovery presented scientists with a challenge: how could they survey the reef without being able to travel there?
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Abducted, shackled and forced to marry at 12
summary: Up to 1,000 Christian, Hindu and Sikh girls are abducted in Pakistan every year, then forced to convert to Islam, and to marry.
headline2: Abducted, shackled and forced to marry at 12
summary2: Farah, a 12-year-old Christian girl, says she was taken from her home in Pakistan last summer, shackled, forced to convert to Islam and made to marry her kidnapper. It's a fate estimated to befall hundreds of young Christian, Hindu and Sikh women and children in the country each year.

headline: 'Smokescreen is like sunglasses for the vines'
summary: Winemakers in France are trying to save their crops amid a sudden drop in temperatures.
headline2: French winemakers fight frost with fire
summary2:
Winemakers in France are trying to save their crops after unseasonably cold weather swept parts of Europe.
Jean de Saint Venant, who owns a vineyard in the Loire Valley, is lighting fires to create a smokescreen to protect the vines from sudden changes in temperature as the sun rises.

headline: Prince Philip: Officer, husband, father
summary: His Royal Highness Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, lived most of his life in the public eye.
summary2:
His Royal Highness Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, lived most of his long life in the public eye.
Born a European prince, he became the husband and vital support to one of the most famous women in the world.
In the process he carved a leading role of his own in Britain and the world.

headline: 'If I saw a busy pub, I wouldn't go in'
headline2: Covid: 'If I saw a busy pub, I wouldn't go in'
summary2:
One year on from the first lockdown, people in Wales say they think it will be "a while" to get back to normal life.
Some said the experience had made them wary of crowded places like pubs.
Others said they would not mind measures like social distancing and face masks staying in place.

headline: The day we introduced our black and Asian families
summary: Blasian - black and Asian - couples now exist in South Africa... but they don't always have an easy time.
headline2: Blasian love: The day we introduced our black and Asian families
summary2: Since the end of apartheid - and even for some years before that - young South Africans have been free to date whoever they want. But relationships between black people and the country's Asian population remain quite rare - and the approval of parents, and grandparents, is not a given.

headline: Why hasn't the UK listed smell loss as a Covid-19 symptom?
summary: Some scientists argue that it is becoming urgent to tell people with sudden loss of smell to self-isolate.
headline2: Coronavirus: Why hasn't the UK listed loss of smell as a symptom of Covid-19?
summary2: Government advisers have been considering since March whether to include loss of smell among the criteria for deciding whether someone has Covid-19. Evidence that it is one of the symptoms is already strong and some scientists argue this is now an urgent step, as the lockdown is eased.

headline: The artist who can’t recognise her own face
summary: Carlotta is a prolific self portrait artist from Munich with prosopagnosia - face blindness.
headline2: Prosopagnosia: The artist in search of her face
summary2: Carlotta has never been able to recognise faces, neither the faces of other people, nor her own. Her condition, face blindness, has had a major effect on her life but has also given her a sense of purpose as an artist - to make self-portraits of the face she cannot picture in her mind.

headline: How can we stop our village flooding again?
summary: The residents of Fishlake, badly flooded two months ago, want eco-friendly solutions to the problem.
headline2: How can we stop our village flooding again?
summary2: Two months ago, as flood water descended on the village of Fishlake, near Doncaster, Peter Trimingham battled through the night to help neighbours to safety. The experience has left him thinking hard about what can be done to prevent this happening again, reports the BBC's Sue Mitchell.

headline: In pictures: Hidden depths of a life lived
summary: Photographer Laura Page challenges the stereotypes of age.
headline2: In pictures: Hidden depths of a life lived
summary2: During the past year, the pandemic has forced many elderly people to isolate and remain indoors for much of the time, yet many have led, and continue to lead, extraordinary lives. Photographer Laura Page set out to capture their stories and challenge what she sees as ageist stereotypes.

headline: 'A rollercoaster week' - reaction after Djokovic wins ninth Australian Open
summary: Relive Novak Djokovic's emphatic victory over Daniil Medvedev in the Australian Open men's final.
headline2: 'A rollercoaster week' - reaction after Djokovic wins ninth Australian Open
summary2:
Novak Djokovic beats Daniil Medvedev 7-5 6-2 6-2 to win ninth Australian Open
Djokovic's 18th Grand Slam title - two behind Federer and Nadal
Serb has won all nine finals he has played in Melbourne
Medvedev lost his composure in second and third sets
Highlights on BBC One from 13:50 GMT

headline: Medical students 'proud' to help during pandemic
summary2:
Medical students have told the BBC they are "proud" of the work they have done while volunteering to work for the NHS during the coronavirus pandemic.
Hannah Beare said it had been "valuable learning experience".
Students have been delivering vaccines, taking samples and covering shifts.

headline: 'My son was also killed by police in Minneapolis'
summary: An immigrant community divided by the anti-racist protests rocking the US.
headline2: George Floyd death: 'The same happened to my son'
summary2: Youa Vang Lee was at her home in Minneapolis when her son showed her the video of George Floyd dying under a police officer's knee. Lee, a 59-year-old Laotian immigrant who assembles medical supplies at a factory, heard Floyd cry out for his mother. It triggered a deep and familiar pain.

headline: Why this female 'garbo' hopes more will join her
summary: Belinda Janson hopes she won't be the only woman driving garbage trucks in Ipswich, Australia, for long.
headline2: Why this female garbage truck driver hopes more women will join her
summary2:
Belinda Janson is the only female waste truck driver in Ipswich, Australia - a statistic the local council is trying to change.
They are designing a new female-only driver program to try and break down barriers and attract more women to the waste industry.
Video journalist: Isabelle Rodd

headline: Australia storms: Dog rescued from sea of foam
summary: Hazel disappeared under a sea of foam at Byron Bay as wild weather battered the coast.
summary2:
A woman in Byron Bay had to rescue her dog, who was lost under a sea of foam, as wild weather batters Australia's east coast.
Byron Bay's famous beach has all but disappeared, and more than 2,000 homes in the cities were out of electricity on Monday after strong winds struck power lines.

headline: Trade deal: Was this week's vote bad news for the NHS?
summary: There has been a row on social media about whether this week's trade bill means the NHS is for sale.
headline2: Trade deal: Was this week's vote bad news for the NHS?
summary2: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer tweeted on Thursday: "The Trump administration would like a trade deal with the UK to benefit America's big healthcare companies. That's why Labour tried to make it law that the NHS would be exempt from any future trade agreements. The Tories voted it down."

headline: The art dealer, the £10m bronze and the Holocaust
summary: Western museums are under pressure to return looted treasure, but what of those in private collections?
headline2: The art dealer, the £10m Benin Bronze and the Holocaust
summary2: Countless historic artefacts were looted from around the world during the colonial era and taken to Europe but there is now a growing campaign to return them. Among the most famous are the Benin Bronzes seized from modern-day Nigeria. Barnaby Phillips finds out about one family's dilemma.

headline: Rapper reptiles make a splash in new home
summary: Flavor Flav and Tupac are among the new arrivals at a reptile park in New South Wales, Australia.
headline2: Rapper reptiles: Alligators make a splash at new home
summary2:
Alligators named Flavor Flav and Tupac are among the new arrivals at the Australian Reptile Park in New South Wales.
Ten alligators were transferred from Australia Zoo, increasing the number at the reptile park to 55.
Unlike the crocodile, alligators are not a native species to Australia.

headline: In pictures: Isolation portraits over the internet
summary: Photographer Fran Monks's portraits of those in isolation due to the coronavirus
headline2: Coronavirus: Isolation portraits over the internet
summary2: As the lockdown started to take hold, photographer Fran Monks, like many freelancers, found her paid commissions were being postponed. But she really wanted to document this extraordinary time where so many are isolated at home and so set about using her skills as a portrait photographer.

headline: Why are Americans so angry about masks?
summary: How face coverings meant to curb virus spread became grounds for political battle.
headline2: Coronavirus: Why are Americans so angry about masks?
summary2: In the midst of the pandemic, a small piece of cloth has incited a nationwide feud about public health, civil liberties and personal freedom. Some Americans refuse to wear a facial covering out of principle. Others in this country are enraged by the way that people flout the mask mandates.

headline: Photographer captures stunning Australia starscape
summary: Stunning 'starlapse' photography highlights the beauty of remote Queensland's skies.
headline2: Australian night sky on show in 'starlapse' video
summary2:
Photographer Stuart Mckay captures "starlapses" - time-lapse photography of the night sky.
He lives in the coastal town of Agnes Water, Queensland, six and a half hours' drive north of the nearest light pollution.
The remote location enables him to take night photos with incredible detail.

headline: A Bedtime Story with Bridgerton star Regé-Jean Page
summary: CBeebies viewers can tuck in with the Duke of Hastings this Sunday.
headline2: Bridgerton star Regé-Jean Page reads CBeebies Bedtime Story
summary2:
From Bridgerton to Bedtime Stories, get ready to tuck in with the Duke of Hastings.
The star of the hit Netflix drama, Regé-Jean Page, is reading Rain Before Rainbows to CBeebies viewers this Sunday, Mother's Day.
UK viewers can watch CBeebies Bedtime Stories daily at 6:50pm or on iPlayer.

headline: Chinatowns fighting racism and pandemic to survive
summary: People have been avoiding Chinatowns since the start of the pandemic - and now they're struggling.
headline2: Covid-19: Chinatowns fighting racism and pandemic to survive
summary2: Lunar New Year is usually the busiest period for businesses in Chinatowns around the globe. But in 2020, it coincided with the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic, leaving many restaurants empty. A year on, the BBC speaks to business owners to find out how they survived - and what's next.

headline: 'They wanted to drown me at birth - now I'm a poet'
summary: Kuli Kohli has always used writing as a means of escape from the prejudice she has experienced as an Asian woman with cerebral palsy.
headline2: 'They wanted to drown me at birth - now I'm a poet'
summary2: Born in an Indian village with cerebral palsy, Kuli Kohli was lucky to survive. Neighbours told her parents they should throw her in the river, instead they brought her to the UK. As she grew up here, writing became her means of escape - and transformed her life in ways she never expected.

headline: Ros Atkins On… Macron’s Covid-19 Crisis
summary: Coronavirus has forced France into a third lockdown and raised questions about President Emmanuel Macron’s leadership.
headline2: Ros Atkins On… Macron’s Covid-19 Crisis
summary2:
Coronavirus has forced France into a third lockdown and raised questions about President Emmanuel Macron’s leadership.
Producer credit: Courtney Bembridge, Henry Belot and Mary Fuller
You can watch and listen to longer editions of "Ros Atkins on…" on BBC iPlayer and BBC Sounds respectively.

headline: Congo's new generation of sharp dressers revealed
summary: A new book highlights the "sapeurs" in the twin Congolese capitals of Brazzaville and Kinshasa.
headline2: Congo's sapeurs pass their style on to a new generation
summary2: Some residents of the twin Congolese capitals of Brazzaville and Kinshasa have long been known for their love of stylish dressing - in particular members of the Society of Ambience-Makers and Elegant People (Sape). These photographs by Tariq Zaidi reveal a whole new generation of "sapeurs".

headline: Archbishop calls for 'a better future for all'
summary: In his Easter sermon, Justin Welby calls for generosity as society emerges from the coronavirus pandemic.
headline2: Easter Sunday: Justin Welby calls for 'a better future for all'
summary2:
The Archbishop of Canterbury has called on people to choose ''a better future for all" as society emerges from the Covid-19 pandemic.
Justin Welby was speaking at Canterbury Cathedral, in an Easter Sunday service which featured across BBC TV, radio, and digital platforms for the first time.

headline: 'I want to offer my condolences to the Queen'
summary: Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill offers condolences to the Royal Family and unionists in NI.
headline2: Prince Phillip: Michelle O'Neill offers condolences to Royal Family
summary2:
NI Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill has offered her condolences to the Royal Family and unionists following the Duke of Edinburgh's death.
"When any family loses a loved one it's really difficult and whilst they may be public figures, they are also a family that is hurting," she said.

headline: Prime Minister defends NHS 1% pay rise recommendation
summary: Boris Johnson says that ministers tried to give as much as they could.
headline2: Prime Minister defends NHS 1% pay rise recommendation
summary2:
Speaking on a visit to a vaccination centre in Brent, North London, the Prime Minister said that a 1% pay rise recommended for NHS workers was as much as ministers could give.
Unions and bodies representing health trusts said the government should honour a rise of 2%, suggested back in 2019.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - Kohli run-out sparks late wobble
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day one of the opening Test between Australia and India in Adelaide.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - Kohli run-out sparks late wobble
summary2:
India slip from 188-3 to 206-6
Kohli run out for 74 after mix-up
Rahane runs out Kohli & wastes review
Pujara 43 off 159 balls, Rahane 42
Two wickets for Starc
Kohli & Rahane add 88 for 4th wkt
Opening day of four-Test series
Day/night Test, Adelaide
India captain Kohli's only Test of series

headline: 'After mum died, no-one talked about her for 15 years'
summary: Iain Cunningham always knew his birth had something to do with his mum's death when he was three.
headline2: 'After mum died, no-one talked about her for 15 years'
summary2: Iain Cunningham always believed that his birth had something to do with his mother's death, but whatever it was seemed to be a family secret that couldn't be discussed. It wasn't until Iain was an adult with a family of his own that he uncovered who his mother really was and why she had died.

headline: Noteworthy: Clydesdale Bank's demise
summary: Phasing out the Clydesdale Bank brand will see the firm's banknotes begin to disappear from circulation.
headline2: Noteworthy: Clydesdale Bank's demise
summary2:
Clydesdale Bank is on the way out and although circulation of its banknotes will continue, that will be on a much reduced scale.
It harks back to the origins of paper banknotes, which Scottish bankers innovated, indulging in unscrupulous and sometimes farcical tactics to undermine each other.

headline: Last coal shipment leaves River Tyne
summary: Reflections on the past and questions for the future as the last shipment of coal leaves Tyneside.
headline2: Last coal shipment leaves River Tyne
summary2: What is thought to be the last shipment of coal from the North East of England has left the River Tyne. Extracted in County Durham, the 12,000-tonne load, bound for Belgium, raises questions for those who once worked deep down the pits, and for the next generation looking to a cleaner future.

headline: The 'weird signs' that led Chadwick Boseman to Wakanda
summary: When Marvel's first black male superhero was cast, Boseman revealed there had been "weird signs" that it might happen.
headline2: Black Panther: The 'weird signs' that led Chadwick Boseman to Wakanda
summary2: The man who first told Chadwick Boseman he would play the role of Black Panther - before Boseman even knew the film would be made - was an Australian bodyguard and comic collector, Charles Carter. It was a story Boseman told more than once, though Carter himself has remained silent until now.

headline: The daring nun who hid and saved 83 Jewish children
summary: A convent in southern France secretly gave sanctuary to 83 Jewish children during World War Two.
headline2: The daring nun who hid and saved 83 Jewish children
summary2: Two Jewish girls from north-eastern France found themselves in great danger when Germany invaded 80 years ago. But while their parents and younger sister were caught and murdered, they survived - with dozens of other Jewish children - thanks to the bravery of a nun in a convent near Toulouse.

headline: Myanmar protesters flee from tear gas
summary: Video footage shows anti-coup demonstrators running to avoid tear gas fired by police.
summary2:
Video footage from Myanmar shows anti-coup protesters running as tear gas is fired by police.
There were demonstrations against the military in several cities on Wednesday.
Several deaths have been reported in the clashes, despite Myanmar's neighbours calling on authorities to show restraint.

headline: Listen: India pull off remarkable draw against Australia
summary: India lose only three wickets on the final day as they draw a thrilling third Test against Australia in Sydney.
headline2: Listen: India pull off remarkable draw against Australia
summary2:
India pull off remarkable draw
Four-Test series level at 1-1
Australia take 3 wickets in final day
Pant 97 (118), Pujara 77 (205)
Ashwin 39* (128), Vihari 23* (161)
Ashwin & Vihari survive final session
Paine drops three catches in innings
Third Test, Sydney
Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary

headline: Great British Bunting on homes across nation
summary: People are commemorating the 75th anniversary of VE Day by making and hanging bunting. As part of the BBC's Make a Difference campaign.
headline2: Great British Bunting marks VE Day anniversary
summary2:
People are commemorating the 75th anniversary of VE Day by making and hanging bunting.
Hundreds shared their pictures with local BBC radio stations, from hand-drawn Union Jack flags to sketches of soldiers and aircraft.
The Great British Bunting is part of the BBC's Make a Difference campaign.

headline: Schools in France to close under lockdown
summary: President Emmanuel Macron has announced new national restrictions to fight against rising Covid cases.
headline2: Covid: Macron outlines new national restrictions
summary2:
President Emmanuel Macron has announced new national restrictions to fight against rising Covid cases.
Mr Macron said that schools would move to remote learning from next week.
Lockdown measures, introduced in some areas of France earlier this month, are also being extended to other districts.

headline: Spectacular ‘tree of life’ found in Australian lake
summary: An amateur photographer’s aerial photos are gaining attention for this little known ‘natural wonder’.
summary2:
Amateur photographer Derry Moroney stumbled across massive patterns in Lake Cakora, on Australia's New South Wales north coast, while taking aerial photographs with his drone.
The stunning pictures are now attracting attention online for their "tree of life" resemblance.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: What did George Floyd really say?
summary: Defence counsel claimed Mr Floyd said "I ate too many drugs" during his arrest. What did witnesses hear?
headline2: Derek Chauvin trial: What did George Floyd really say?
summary2:
Derek Chauvin's defence team claimed that Mr Floyd could be heard saying "I ate too many drugs" in bodycam footage of the arrest.
Ultimately, both expert witnesses Sgt Jody Stiger and Special Agent James Reyerson testified that they could not hear the phrase in the clip played during the trial.

headline: Lions frolic in snow after historic blizzard
summary: These cats enjoyed the record snowfall that hit Colorado over the weekend.
headline2: Lions at Denver Zoo frolic in the snow after historic blizzard
summary2:
Colorado was hit by the fourth largest snowstorm in its history over the weekend and lions at the Denver Zoo took advantage by playing in the thick snow.
A tweet from the zoo's official account read: "Lions spend most of their day finding ways to keep cool, so actually our lions love the snow!"

headline: Australia floods as big as 'two European countries'
summary: Some areas are seeing enormous amounts of rain, in what has been called a “once in 200 years event”.
summary2:
A weather system has drenched Australia’s east coast, causing widespread flooding and forcing thousands to evacuate.
Senior risk scientist Thomas Mortlock spoke with the BBC about the scale of the event, and why Australia can see such extremes from one summer to the next.
Video by Isabelle Rodd.

headline: 'I hated my homophobic stepdad, then he came out as trans'
summary: A mail order bride moved to the US with her gay son, but her conservative husband had a surprise in store.
headline2: 'I hated my homophobic stepdad, then he came out as trans'
summary2: As a gay teenager in post-Soviet Russia, Wes Hurley breathed a sigh of relief when his mother married an American and they moved to the US - but he soon discovered his stepfather, James, was violently homophobic. This led to strained relations, until James underwent an unexpected transformation.

headline: How satellite images are helping one country hand out cash
summary: Togo has found a new way to send emergency cash to people struggling in the pandemic.
headline2: How satellite images are helping one country hand out cash
summary2:
Togo has found a high-tech way to identify people who need financial help in the pandemic and send them emergency cash.
They use computers to search for clues in satellite images, then distribute money through mobile phones.
A film for People Fixing the World by Hannah Gelbart and Richard Kenny.

headline: 'We are trapped in the house that killed our son'
summary: Zane Gbangbola was poisoned during flooding at his home. But has the full story of his death been told?
headline2: 'We are trapped in the house that killed our son'
summary2: When Kye Gbangbola and Nicole Lawler moved into their house on the banks of the River Thames in Surrey, it looked like the perfect place to raise a family. Sixteen years later, it stands as a reminder of Zane, the son they lost, while their fight for answers continues over what caused his death.

headline: Covid trials hope inside Great Western Hospital
summary: Helen Langton is an Operating Department Practitioner at the Great Western Hospital, the samples Helen and the team gather could save lives.
headline2: Clinical trials offer new hope for Covid-19 treatment
summary2:
Clinical trials are taking place at the Great Western Hospital with the aim of finding more effective ways to treat patients with coronavirus.
Operating department practitioner Helen Langton explains how her team approaches patients and families to get their consent.
Video journalist: Emma Colman

headline: 'Smart' face masks promise high-tech protection
summary: BBC Click's Lara Lewington puts some "smart" face masks to the test.
headline2: 'Smart' face masks promise high-tech protection
summary2:
Face masks have become an everyday item due to the spread of coronavirus.
But now some brands are exploring ways to add hi-tech features focused on safety and utility.
BBC Click's Lara Lewington tried out some of the more elaborate "smart" masks on offer.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: Brexit: Why is Ireland bypassing Britain?
summary: Irish freight is being shipped directly to Europe to avoid Brexit bureaucracy.
headline2: Brexit: Why Irish freight trade is avoiding Britain
summary2: Two months after Great Britain (GB) left the EU single market and customs union, the volume of freight being shipped across the Irish Sea from the Republic of Ireland to GB is still down significantly, raising further questions about government claims that trading volumes are returning to normal.

headline: Is sexual abuse a problem at psychedelic retreats?
summary: Ayahuasca's psychedelic powers are attracting more and more tourists. But the scene appears to have a dark side.
headline2: 'I was sexually abused by a shaman at an ayahuasca retreat'
summary2: The psychedelic powers of a traditional Amazonian plant medicine called ayahuasca are attracting more and more tourists. It's said to bring spiritual enlightenment and to help with addiction, depression and trauma. But a string of allegations suggests there's a darker side to the ayahuasca scene.

headline: Glastonbury: 'It was girls underneath, boys over the top!'
summary: There was a golden age of breaking into Glastonbury. It's now over but some still manage it.
headline2: Glastonbury fence-jumpers: 'It was girls underneath, boys over the top!'
summary2: For much of the Glastonbury festival's 50-year-long history, paying for a ticket wasn't the only way to get in - if you were prepared to take a few risks, get a bit dirty and run fast in the dark. Adam Bloodworth talks to four gatecrashers about their dramatic experiences with the perimeter fence.

headline: How Covid forced musicians to 'look at life anew'
summary: Music in a pandemic: Guerrilla gigs, song-writing compulsions and learning an Elizabethan guitar.
headline2: Covid-19: What have lockdowns and restrictions meant for musicians?
summary2: Unable to perform up close and in person, the Covid-19 pandemic has been a "difficult" time for musicians. The BBC spoke to those involved in the music scene in Corby, which currently has the highest infection rate in England, about what they have been up to and their plans for post-lockdown life.

headline: Video calls and bookshelves dressed to impress
summary: Video calls have given us all an insight into people's homes – and one firm an unexpected boost.
headline2: Video calls and bookshelves dressed to impress
summary2:
A year ago who'd have imagined people would be spending so much time working from home and online?
Video calls – from TV interviews to work meetings – have given us all an insight into other people's homes.
And, for one company that sells books in Somerset, that's provided a very unexpected boost.

headline: The woman who created Mother's Day - and regretted it
summary: She created Mother's Day out of love for her own mother but was shocked by how it became commercialised.
headline2: Anna Jarvis: The woman who regretted creating Mother's Day
summary2: The woman responsible for the creation of Mother's Day, marked in many countries on the second Sunday in May, would have approved of the modest celebrations likely to take place this year. The commercialisation of the day horrified her - to the extent that she even campaigned to have it rescinded.

headline: When Amazon packages arrive that you didn't order
summary: Zoe Kleinman looks at the sneaky way some sellers are trying to boost their products on Amazon.
summary2:
Have you ever received an Amazon package you did not order?
You have have been the victim of so-called "brushing", whereby unscrupulous online sellers send out goods to people who did not order them, so they can leave themselves glowing reviews.
For some people, it has become a regular occurrence.

headline: 'The mixer that helped my family through hard times'
summary: As Covid leaves thousands struggling, Rebecca Stott recalls how her mum coped with a financial disaster in the 1970s.
headline2: Smash and Angel Delight: 'The mixer that helped my family through hard times'
summary2: An ageing mixer reminds the writer Rebecca Stott of a period of adversity for her family in the 1970s, and the way her mother gritted her teeth and got them through it. Will today's children one day look back at the difficulties of the Covid era, she wonders, and remember someone who did the same?

headline: The pop star doctor who answered the Covid call
summary: Australian singer Gordi is "reaching people" through medical consultations, as well as her music.
headline2: Gordi: The pop star doctor who answered the Covid call
summary2: Singer-songwriter Gordi thinks it's "incredibly selfish" not to wear a face mask during the coronavirus pandemic. As a practising doctor in hospitals around the state of Victoria - the current "epicentre of Covid in Australia" - she's perhaps more qualified than most musicians to talk on the topic.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - second Test, day one
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day one of the second Test between Australia and India in Melbourne.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - second Test, day one
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
India without captain Virat Kohli
Has returned home for birth of first child
Ajinkya Rahane is stand-in captain
Australia still without opener David Warner
Australia lead four-Test series 1-0
Second Test, day one
MCG, Melbourne

headline: 'How do I prove a thing I've tried to hide my whole life?'
summary: More than 1,500 people claim asylum in the UK each year, claiming that they are persecuted for being gay. But it's not an easy thing to prove.
headline2: 'How do I convince the Home Office I'm a lesbian?'
summary2: Angel fled Zimbabwe in fear of her life after police found her in bed with another woman five years ago. It's taken most of the time since then for her to convince the Home Office that she is gay and will be persecuted if she returns. But how do you prove something you spent your life trying to hide?

headline: The most crucial Budget for business in a generation
summary: Business needs government to go on another spending spree, says BBC business editor Simon Jack.
headline2: Budget 2021: The most important Budget for business in a generation
summary2: There has arguably never been a moment in living memory where business and government need each other more than now. Clinging together like the passengers in the front car of a rollercoaster - this Budget is the moment the photo is snapped after the sickening plunge, grimaces fixed for the ride ahead.

headline: Call My Agent star joins plea to reopen theatres
summary: Grégory Montel believes the French government must allow theatres and cinemas to start working again.
headline2: France and Covid: Call My Agent star joins plea to reopen theatres
summary2: Even in France, a protest about the calculation of unemployment benefits could feel a little niche during a pandemic. But it has led to the occupation of 90 theatres across France, and the emergence of new links between social and cultural crusaders who feel short-changed by President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: A black reporter on British TV in the swinging 60s
summary: In 1968 Barbara Blake Hannah got a reporting job with Thames Television, but some viewers strongly objected.
headline2: Barbara Blake Hannah: The first black female reporter on British TV
summary2: When British TV got its first black female reporter in 1968 some viewers strongly objected and she was sacked in less than a year. Now, half a century later, a British Journalism Award has been named in her honour. Looking back, how does Barbara Blake Hannah feel about the way the country treated her?

headline: Oppo smartphone adds 60x microscope camera
summary: A smartphone with a microscope camera has been revealed by Chinese phone-maker Oppo.
headline2: Oppo smartphone adds 60x microscope camera
summary2:
A smartphone with a microscope camera offering 60x magnification has been revealed by Chinese phone-maker Oppo.
BBC Click's Chris Fox went hands-on with the Oppo Find X3 Pro to see what the microscope could capture - and whether it was useful or just a gimmick.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: 'I don't really know the people I star with'
summary: Thirteen-year-old Jordan Nash has shared screen time with Hollywood superstars Will Smith and Angelina Jolie.
headline2: 'I don't really know the people I star with'
summary2:
Most of the time Jordan Nash is like most other 13-year-olds, he likes music and riding on his scooter.
But he also happens to be a rising Hollywood star. Jordan has acted opposite the likes of Will Smith and Angelina Jolie.
BBC News caught up with Jordan during lockdown.
Produced by Sophie van Brugen.

headline: The woman who led a 24-day sit-in that changed US law
summary: Judy Heumann has fought all her life to challenge the stereotypes and misconceptions associated with disability.
headline2: The disabled activist who led a historic 24-day sit-in
summary2: The UK is marking 25 years of the Disability Discrimination Act, while this year is also the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act. But the US law owes much to a group of disabled people who staged a sit-in more than a decade earlier - led by a determined young activist, Judy Heumann.

headline: The brilliant Brazilian loved by both Barca & Madrid
summary: Barcelona's first Brazilian striker left for Real Madrid, managed Iraq with Saddam Hussein's son and beat Pele to a goalscoring record.
headline2: Evaristo de Macedo: The record-breaking Brazilian loved by Barca & Madrid
summary2: The first Brazilian striker to play for Barcelona scored more times than Ronaldo and Romario combined, had a better goals-to-games ratio than Neymar or Rivaldo and got the goal that knocked Real Madrid out of the European Cup for the very first time - before crossing that bitter divide two years later.

headline: 'My search for the boy in a child abuse video'
summary: Lucy Proctor was horrified when she was WhatsApped a sex abuse video. And she wanted to find out if the boy was safe.
headline2: 'My search for the boy in a child abuse video'
summary2: One day, just after I had dropped my son off at school, I was sent a horrific video on WhatsApp. It made me question how images and videos of child sex abuse come to be made, and how they can be openly circulated on social media. And I wanted one answer above all - what happened to the boy in the video?

headline: 'Ambition needed' over NI tree cover
summary: The Woodland Trust is calling for more ambitious targets to be set to bring back Northern Ireland's forests.
headline2: 'Ambition needed' over NI tree cover
summary2:
The Woodland Trust is calling for more ambitious targets to be set to bring back Northern Ireland's forests.
Northern Ireland has the lowest density of woodland in Europe and is well behind the UK average.
Just 8% of land in Northern Ireland is forest, compared with 13% in Great Britain.
Read more here.

headline: Pope celebrates Easter mass under Covid
summary: For the second consecutive year the mass took place behind closed doors.
summary2:
Pope Francis has led his Easter mass in front of a small congregation of around 200 people while thousands of others around the world attended virtually.
It's the second consecutive Easter that the mass and traditional ''Urbi et Orbi'' blessing has taken place behind closed doors because of coronavirus.

headline: AstraZeneca vaccine: Clotting 'possible side-effect'
summary: The benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine "outweigh the risks of side effects", says the EMA's Emer Cooke.
headline2: AstraZeneca vaccine: Clotting 'listed as possible side-effects'
summary2:
The benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine "outweigh the risks of side effects", the European Medicines Agency has said.
Blood clots will be listed as "possible side-effects" said the agency's executive director, Emer Cooke.
But the AstraZeneca vaccine is "highly effective" and is "saving lives", she said.

headline: Could it be Bernie Sanders v Donald Trump?
summary: If Bernie Sanders isn't the Democratic front-runner at this point, the word has little meaning.
headline2: US election 2020: Could it be Bernie Sanders v Donald Trump?
summary2: Bernie Sanders is firmly the front-runner in the race to become the Democratic challenger to Republican President Donald Trump, fresh from a victory this week in the second state-by-state contest. His support is fervent but is his party, let alone the country, ready to embrace such an unusual candidate?

headline: Adopting a child in the age of opioids
summary: At 40, Carrie Brady decided to start a family and open her heart to adopting a child in need.
headline2: Adopting a child in the age of opioids
summary2:
Carrie Brady had no idea the impact that opioids had on birth mothers and their children, but at age 40 she decided to start a family and open her heart to adopting a child in need.
Find out how that decision reshaped her and her family’s life forever.
Produced by Hannah Long-Higgins and Chelsea Bailey.

headline: The myth of the mutiny in space
summary: Did a crew sent to the US Skylab space station go on strike? The last surviving member says it's a myth that won't die.
headline2: Skylab: The myth of the mutiny in space
summary2: It's been almost half a century since the three astronauts on board the Skylab 4 space mission famously fell out with mission control. Soon afterwards, reports began to circulate that they went on strike. But Ed Gibson, the only one of the crew still alive, says the idea that they stopped work is a myth.

headline: Josh O'Connor: Romeo role 'my greatest career experience'
summary: The Crown star's stage role in Romeo and Juliet fizzled out - but was reborn by making a TV film.
headline2: Josh O'Connor: Romeo role 'greatest experience of my career'
summary2: Josh O'Connor and Jessie Buckley were excited about heading up a stage production of Romeo and Juliet. Then when Covid-19 forced the play's cancellation last year the National Theatre had another idea - how about doing it as a film for TV? O'Connor and Buckley almost said no but they're glad they didn't.

headline: Where do statues go when they die?
summary: What is the best thing to do with unwanted statues - and is it an option to leave a divisive statue standing?
headline2: What's the best thing to do with unwanted statues?
summary2: When a country has statues of people that no longer reflect its values, what is the best solution? Is there a way of addressing the past without erasing it? And is doing nothing an option? The BBC's Kavita Puri speaks to four people about possible lessons to be drawn from Iraq, Germany, India and the US.

headline: PSNI news conference on recent Belfast violence
summary: The Police Service of Northern Ireland are holding a news conference following the latest disorder.
headline2: PSNI news conference on recent Belfast violence
summary2:
The PSNI are holding a news conference on the recent violence in Belfast
Seven police officers were injured in violence in west Belfast on Wednesday night
It brings the total number of officers injured recently to 55
Temporary Assistant Chief Constable Jonathan Roberts will address the media at 12:30 BST

headline: Jessie Ware meets her 'lookalike' Gemma Arterton
summary: The pop star called in a favour from her "celebrity lookalike" for her latest music video.
headline2: How Jessie Ware made a video with her 'lookalike' Gemma Arterton
summary2:
Jessie Ware has been mistaken for actress Gemma Arterton many times over the years.
So when the time came to film a video for her latest single, Remember Where You Are, she decided to get the Bafta Award-winner to take her place.
They discussed the making of the video with BBC music reporter, Mark Savage.

headline: 'The foster child who drew himself into our family photo’
summary: George was neglected by his parents, then an adoption went wrong. There was only one family that he felt loved by.
headline2: ‘Our foster child asked us to adopt him – by drawing himself on to a family photo’
summary2: George is one of tens of thousands of children in the UK who've been taken into care because their parents are unable to look after them. Severely neglected, he struggled to express himself, so when there was something very important he wanted to ask his foster family, he chose an unusual way of doing it.

headline: Tiny possum species found alive after bushfires
summary: The world’s smallest possum had not been seen on Kangaroo Island since Australia's fires a year ago.
headline2: Little pygmy possum found on Australian island for first time since fires
summary2:
Bushfires destroyed almost half the bushland on Australia’s Kangaroo Island last summer, devastating animal habitats.
Ecologists feared the island’s population of little pygmy possums – the world’s smallest possum species – had been wiped out, but a new discovery has given them hope.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: ‘I hugged the man who murdered my father’
summary: Candice Mama's father was killed by a man nicknamed "Prime Evil", yet the only way she could find peace was to forgive him.
headline2: ‘I hugged the man who murdered my father’
summary2: When Candice Mama was nine years old, she secretly opened a page in a book she wasn't meant to look at. The picture she saw there revealed something terrible - the dead body of her murdered father. But years later Candice went on to meet and forgive the killer - a man known as "Prime Evil", Eugene de Kock.

headline: Welsh politicians pay tribute to Duke of Edinburgh
summary: Members of the Senedd hold minute's silence to remember Prince Philip, who died aged 99 on Friday.
headline2: Prince Philip: Senedd pays tribute to Duke of Edinburgh
summary2:
Senior Welsh politicians have paid tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh at a recalled meeting of the Senedd.
Members of the Senedd held a minute's silence at the virtual meeting for the duke, who died on Friday at Windsor Castle at the age of 99.
MPs in Westminster also gathered on Monday to remember the duke.

headline: How a Korean family chases the American Dream in Minari
summary: Director Lee Isaac Chung on making the critically-acclaimed film and why he avoided seeing Parasite.
headline2: Minari: Oscar favourite sees Korean family chase the American Dream
summary2: Parasite, last year's Oscar winner from South Korea, dented assumptions that English-speaking audiences are wary of any film with subtitles. Now another Korean-language film is making waves. Minari is a very different story set in rural America. But there's buzz about its chances in April's Academy Awards.

headline: Starmer ‘would not appoint' Abbott to trade role
summary: The Labour leader says he has “real concerns” about former Australian PM being given a role in post-Brexit trade talks for the UK.
headline2: Keir Starmer on Tony Abbott getting UK trade role
summary2:
The Labour leader says he has “real concerns” about the former Australian PM being given a role in post-Brexit trade talks for the UK.
Sir Keir Starmer says: “I don’t think he is the right man for the job.”
There are unconfirmed reports that Mr Abbott is being considered for a UK trade representative role.

headline: 'The year city-dwellers needed my photos of country life'
summary: Farmer and writer James Rebanks explains how the coronavirus pandemic has affected him.
headline2: 'The year city-dwellers needed my photos of country life'
summary2: James Rebanks the farmer and writer has long had a devoted following on social media for the pictures he posts of his land and animals in the Lake District fells, but the photographs have taken on an extra significance for some in this year of coronavirus. Here he explains how the pandemic has affected him.

headline: OneWeb represents 'big commercial opportunity'
summary: Neil Masterson, the new CEO of the OneWeb satellite broadband company, explains why he came onboard.
headline2: OneWeb CEO: Company represents 'big commercial opportunity'
summary2: Neil Masterson was charged with guiding the OneWeb satellite broadband company out of bankruptcy at the end of last year. The CEO believes the re-born mega-constellation operator now has a very bright future. He spoke at length with our science correspondent Jonathan Amos about his plans for the year ahead.

headline: 'Why I quit my job after my home burned down'
summary: After surviving a bushfire that destroyed his house, Jack quit his job to become a climate activist.
headline2: 'Why I quit my job after my home burned down'
summary2:
Jack Egan and his partner Cath Bowdler survived a bushfire which destroyed their home in North Rosedale, NSW, Australia.
For Jack it was a life-changing day – one that prompted him to quit his job and dedicate himself to campaigning for tougher action on climate change.
Produced and edited by Simon Atkinson

headline: 'I trained as a K-pop idol - here's why I quit'
summary: Euodias experienced the highs and lows of a K-pop trainee's life. Why did she leave on the verge of stardom?
headline2: 'I could have been a K-pop idol - but I'm glad I quit'
summary2: Achieving fame as a K-pop star involves years of intensive training, and often some plastic surgery. Euodias is one of the few British hopefuls to have experienced the gruelling life of a K-pop trainee. Here she describes what it was like, and explains why - after being selected for a girl group - she quit.

headline: Why is everyone fighting over the South China Sea?
summary: China claims most of it but surrounding countries and the US disagree. The BBC's Zhaoyin Feng explains why.
headline2: Why is everyone fighting over the South China Sea?
summary2:
The South China Sea is one of the most disputed regions in the world. China claims most of it but surrounding countries and the US disagree.
Tension is building and the area is becoming a regional flashpoint with consequences that could be felt around the world. So why is the South China Sea so contentious?

headline: ‘He wrote to us as he waited for the train to Auschwitz’
summary: Daniele Israel's daily letters to his family from jail in Trieste paint a moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.
headline2: Letters of love: 'Our father wrote every day as he waited to be sent to Auschwitz'
summary2: Arrested by the Nazis for being a Jew, Daniele Israel spent months in jail in Trieste before being deported to Auschwitz. The letters he wrote to his wife as she hid with their two sons only recently came to light, writes Dany Mitzman, and paint a deeply moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.

headline: Autistic boy's lockdown quotes turned into art
headline2: Autistic boy's lockdown quotes turned into art
summary2:
Woody is only eight years old but he has a lot to say about lockdown.
He was diagnosed with autism when he was three and the condition has given him a unique viewpoint on the world.
His dad Sonny is now turning his son's poetic observations into art to raise money for an autism charity.
Video by Gareth Furby.

headline: Antarctic seafloor exposed after 50 years of ice cover
summary: German research vessel Polarstern studies Antarctic seafloor life uncovered by the calving of a big iceberg.
headline2: Antarctic seafloor exposed after 50 years of ice cover
summary2:
When the giant iceberg A74 calved from Antarctica's Brunt Ice Shelf, it exposed seafloor that had been covered over for five decades. The German research vessel Polarstern managed to get between the berg and the ice shelf to image the animals living on the seabed.
Video courtesy of the Alfred Wegener Institute

headline: The rise and fall of the five stages of grief
summary: Elisabeth Kübler-Ross's stages of grief are now rarely taught in a medical setting but live on in management.
headline2: Elisabeth Kübler-Ross: The rise and fall of the five stages of grief
summary2: Denial. Anger. Bargaining. Depression. Acceptance. Everyone knows the theory that when we grieve we go through a number of stages - it turns up everywhere from palliative care units to boardrooms. A viral article told us we'd experience them during the coronavirus pandemic. But do we all grieve in the same way?

headline: The sea intruder causing havoc in Tasmania
summary: Locals hope removing an introduced starfish can help save an iconic Australian species.
summary2:
The Northern Pacific seastar has spread rapidly through the River Derwent in Tasmania, Australia, since it was introduced from Japan in the 1980s.
Tasmanians hope a new effort to remove the species - which has no predator locally - will help save the critically endangered spotted handfish.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: How the net closed on Oxford's grooming gang
summary: How did sex offenders at the centre of Oxford's depraved underworld finally come to face justice?
headline2: How the net closed on Oxford's grooming gang
summary2: Nearly a decade after the abuse of vulnerable girls in Oxford began to be addressed, following years of negligence by police and social services, the last of the so-called Operation Bullfinch trials has ended. How did the sex offenders at the centre of the city's depraved underworld finally come to face justice?

headline: Drone footage follows Shetland 'ice breaker'
summary: An ice breaker has been captured in beautiful drone footage coming in from the sea in Shetland.
headline2: Drone footage follows Shetland 'ice breaker'
summary2:
An "ice breaker" has been captured in beautiful drone footage coming in from the sea in Shetland.
The vessel was creating a channel for another boat to make its way out of the inlet at Voe.
The other boat's hull could have been damaged if it had attempted to leave through the frozen waters.
Footage: Norfilm Ltd.

headline: Exterminate! Dr Who super fan builds own Dalek
summary: Ian McTeague, a Dr Who mega fan, has built his own Dalek from scratch.
headline2: Dr Who super fan builds homemade Dalek
summary2:
A Dr Who super fan has built his very own Dalek.
Ian McTeague, from Weston-super-Mare, spent around 18-months making Draco.
Powered by an electric wheelchair, Draco is used to raise funds for Help for Heroes and Macmillan Cancer Support at conventions up and down the south west.
Video journalist: Jonathan Holmes

headline: Xinjiang cotton: How do I know if it's in my jeans?
summary: It's at the centre of a row between Western brands and China over allegations of forced labour.
headline2: Xinjiang cotton: How do I know if it's in my jeans?
summary2: Xinjiang cotton is some of the best fabric in the world. It's also, human rights campaigners say, produced by forced labour. Some Western brands have removed it from their supply chains, leading to a backlash from Chinese celebrities and netizens. Welcome to the row over cotton from the Xinjiang region of China.

headline: Lockdown easing 'lifts everyone's spirits'
headline2: Covid: Lockdown easing 'lifts everyone's spirits'
summary2:
From haircuts to shopping and a pint in the pub, people in the north west of England are making the most of the easing of lockdown restrictions.
In Chester, one woman told the BBC that being able to socialise "lifts everyone's spirits".
"People are fed up with lockdown and keen to get back to normal," she added.

headline: New bodycam footage of George Floyd's arrest
summary: Several witnesses gave emotional testimony on day three of the trial, and prosecutors released new arrest footage.
headline2: Chauvin trial: New bodycam footage of George Floyd's arrest
summary2:
Several witnesses gave emotional testimony on day three of Derek Chauvin's murder trial, and prosecutors released new arrest footage.
Mr Chauvin was fired as a police officer in Minneapolis after a viral video showed him with his knee on the neck of George Floyd for more than nine minutes. He denies the charges.

headline: The real reason humans are the dominant species
summary: How demand for energy has been central to the development of humanity.
headline2: The real reason humans are the dominant species
summary2: From early humans rubbing sticks together to make fire, to the fossil fuels that drove the industrial revolution, energy has played a central role in our development as a species. But the way we power our societies has also created humanity's biggest challenge. It's one that will take all our ingenuity to solve.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - tourists lose first Test after being skittled for 36
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day three of the opening Test between Australia and India in Adelaide.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - tourists lose first Test after being skittled for 36
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
India bowled out for 36 - their lowest Test total
Lowest total by anyone since 1955
Josh Hazlewood takes 5-8
Australia chasing 90 to win
Day/night Test, Adelaide, day three
First Test of four-match series
Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary

headline: Scientists studying volcano cook sausages on lava
summary: Researchers at the base of Iceland's Mount Fagradalsfjall have been using its lava to heat up snacks.
headline2: Iceland volcano: Scientists studying eruption cook sausages on lava
summary2:
Scientists studying a volcanic eruption in Iceland have been using its lava to cook sausages.
Lava started to burst through a crack in Mount Fagradalsfjall on Friday, in the first eruption of its kind in more than 800 years.
Researchers and spectators have flocked to the area to see the environmental phenomenon.

headline: Supermodel Halima Aden: ‘Why I quit’
summary: The first hijab-wearing supermodel, Halima Aden, tells the BBC why she abandoned the fashion industry.
headline2: Supermodel Halima Aden: ‘Why I quit’
summary2: Halima Aden, the first hijab-wearing supermodel, quit the fashion industry in November saying it was incompatible with her Muslim religion. Here, in an exclusive interview, she tells BBC Global Religion reporter Sodaba Haidare the full story - how she became a model, and how she reached the decision to walk away.

headline: Seaside 'influx' fear over easing travel rules
summary: What do people in Porthcawl think about easing Covid travel restrictions?
headline2: Covid: Seaside 'influx' fears over easing travel rules
summary2:
People in seaside community Porthcawl share their thoughts about the prospect of tourists returning when the Welsh government eases Covid restrictions allowing people to travel further afield.
While some are concerned about an "influx" and social distancing, others say they will bring benefits to local businesses.

headline: Covid hotspot town 'so happy' on reopening day
summary: How is the easing of lockdown going in the area with England's highest Covid-19 case rate?
headline2: Covid lockdown eases: Corby reopening 'couldn't have gone better'
summary2: Over the past two months, Corby in Northamptonshire has consistently had one of the highest Covid-19 case rates in England. At the weekend, mass testing was carried out on residents in an attempt to stop transmission and spot asymptomatic cases. So how do pubs, shops and their customers feel about lockdown easing?

headline: 'My grandfather's hidden wartime photo album'
summary: Peter Goffin's grandfather told stories about the war, but never showed anyone his collection of 300 photos.
headline2: 'My grandfather's hidden wartime photo album'
summary2: Peter Goffin's grandfather told many stories of his war years in the UK with the Canadian Air Force, but only ever showed his family one photograph - of his wedding to a Welsh bride, Peter's grandmother. But after he died, an album was discovered that provided images to accompany the tales the family knew so well.

headline: Blackpool Pleasure Beach to reopen 125 years on
summary: It remained open throughout the two world wars, but was the Covid-19 pandemic forced it to shut.
headline2: Blackpool Pleasure Beach to reopen 125 years on
summary2:
The BBC's Dan Johnson has been testing the rides at Blackpool Pleasure Beach ahead of its re-opening on Monday.
Although it remained open throughout the two world wars, the Covid-19 pandemic forced it to shut.
Monday's reopening will be especially poignant since it marks 125 years since the theme park was founded.

headline: Could Biden's win doom this town?
summary: Built on coal, Colstrip has been under threat for years. It may not matter who sits in the Oval Office.
headline2: A harsh reality in coal country - with or without Trump
summary2: Colstrip, Montana, has been a poster child for the kind of coal mining community that looked to Donald Trump to bring back the industry and save their town. But four years later, on the eve of a Joe Biden presidency, the only thing that's clear is that saving coal - and Colstrip - was never going to be that simple.

headline: Health check: Smartphone app measures vital signs
summary: Lara Lewington looks at technology which can help with remote diagnosis and health monitoring.
headline2: Health check: Measuring vital signs with a smartphone
summary2:
The coronavirus pandemic has seen a rise in innovative health focused technology.
From an app which uses a device’s camera to measure your vital signs to kit which could help doctors with a remote diagnosis, BBC Click’s Lara Lewington looks at some of the latest technology.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: How a boy from Vietnam became a UK cannabis farm slave
summary: Ba was a street child in Ho Chi Minh city. He ended up growing cannabis as a slave in the UK - until he escaped.
headline2: How a boy from Vietnam became a slave on a UK cannabis farm
summary2: It was a horrifying death for the 39 Vietnamese nationals found in the back of a trailer in an industrial park in Essex, in October last year. The story shone a light on the subterranean world of people smuggling and human trafficking, reports Cat McShane, specifically the thriving route between Vietnam and the UK.

headline: Captain Sir Tom Moore laid to rest at family funeral
summary: Captain Sir Tom Moore, who raised millions for the NHS, is laid to rest at a private funeral in Bedford.
headline2: Captain Sir Tom Moore funeral: Family pays tribute to pandemic hero
summary2:
Captain Sir Tom Moore's funeral has taken place in Bedford attended by eight members of his family.
The 100-year-old war veteran raised millions for the NHS walking laps of his garden in lockdown last year.
Relatives expressed "pride" for him in readings at the private ceremony and pledged to keep his legacy alive.

headline: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
summary: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?
headline2: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
summary2: A Reddit post by a woman who explained her mixed emotions at receiving an out-of-the-blue apology from her first boyfriend during lockdown prompted dozens of others to share details of their own experiences. The BBC spoke to a man who has sent two unexpected lockdown apologies - and to a woman who has received one.

headline: How Covid-19 has left Royal fans 'disappointed'
summary: About 5,000 people usually spend their Christmas morning watching the Royal Family arrive at church - but not this year.
headline2: Covid-19: Sandringham Royal Family fans left 'disappointed'
summary2: For the past 32 years the Queen and other members of the Royal Family have spent Christmas at her estate in Sandringham, Norfolk. But this year, because of the coronavirus, the Queen has chosen instead to celebrate "quietly" at Windsor Palace. What will this mean for the Christmas regulars who gather at Sandringham?

headline: 'Luck of the draw': What it's like in hotel quarantine
summary: Travellers share their experiences of isolating in hotels, as the UK announces a similar scheme.
headline2: Covid hotel quarantine: 'It's the luck of the draw'
summary2: UK nationals and residents returning from "red list" countries will be made to quarantine in accommodation such as hotels for 10 days, Boris Johnson has said. While exact details of the policy remain unclear, similar schemes are already in place elsewhere, including in Australia and New Zealand. So how does it work?

headline: 'Bay of Piglets': A 'bizarre' plot to capture a president
summary: How did exiled Venezuelans and former US Special Forces end up joining what looked from the outset like a suicide mission?
headline2: 'Bay of Piglets': A 'bizarre' plot to capture a president
summary2: On Sunday 3 May, the government of Nicolas Maduro announced Venezuela's armed forces had repelled an armed incursion. Operation Gideon was a deeply flawed coup attempt. But what would compel exiled Venezuelans and former US Special Forces soldiers to join a plan that, from the outset, looked like a suicide mission?

headline: What is a recession?
summary: The coronavirus pandemic has thrown many countries into recession - but what exactly is it and how could it affect you?
headline2: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
summary2:
Experts think that many countries, including the UK and the US, are facing one of the worst recessions seen on record because of the coronavirus pandemic.
BBC Business reporter Lora Jones explains what exactly the term means, and what it could mean for you.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Produced by Soraya Auer

headline: Kohli's thrilling knock & Malan back to form - relive decisive India-England T20
summary: Virat Kohli and Bhuvneshwar Kumar inspire India to 36-run win over England in fifth and final T20 in Ahmedabad.
headline2: Kohli's thrilling knock & Malan back to form - relive decisive India-England T20
summary2:
England collapse from 130-1 after 12.4 overs
Buttler & Malan put on 130 for second wicket
Kohli top-scores for India - 80* off 52 balls
India's highest T20 score against England
Jordan snares Suryakumar (32 off 17) one-handed on the boundary, then throws to Roy who completes catch
Rohit hits thrilling 64 off 34 balls

headline: Inside Poland’s 'LGBT-free zones'
summary: Dozens of Polish towns have declared themselves free of "LGBT ideology". It means difficult choices for gay people living in them.
headline2: Inside Poland’s 'LGBT-free zones'
summary2: In Poland, dozens of small towns have declared themselves free of "LGBT ideology". Politicians' hostility to gay rights has become a flashpoint, pitting the religious right against more liberal-minded Poles. And gay people living in these areas are faced with a choice: emigrate, keep their heads down - or fight back.

headline: ‘There’s no such thing as a bad view’
summary: People from around the world are sharing videos of what’s outside their windows.
headline2: WindowSwap: ‘I think we all are explorers in our own ways’
summary2:
The coronavirus pandemic has made travel a distant memory for most of us.
But what if you could virtually escape from the comfort your home?
That’s exactly the idea behind the WindowSwap project, where people from around the world are sharing videos of what’s outside their windows.
Video produced by Sandrine Lungumbu

headline: Cut negatives capture the isolation of lockdown
summary: Photographer Aletheia Casey talks about her series To Dance With Shadows, made during the pandemic.
headline2: Coronavirus: Cut negatives capture the isolation of lockdown
summary2: During the coronavirus crisis, many photographers have been taking socially distant pictures of their neighbours or images of the unusually empty streets where they live. For some though it is not about recording the seen world, it is about creating an image that captures their own experiences of the past few months.

headline: What we all get wrong about the Mayflower
summary: The ship that brought the Pilgrims 400 years ago has been politicised since the founding of the US.
headline2: Mayflower at 400: What we all get wrong about the Pilgrim Fathers
summary2: At a time when America is straining under the weight and contradictions of its history, along comes the 400th anniversary of the Mayflower dropping anchor off these shores. Already this year the country has been forced to confront the baleful legacy of slavery, and the systemic racism that grew from that Original Sin.

headline: 'We tried paying everyone the same salary'
summary: As part of the CEO Secrets series, Calvin Benton discusses his firm Spill's "open" salary policy.
headline2: CEO Secrets: 'We tried paying everyone the same salary. It failed'
summary2: When Calvin Benton started his psychotherapy company Spill, he had the idea of paying everyone the same amount of money. He thought it would bring harmony to the team. Instead, he was forced to abandon the scheme within a year because of the rancour it created and pay people according to their seniority and expertise.

headline: 1,000 lost on one boat - this woman hopes to name them
summary: An Italian pathologist is trying to identify the migrants on a boat that sank in the Mediterranean in 2015.
headline2: 1,000 lost on one boat - this woman hopes to name them
summary2: On 18 April 2015 more than 1,000 refugees and migrants left Libya in an overloaded fishing boat bound for Europe. On a moonless night in the Mediterranean the vessel sank. But those who drowned are not forgotten - for the last five years a team led by an Italian forensic pathologist has been on a mission to name them.

headline: Coronavirus: 24 hours on lockdown
summary: A group of 24 photographers record one hour each of life under restrictions imposed because of coronavirus.
headline2: Coronavirus: 24 hours on lockdown
summary2: Seventeen years ago, a group of 24 photographers set out to document every hour of New Year's Day, every year, for 24 years. But during these unprecedented times, members of the collective have come together again, this time turning their attention and lenses to the Covid-19 pandemic, to document 24 hours on lockdown.

headline: Chadwick Boseman wins and other SAG Awards highlights
summary: Taylor Simone Ledward accepted her late husband's Screen Actors Guild Award for best actor.
headline2: Chadwick Boseman wins and other SAG Awards highlights
summary2:
For the first time at the Screen Actors Guild Awards, actors from ethnic minorities won in all four individual film categories.
Taylor Simone Ledward accepted her late husband Chadwick Boseman's award for best actor in the 1920s drama Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.
Read more: Boseman triumphs in diverse night for SAG awards

headline: A super-spreading funeral that led to three deaths
summary: Before the lockdown, many mourners at a funeral in Bradford became infected with Covid-19, and three died.
headline2: Coronavirus doctor's diary: A super-spreading funeral that led to three deaths
summary2: In March, before the lockdown began, the Hussain family held a big funeral in Bradford's Grand Mosque. Tragically, many mourners fell ill with Covid-19, including the dead man's son, Mohammed. But while three family members died, Mohammed eventually pulled through, writes Dr John Wright of the Bradford Royal Infirmary.

headline: The roofer who groomed children over Facebook
summary: David Wilson's sex offences were flagged up by a Facebook algorithm before he was caught by police.
headline2: David Wilson: The King's Lynn roofer who lured sex victims by posing as a girl
summary2: They were lured in by messages seemingly from a teenage girl. From there, the young victims were not only enticed into sharing sexualised images of themselves but in some cases blackmailed to commit abuse by proxy on their younger siblings. How was David Wilson - the man behind the teenage girl mask - eventually caught?

headline: What do Australians think of Facebook's news ban?
summary: The social media giant's decision to block news in Australia has prompted anger and confusion.
headline2: Facebook: What do Australians think of the tech giant's news ban?
summary2:
Facebook users within Australia will no longer be able to view or share news content on the platform.
The decision was made by the social media company in retaliation to a proposed law which would make tech firms pay for news content.
The BBC asked Australians what it's like to see news suddenly vanish from their feeds.

headline: 'I was told to shoot protesters - I refused'
summary: Police officers from Myanmar tell the BBC they defected to India after refusing to carry out orders.
headline2: Myanmar coup: 'We were told to shoot protesters', say police who fled
summary2: Police officers from Myanmar have told the BBC they fled across the border into India after refusing to carry out the orders of the military which seized power in a coup last month. In some of the first such interviews, more than a dozen defectors told us they escaped, fearing they'd be forced to kill or harm civilians.

headline: Ahem! No chair for von der Leyen
summary: The European Commission president had to sit on a nearby sofa as the EU visited Turkey.
headline2: Ursula von der Leyen left without chair during EU visit to Turkey
summary2:
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen was left without a seat, and had to sit on a nearby sofa, as the bloc's leaders met with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Only two chairs were set up for the meeting, which involved Ursula von der Leyen, President Erdogan, and EU Council President Charles Michel.

headline: The country governed by women in their 30s
summary: Nearly a year into her job, Finnish PM Sanna Marin says it's 'everyone's job to identify themselves'.
headline2: Sanna Marin: The feminist PM leading a coalition of women
summary2: A year will soon have passed since Finland's new coalition government headed by five women started work. It has dealt efficiently with the coronavirus pandemic, while drafting an ambitious Equality Programme - a programme that states, among other things, that everyone has the right to determine their own gender identity.

headline: 'This is Paine's Australia Test team now'
summary: As Australia prepare for their Boxing Day Test against India, we look at how Tim Paine has grown into an undisputed leader of their Test team.
headline2: Australia v India: Heading into the Boxing Day Test, this is Paine's Australia now
summary2: As Tim Paine walked off the field on the first day at Headingley in 2019, the tension was clear. England's players had huddled to await an umpire's review that saw Paine lbw to Chris Woakes for 11. He looked back to the huddle and several players turned their heads, their words following the departing Australian captain.

headline: The Russians who came with a warning Britain wouldn't hear
summary: Dynamo Moscow's 1945 tour saw the Russians impress against supposedly superior British sides, at a time of growing suspicion.
headline2: Dynamo Moscow's 1945 tour of Britain: Was it really 'war minus the shooting?'
summary2: It was a Tuesday afternoon in November 1945 and the streets of Fulham were teeming. Tens of thousands of people were about to witness something most hadn't been able to since 1939, while for some it would be a lifetime first. They were on their way to attend a football match where a British team faced foreign opposition.

headline: 'Alien' barnacles washed up
headline2: 'Alien' barnacles washed up on Isles of Scilly
summary2:
Thousands of goose barnacles have washed up on the Isles of Scilly attached to a piece of driftwood.
Photographer and wildlife expert Lucy McRobert, who lives on St Mary's, was tipped off by a friend about a long length of wood on the beach at St Mary's Harbour.
The wood was encrusted with "thousands of goose barnacles."

headline: What's behind 'baffling' AstraZeneca concerns?
summary: The vaccine has been put on hold in some countries, but not taking it leaves people at risk of Covid-19.
headline2: Covid-19: Why some countries paused AstraZeneca vaccines
summary2:
Use of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine has been paused in 11 European countries after a small number of blood clots were reported among people who had recently had the jab.
But one senior global health researcher called the response "baffling", given there is no evidence to suggest it is unsafe to use.
Ros Atkins explains.

headline: The blogger who hit back at a Russian 'assassin'
summary: Tumso Abdurakhmanov says Russia's security service must have helped Chechens plan an attempt to assassinate him.
headline2: The blogger who hit back against a hammer-wielding Russian ‘assassin’
summary2: Sergei Skripal was poisoned with the nerve agent Novichok, Alexander Litvinenko was killed with radioactive polonium… by contrast the man who attacked Chechen blogger Tumso Abdurakhmanov was armed with nothing more than a hammer. But he is still convinced that Russian security services were involved, reports Nick Sturdee.

headline: Russians cheer as they exit North Korea on hand-pushed trolley
summary: The diplomats had no choice as Pyongyang has banned trains from leaving as part of Covid measures.
headline2: Russians cheer as they exit North Korea on hand-pushed trolley
summary2:
A group of Russian diplomats and their families made an unusual exit out of North Korea on a hand-pushed rail trolley due to strict Covid measures.
A clip released by the Russian Foreign Ministry showed them cheering as they crossed a railway bridge into Russia.
Read more: Russians leave North Korea on hand-pushed trolley

headline: England crash to innings defeat as India reach WTC final - reaction & analysis
summary: India will play New Zealand in the World Test Championship final after beating England by an innings and 25 runs in fourth Test.
headline2: England crash to innings defeat as India reach WTC final - reaction & analysis
summary2:
England collapse to 135 all out - all 10 wickets fall to spin
Lawrence hits second Test century to hold up India
England have now gone 74 partnerships without a 50-run stand
India bowled out for 365 - a lead of 160
Sundar left stranded on 96 not out
Victory puts India into World Test Championship final against New Zealand

headline: 'What happens if there is another earthquake?'
summary: New Zealanders are still on edge after three tremors trigger tsunami warnings and evacuations.
headline2: New Zealand earthquakes: 'What happens if there is another one?'
summary2:
Whakatane resident Tara saw people flock to high ground near her home when tsunami warnings were issued following three earthquakes off the coast of New Zealand.
The six hour ordeal made her realise how she, and many others, were not prepared for what unfolded.
Read more: Tsunami alert lifted after quakes rock New Zealand

headline: 'I turned my office into a cafe for cyclists'
summary: Three stories of people working in hospitality who have set up new businesses during Covid-19.
headline2: Covid brainwave: 'I turned my office into a cyclists' cafe'
summary2: As part of our CEO Secrets series, which invites business leaders to share their advice, we are focusing on start-ups that have launched during lockdown, looking at different types of entrepreneur. This week, we hear from people whose jobs are under threat in hospitality, a sector hit particularly hard during the pandemic.

headline: From Manchester to Nollywood filmmaking
headline2: Nollywood: Former Manchester schoolboy directs Nigerian film
summary2:
A former Manchester schoolboy has directed his first film in Nigeria's Nollywood.
Mathew Alajogun made The Cleanser, which involves corrupt politicians being assassinated, in the city of Ibadan.
Popularly known as Nollywood, Nigeria's film industry is the world's second largest producer of movies behind Bollywood in India.

headline: Capturing outback storms after years of drought
summary: Australian photographer Jacob Vlatko welcomes new life to harsh outback landscapes.
headline2: Australia drought: Capturing spectacular storms in the outback
summary2:
The town of Broken Hill in outback Australia has endured an intense drought since 2017, but it is finally seeing some longed-for rain.
Spectacular images of recent thunderstorms have been captured by local photographer Jacob Vlatko.
He tells the BBC how, after so long, it's been "amazing" to witness.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: The photographer bringing his community together
summary: Misan Harriman normally photographs celebrities and events but now he’s turned to capturing his local community.
summary2:
Misan Harriman is used to photographing celebrities like Rihanna and Stormzy.
But now due to the lockdown he is taking photos of his local community in Woking.
The "Lost in Isolation" project hopes to bring the community together.
Mr Harriman said: "Finding beauty in the simple moments in life has been a great gift to me."

headline: Former PM on William and Harry rift
summary: The former prime minister, Sir John Major, says Prince Philip's funeral is an ideal time to end friction between the royals.
headline2: Major: I hope it's possible to mend any rifts
summary2:
The former prime minister, Sir John Major, says Prince Philip's funeral is an ideal time to end friction between members of the Royal Family.
He told the BBC's Andrew Marr that he hoped any rifts could be mended.
Sir John was appointed as guardian to Princes William and Harry after the death of their mother, Diana, in 1997.

headline: Relive Pant's incredible innings - how day two unfolded as India take 89-run lead
summary: Rishabh Pant dismissed for 101, but India in charge of fourth Test against England on day two in Ahmedabad.
headline2: Relive Pant's incredible innings - how day two unfolded as India take 89-run lead
summary2:
Pant hammers 115-ball century - brings up hundred with a six
Pant and Sundar frustrate England after India fall to 146-6
