Disciplined England bowlers dominate before Pant & Sundar stand
Pacemen Anderson & Stokes miserly in long spells
Three wickets for Anderson, two for Leach & Stokes
Struggles continue for Bess - 0-56 off 15

headline: 'I faced miscarriage alone - my partner had to wait in the car park'
summary: Lockdown rules mean pregnant women must have scans alone - but what if there's bad news?
headline2: 'I faced miscarriage alone - my partner had to wait in the car park'
summary2: Pregnant women are often now attending hospital appointments on their own. Covid-19 safety measures in hospitals mean loved ones must sit in the car or pace outside. It means some are being given the heartbreaking news of miscarriages on their own. Four women tell their stories of miscarriage during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: In pictures: Sophie Raworth's deserted London
summary: BBC presenter's photographs of deserted streets as she runs to work in central London.
headline2: Coronavirus: Sophie Raworth's deserted London
summary2: For the past two weeks, since the lockdown restrictions began, BBC news presenter Sophie Raworth has been running to work at lunchtime to present the BBC News at Six and Ten, taking pictures as she passes some well-known landmarks. Here she describes what it is like to commute through the now deserted streets of the capital.

headline: Welsh NHS workers 'deserve pay rise'
summary: Ministers will not try to cap any pay rise for Welsh NHS staff in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, says Vaughan Gething
headline2: Covid: Welsh NHS workers 'deserve pay rise' says health minister
summary2:
Ministers will not try to cap any pay rise for Welsh NHS staff in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, Health Minister Vaughan Gething has said.
The UK government has faced a backlash after saying a pay rise for staff in England should be capped at 1%.
Mr Gething said on Friday that Welsh NHS workers "deserved a pay rise".

headline: Oscars nominations 'really exciting this year'
summary: Film critic Clarisse Loughrey shares her thoughts on this year’s Oscar nominations.
headline2: Oscars: 'The nominations this year are really exciting'
summary2:
The 2021 Oscar nominations have been announced. The film Mank, about life in the golden
era of Hollywood, comes out on top with ten nominations.
Eight British actors are in the nominee line up, including Riz Ahmed, Daniel Kaluuya andCarey Mulligan.
Film critic Clarisse Loughrey shared her thoughts on this year’s nominations.

headline: In pictures: The football fans without a team
summary: When Bury FC was expelled from the English Football League, supporters were left with a hole in their lives.
headline2: Bury FC: The football fans without a team
summary2: When Bury FC was expelled from the English Football League in August 2019, its supporters were left with no team to follow and a hole in their Saturday afternoons. Many have found it too painful to watch any football since. But they hope the club can somehow be revived. Photographer Madeleine Penfold has been following them.

headline: Oscars 2020: How diverse are the Oscars?
summary: No women were nominated in the best director category for this year's Oscars.
headline2: Oscars 2020: How diverse are the Oscars?
summary2: The South Korean film Parasite has made Oscar history by becoming the the first non-English language film to win best picture. Bong Joon-Ho also won best director for the film but its overall success - it won four awards - hasn't silenced the critics who have highlighted the lack of diversity in this year's Oscar categories.

headline: Thick ash clouds the sky as Etna erupts
summary: No towns are thought to be at risk from Mount Etna, one of the world's most active volcanoes.
headline2: Mount Etna: Ash clouds as Sicilian volcano erupts
summary2:
Mount Etna has erupted, sending hot lava and ash clouds into the sky.
Located on the Italian island of Sicily, Etna is considered one of the world’s most active volcanoes.
Catania International Airport was temporarily closed because of Tuesday's eruption, but local authorities have told residents of nearby towns not to worry.

headline: Woman 'thrilled' to be first to get Moderna jab
summary: Unpaid carer Elle Taylor, 24, from Ammanford, received the jab at Glangwili Hospital in Carmarthen.
headline2: Covid: UK's first Moderna vaccine recipient 'thrilled'
summary2:
A woman who was the first person in the UK to have the Moderna Covid vaccine has said she was "thrilled" to receive it.
Unpaid carer Elle Taylor, 24, from Ammanford, had the jab at Glangwili Hospital in Carmarthen.
The UK is committed to buying 17 million doses of Moderna, the third of seven vaccines it has put in orders for.

headline: The poet, the queen and 120-year-old chocolate
summary: Australian historians find remarkably well-preserved chocolate, giving a fascinating glimpse into history.
headline2: Banjo Paterson: 120-year-old chocolate found in Australian poet's belongings
summary2:
When the National Library of Australia recently acquired famous poet Banjo Paterson's personal belongings, the last thing they expected to find was chocolate.
With links to Queen Victoria, the discovery from 1900 is "one of the best preserved chocolates of this age anywhere", a historian tells the BBC.
Video by Isabelle Rodd.

headline: 'We switched to virtual wine tastings during lockdown'
summary: Kirby Bryant's wine and spirits shop closed during lockdown, but she took the business in a new direction online to survive - and thrive.
headline2: 'We switched to virtual wine tastings during lockdown'
summary2:
Kirby Bryant's wine and spirits shop in Hertfordshire closed during lockdown, but she took the business in a new direction online to survive - and thrive.
This is the latest video in a special edition of our CEO Secrets series, looking at businesses started during the coronavirus pandemic.
Video by series producer Dougal Shaw

headline: 'I was forced to work in a North Korean coal mine'
summary: A former South Korean prisoner describes her time working in a North Korean coal mine.
headline2: North Korea: Forced to work in a coal mine for 28 years
summary2:
Generations of South Korean prisoners of war are being used as slave labour in North Korean coal mines to generate money for the regime, according to a report released by a human rights organisation.
Former prisoner Kim Hye Soon, whose grandfather fought for the South, tells the BBC's Laura Bicker what the experience was like.

headline: Why jellyfish could be a 'perfect food'
summary: Amid fresh concern about overfishing, scientists say jellyfish could give us multiple benefits.
headline2: Eating jellyfish: Why scientists are talking up a 'perfect food'
summary2:
Australian researchers recently found that over 90 species of endangered fish are caught legally by industrial fisheries globally.
In the wake of the study, scientists have again suggested eating more jellyfish as a sustainable option.
Why? Marine biologist Lisa-ann Gershwin says there are a few reasons.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Icelandic volcano erupts near Reykjavik
summary: Aerial footage shows lava snaking its way down after the eruption.
headline2: Icelandic volcano erupts near Reykjavik
summary2:
A volcano has erupted south-west of Iceland's capital Reykjavik, the country's meteorological office says.
It says the fissure is about 500-700 metres long (1,640-2,300ft) at Fagradalsfjall on Reykjanes peninsula. The last eruption there was some 800 years ago.
Aerial footage shows lava snaking its way down after the eruption.

headline: Five countries, five winter lockdowns: Tips on coping
summary: Tips on lockdown life in cold weather, from keeping your windows open to watching films in the bath.
headline2: Covid: How to cope in a winter lockdown, from those who've done it
summary2: It's hard to stay positive during lockdown, particularly in the winter months. You might be feeling just as frosty, gloomy and miserable as the UK's weather forecasts. But last year, millions of people across the world experienced coronavirus lockdowns in snowy and sometimes sub-zero conditions - so what can we learn from them?

headline: Keeping score on UK-EU relations since Brexit
summary: Despite promises to work together, it has been far from plain sailing between the UK and the EU since Brexit.
headline2: Keeping score on UK-EU relations since Brexit
summary2:
The relationship between the UK and the EU since the Brexit transition period ended has been marked by point-scoring over issues like Northern Ireland and vaccine exports. But are we seeing signs that things might improve?
Chief Political Correspondent Adam Fleming gives us the score so far.
Videos produced by Larissa Kennelly.

headline: 'I've gone from being a photographer to being a farmer'
summary: As coronavirus hit, photographer Anna Jackson returned to help her family on their Lincolnshire farm.
headline2: My Money: 'I've gone from being a photographer to a farmer'
summary2: My Money is a series looking at how people spend their money - and the sometimes tough decisions they have to make. Here Anna Jackson, 27, takes us through a week in the life of her family's farm in Bottesford near Scunthorpe, where she has returned after the coronavirus outbreak brought her freelance photography work to a halt.

headline: First minister defends alcohol ban in pubs
headline2: Covid: Alcohol ban for Welsh pubs and restaurants from Friday
summary2:
A ban on alcohol will begin in Welsh pubs, bars and restaurants on Friday.
As part of new measures announced by the first minister on Monday, hospitality venues will also be unable to open to customers beyond 18:00 GMT.
Mark Drakeford said without changes there could be between 1,000 and 1,700 preventable deaths over the winter.

headline: Myanmar protester: I am scared but we must fight
summary: Hannah says she is scared but the protests must continue until democracy is restored.
headline2: Myanmar protester: I am scared but we still have to fight for freedom
summary2:
Protests, in Myanmar, also known as Burma, must continue until there is democracy and freedom, Hannah says.
She told BBC World News many of the protesters were aged just 17 or 18.
"I am scared," she said.
"But we still have to fight for the democracy we want.
"Me and my fellow protesters will fight until we get our leaders back."

headline: Government on steel rescue standby again
summary: A closer look at the 'murky' relationship between the steel industry. finance and politics.
headline2: Gupta and Greensill prompt steel jobs crisis
summary2: The crisis engulfing the UK's third largest steel maker, its financier, and the government now tasked with saving thousands of jobs, is a complex tapestry of strands, none of which are in themselves particularly shocking, but woven together make up a very murky picture of the relationship between industry, finance and government.

headline: 'One of the worst human rights crisis of our time'
summary: The international community "simply cannot look the other way" on the abuse of human rights to Uighur Muslims in Chinas, says the UK foreign secretary.
headline2: Raab on China's treatment of Uighur Muslims in camps
summary2:
The international community "simply cannot look the other way" on the abuse of human rights to Uighur Muslims in China, the UK foreign secretary has told MPs.
Describing a “highly disturbing programme of repression”, he announced British sanctions on Chinese government officials, as the US, Canada and EU imposed similar measures.

headline: 'Misdiagnosed back pain means I can never dance again'
summary: Singer Talia Dean was 18 when she first had symptoms of axial spondyloarthritis. It took 15 years to get a diagnosis.
headline2: Talia Dean: 'My back pain was misdiagnosed for 15 years - now I can't dance'
summary2: When singer-songwriter Talia Dean was 18 years old, she started experiencing the symptoms of a condition called axial spondyloarthritis - or axial SpA. But the condition has a tendency to be overlooked in women and it took more than 15 years for her to get a diagnosis. By this time, irreversible damage had been done to her spine.

headline: Blinken opens China talks with critical comments
summary: Antony Blinken used his opening remarks to say the US would "discuss our deep concerns with actions by China".
headline2: US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken opens China talks with rebuke
summary2:
High-level talks between the US and China have begun with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken saying the US would "discuss our deep concerns with actions by China".
In response, China's senior foreign policy official, Yang Jiechi, accused Washington of using its military might and financial supremacy to suppress other countries.

headline: The bilbies 'thriving' after a 100-year absence
summary: The marsupial has bred in the wild in New South Wales for the first time in a century.
headline2: The bilbies 'thriving' after a 100-year absence in New South Wales
summary2:
Populations of the Australian bilby have been devastated over the past 200 years after being hunted by cats and foxes.
Now a conservation programme has helped the species to breed in the wild in New South Wales for the first time in more than a century.
Ecologists say it gives hope to the threatened species.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: 'We commute 1,800km to run an outback pub’
summary: The Ellis family in Australia make frequent trips on a small plane, fulfilling what they call "a dream".
headline2: The Australian family that travels 1,800km to run an outback pub
summary2:
Talia Ellis and her family live on a farm in New South Wales, Australia. So they are perhaps not the most likely owners of a pub 1,800km (1,200 miles) away in outback Queensland.
But luckily for them, Ms Ellis is an experienced small plane pilot.
She tells the BBC how it's helped the family fulfil "a dream".
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: ‘I am the last shepherd in my family’
summary: Phuntsog Tsering lives a tough life, herding yaks at 5,000m. He's among just a few carrying on an ancient way of life.
headline2: A yak herder in the Himalayas: ‘I am the last shepherd in my family’
summary2:
Phuntsog Tsering lives a tough life, herding yaks at 5,000m in the Himalayas.
Not much has changed since his ancestors used to walk the Silk Road in Ladakh in India.
Young people seek an easier life and he’s now just one of a handful of shepherds left in the village.
Filming by Faisal H Bhat, Editing and Reporting by Aamir Peerzada

headline: Coronavirus: Rainbow portraits thank the NHS
summary: Photographer Tom Skipp's pictures of the many rainbows supporting the NHS across the city of Bristol.
headline2: Coronavirus: Rainbow portraits thank the NHS
summary2: When the country began social distancing and then lockdown, photographer Tom Skipp was due to visit his mother, who lives in a care home about four hours' drive from him, for Mother's Day. No longer able to travel, instead of making the trip on that Sunday, he photographed the many rainbows that had sprung up in and around Bristol.

headline: Myanmar's deadliest day since its coup
summary: Security forces opened fire on protesters as military leaders marked the country's Armed Forces Day.
headline2: Myanmar's deadliest day since its coup
summary2:
Myanmar has experienced the deadliest day since its military coup, with security forces opening fire on protesters while during the country's Armed Forces Day.
More than 90 people were killed on Saturday after demonstrators took to the streets of Yangon and other cities.
Read more: Generals celebrated amid global fury over massacre

headline: Why Australian women are saying 'enough is enough'
summary: Australian politics is often called toxic to women - now rape allegations have ignited national fury.
headline2: Why Australian women are saying 'enough is enough'
summary2:
Australia's political scene has frequently been called toxic to women, with a culture beset by accusations of misogyny and sexist intimidation.
The BBC's Shaimaa Khalil explains how allegations of rape have now lit the fuse on a wider conversation.
Could it be a turning point?
Video produced by Simon Atkinson. Filming by Dan Soekov.

headline: India sweep to two-day Test win over England - reaction & analysis
summary: India beat England by 10 wickets in an incredible third Test in Ahmedabad that finishes well inside two days.
headline2: India sweep to two-day Test win over England - reaction & analysis
summary2:
India win inside two days
Hosts chase 49 for victory
India lead 2-1 in four-match series
Shortest Test since 1935
England bowled out for 81
Axar 5-32 - 11-70 in match
Ashwin 4-48 - passes 400 Test wickets
28 of 30 wickets fall to spin
India fall from 114-3 to 145 all out
Root 5-8, Leach 4-54; Rohit 66
Day-night third Test, Ahmedabad

headline: Texas blanketed by snow
summary: Texas blanketed by snow
summary2:
A severe winter storm has swept throughout Texas bringing snow, ice, and dangerously low temperatures.
A state of emergency is declared in the US where a surge in demand for electricity has led to massive power cuts.
The federal authorities say more than 150 million Americans are now under winter storm warnings in a number of states.

headline: The islands that halted an outbreak by locking down early
summary: Shetland was one of the UK areas worst hit by Covid-19 - now there have been no new cases for six weeks. How did they do it?
headline2: A cluster of islands: How Shetland locked down early and stopped the virus in its tracks
summary2: Early in the Covid-19 outbreak, the Shetland Islands were one of the worst-hit areas of the UK by head of population. Now, no new cases have been detected there for six weeks. Some experts say it offers the rest of the country a route map out of lockdown - but for the first family on the islands to test positive, it hasn't been easy.

headline: Erupting again: Living beneath Etna
summary: Three weeks of spectacular blasts have amazed onlookers - but caused untold damage for Sicilians.
headline2: Etna: Life beneath the volcanic dust of repeated eruptions
summary2: Irene Corsaro will never forget her first driving lesson under a rain of black ash from Mount Etna. Like many Sicilians from Catania, the 18-year-old has learnt quickly how to make her way home on a road covered in volcanic dust during one of the volcano's 11 eruptions in the past three weeks. A 12th eruption was under way on Friday.

headline: Lockdown: 'I cycled every street in my 5km radius'
summary: Ben Loke cycled 1,371km whilst under Melbourne's tough restrictions.
headline2: Melbourne lockdown: Cycling trend ‘burbing’ takes off under tight restrictions
summary2:
The Australian city of Melbourne has faced one of the world's longest and harshest lockdowns.
Tight restrictions included a 5km (3 mile) travel limit, sparking the trend "burbing": to cycle every road in a suburb.
Resident Ben Loke decided to take this trend even further and ride every street in his 5km radius.
Video by Isabelle Rodd.

headline: Melbourne cheers end of Australia's strictest lockdown
summary: After months of restrictions, Melbourne's bars, restaurants and shops are finally open again.
summary2:
Melbourne was at the heart of Australia's second wave of the coronavirus pandemic, and went into a second lockdown for nearly four months - the strictest the country had seen.
On Wednesday, the city eased restrictions and people were able to go to bars, restaurants and shops again for the first time in months.
Video by Andreas Illmer.

headline: Fibromyalgia: 'How cooking gave me my family back'
summary: Ian loved cooking, but after being diagnosed with fibromyalgia he had to think of new way to get into the kitchen.
headline2: Fibromyalgia and pain: 'How cooking gave me my family back'
summary2: When you flick through a recipe book, there are often brightly coloured photos of food, with texture and zing bursting off the pages. The pictures are designed to make you think, "I want to eat that", but what if those photos do the exact opposite? That was the challenge Ian Taverner faced when he was diagnosed with a chronic illness.

headline: 'We couldn’t afford IVF so we found a sperm donor online'
summary: The high cost of fertility treatment leads some to find donors on social media, even though it's risky and could be illegal.
headline2: 'We couldn’t afford fertility treatment so we risked finding a sperm donor on Facebook'
summary2: If people are unable to get fertility treatment on the NHS they sometimes use unregulated Facebook groups to find men willing to sell or donate their sperm. The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority says this carries significant risks - and it could also be illegal - but two women told the BBC they felt that they had no choice.

headline: 'A massive honour to be competing at Tokyo 2020’
summary: Marathon runner Stephanie Davis says she is grateful the postponed Games are going ahead.
headline2: 'It’s a massive honour to be competing at Tokyo 2020’
summary2:
It is 100 days before the 2021 Olympics begins in Tokyo and athletes all over the world are back in training.
Marathon runner Stephanie Davis, who will be competing in the Games for the first time, told BBC World News that she was really grateful that the Olympics was going ahead after it was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Revenge of the secretaries: The real story behind 9 to 5
summary: The 1980 hit comedy 9 to 5 was inspired by a real protest movement, which is profiled in a new documentary.
headline2: Revenge of the secretaries: The protest movement that inspired the film 9 to 5
summary2: The hit comedy 9 to 5, in the US the second-highest grossing film of 1980, saw three female office workers kidnapping their lecherous boss and starting a workplace revolution. But not everyone knows that the film, starring Jane Fonda, Dolly Parton and Lily Tomlin, was inspired by a real-life movement to empower women in the workplace.

headline: Bringing warmth to the needy in freezing weather
headline2: Plymouth team brings warmth to needy in freezing weather
summary2:
A team of volunteers is on hand seven nights a week in Plymouth to provide food for those in need.
Hilary Knight is the coordinator of Plymouth's Soup Run, working with the city's Shekinah Mission, which provides services for homeless people and the underprivileged.
She recorded a video diary of a typical weekend for her and her team.

headline: Police raid home of vaccine text fraudster
summary: More than 6,000 cases of Covid-related fraud and cyber-crime have been recorded by the UK's police forces during the pandemic.
headline2: Police raid home of vaccine text fraudster
summary2:
More than 6,000 cases of Covid-related fraud and cyber-crime have been recorded by the UK's police forces during the pandemic.
The Action Fraud team said £34.5m had been stolen in England, Wales and Northern Ireland since 1 March 2020.
Teige Gallagher, 21, has pleaded guilty to two charges relating to fraud and is awaiting sentencing.

headline: 'I knew my mum was a drinker but we never talked about it'
summary: Becky Ellis Hamilton's mum had an alcohol problem but no-one talked about it - and this had tragic consequences.
headline2: 'My mum was an alcoholic and it was a massive secret'
summary2: Growing up with a parent who has a drinking problem can profoundly affect children in many ways. Children of alcoholics are more likely to suffer from depression, struggle in school, and experience abuse and violence at home. Many find that they are still deeply affected by their parent's drinking as adults - like Becky Ellis Hamilton.

headline: Leicester Comedy Festival goes online
summary: Fans can watch more than 100 comedians from the comfort of their own homes - or even hot tubs.
headline2: Leicester Comedy Festival goes online in lockdown
summary2:
The Leicester Comedy Festival has been running for nearly 30 years, but this year it's going online.
Fans can watch more than 100 comedians from the comfort of their own homes - or even hot tubs - on the video-on-demand service, NextUp Comedy.
The BBC's arts editor Will Gompertz joined them to see if this could be the future of comedy.

headline: Prince Albert II: Marine ecosystems need our help
summary: An unhealthy ocean threatens human life and our existence on the planet, the prince says.
headline2: Prince Albert II: Why marine ecosystems need our help
summary2:
Monaco Ocean Week, which showcases the latest projects, initiatives and activism for the protection of global marine ecosystems, has been running as a virtual event this week.
One of the organisers of the event, Prince Albert II of Monaco, told BBC World News his interest in marine conservation dated back to his great-great-grandfather.

headline: 'Dive through the window of opportunity'
summary: Technology boss Steve Killelea says entrepreneurs must act fast when a business opportunity arises.
headline2: 'Dive through the window of opportunity'
summary2:
Technology boss Steve Killelea says entrepreneurs must act fast when a business opportunity arises. Mr Killelea, the founder of Australian IT firm Integrated Research, says that they also need to be able to adapt and change.
He was interviewed for a new mini-series called Paths to Success.
Filmed by Matt Leiper. Edited by Robert Miller.

headline: Grandad's Covid sea shanty video goes viral
headline2: Covid sea shanty video goes viral for Isle of Wight grandad
summary2:
A singer has become an unlikely internet star at the age of 82 with his recording of a sea shanty aimed at encouraging people to have the coronavirus vaccine.
Martyn Waitt, from the Isle of Wight, wrote and recorded a version of The Wellerman with his granddaughter and posted it on TikTok where it has been viewed more than 450,000 times.

headline: 'Raw and inspiring': Tales of pandemic motherhood
summary: A project brings together the experiences of 277 mums who all gave birth in 2020.
headline2: Born in Lockdown: Mothers' stories of giving birth in 2020
summary2: It is a book with 277 authors but with one shared experience - becoming a new mother in 2020. The mothers speak about their isolation, uncertainty and the pressure placed on their mental health by the pandemic, but some say they were also able to find "silver linings" and positives that have come out of an extraordinary joint experience.

headline: How Wikipedia focuses on accuracy
summary: BBC Click's Lara Lewington talks to the co-founder of Wikipedia Jimmy Wales.
headline2: How Wikipedia maintains its reputation for accuracy
summary2:
The online encyclopedia, Wikipedia, has just marked its 20th birthday with some impressive statistics.
It now hosts 55 million articles, can be read in 300 languages and is read 8,000 times every second.
BBC Click's Lara Lewington spoke to the co-founder of Wikipedia Jimmy Wales to find out more.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: What it's like watching the Soviet Lord of the Rings
summary: A rediscovered Soviet TV version of The Lord of the Rings is drawing fans for all the wrong reasons.
headline2: Khraniteli: The Soviet take on Lord of the Rings
summary2: Russian-speaking fans of JRR Tolkien have been flocking to YouTube to watch a newly rediscovered Soviet TV version of The Lord of the Rings. The low-budget production, which aired briefly in 1991, the year the Soviet Union collapsed, was uploaded this month by Russian television channel 5TV (successor to Leningrad TV, which produced it).

headline: He made his name satirising Trump - now what?
summary: Why the show's not over for Randy Rainbow who used Broadway tunes to make fun of Donald Trump.
headline2: Randy Rainbow made his name satirising Trump - now what?
summary2: Those with cause to lament Donald Trump's departure from the White House may include America's satirists - the people he gave comic material to almost daily. In those four years the videos of Randy Rainbow delighted countless followers with satire chiefly using the improbable medium of Broadway show tunes. But the curtain's not down yet.

headline: Relive how Tsitsipas fought back to stun Nadal in five sets
summary: Relive how Stefanos Tsitsipas fought back to beat Rafael Nadal and reach the Australian Open semi-finals.
headline2: Relive how Tsitsipas fought back to stun Nadal in five sets
summary2:
Stefanos Tsitsipas beats Rafael Nadal in quarter-final classic
Greek sixth seed Tsitsipas wins 3-6 2-6 7-6 (7-4) 6-4 7-5
Plays Daniil Medvedev in semi-finals after Russian beat compatriot Andrey Rublev
World number one Ashleigh Barty stunned by Karolína Muchova in women's quarter-finals
Jennifer Brady beats fellow American Jessica Pegula

headline: Public pays tribute to Prince Philip: 'A loss to us all'
summary: 'He's someone I look up to as a young person,' said one of the visitors paying their respects to HRH Prince Philip.
headline2: Prince Philip: Mourners arrive in London and Windsor
summary2:
People have been visiting Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace to lay floral tributes and to pay their respects to Prince Philip.
An online book of condolences has been set up on the Royal Family's website and Royal officials have asked people not to gather or lay flowers, due to the pandemic, but many people felt they had to come anyway.

headline: Did Britain meddle in a US presidential election?
summary: When President Bush needed a smoking gun on his rival Bill Clinton, a key US ally dug for dirt.
headline2: Did Britain meddle in a US presidential election?
summary2: When US President George HW Bush craved "a smoking gun" in 1992 to politically kneecap his White House challenger Bill Clinton, the British government delved into its files for damaging information. So, did the Bush camp solicit foreign interference to help him win an election - the very allegation that has seen President Trump impeached?

headline: 'We sprang Grandma from the care home'
summary: Rita Perrott went into a care home, but then visiting was curtailed. Her family didn't want her to die alone.
headline2: 'We sprang Grandma from the care home'
summary2: The decision to place an elderly relative in a care home is a difficult one at the best of times, but the coronavirus pandemic and the restrictions on visiting make it even harder. For one family it seemed like the best solution before the virus arrived - but early last month they reversed their decision and brought 95-year-old Rita home.

headline: 'Odd radio circles' in the sky a ‘genuine mystery’
summary: A new high powered telescope has discovered inexplicable ghostly circles in the sky.
headline2: Astronomy: 'Odd radio circles' in the sky a ‘genuine mystery’
summary2:
A new high powered telescope in the Australian outback has led astronomers to an intriguing new discovery.
"Odd radio circles" or ORCs have never been seen before and have left scientists baffled.
Astrophysicist Professor Ray Norris explained to the BBC why the mysterious circles have the space community so excited.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Attenborough's new doc: 'Humans are the intruders'
summary: Sir David Attenborough fronts a new documentary on lockdown's effect on the natural world.
headline2: Sir David Attenborough's new doc: 'Humans are intruders'
summary2:
Sir David Attenborough has urged people to remember their impact on the natural world, ahead of his new documentary on the impacts of lockdown on nature.
He spoke to the BBC's David Shukman about his hopes for the project, the upcoming global climate summit and his young fan base.
'The Year Earth Changed' airs Friday 16 April on Apple TV+.

headline: NI riots: 'Young people are still being brainwashed'
summary: Lyra McKee's partner, Sara Canning, says "it's fed down that this is what your community does".
headline2: NI riots: 'Young people are still being brainwashed'
summary2:
Sara Canning believes "young people are still being brainwashed" in Northern Ireland.
Canning's partner, Lyra McKee was shot dead in 2019 while observing rioting in Londonderry.
Speaking to Victoria Derbyshire about the latest riots she said:
"It gives them something to cling to, and a way of maybe increasing their cachet in the community".

headline: Abood Hamam seen filming IS takeover of Raqqa
summary: Photographer Abood Hamam seen at work in Raqqa as the Islamic State group takes control of the city.
headline2: Abood Hamam seen filming IS takeover of Raqqa
summary2:
When the Islamic State group took over Raqqa, most journalists fled.
Abood Hamam, once a photographer to Bashar al-Assad, should have been in more danger than most, but he stayed, and went on working.
Extraordinary footage discovered later in the mobile phone of a dead IS fighter shows him in a long galabiya gown filming at a road junction.

headline: How stem cell ‘reboots’ could change medicine
summary: Bit.bio is working on a method to produce any type of cell in industrial quantities.
headline2: What a stem cell ‘reboot’ technique could mean for us?
summary2:
A technique which allows stem cells to be reprogrammed to produce any type of human cell in industrial quantities has been created by Cambridge company Bit.bio.
The technology could be used for patient therapies, studying rare diseases or discovering new medicines.
BBC Click’s Jen Copestake reports.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: 'Wearing a dream wedding dress on my big day'
summary: In a bid to represent African culture, Chioma Inyang set out to wear an Ankara-styled gown on her wedding day.
headline2: Nigeria: A fashion designer's challenge to wear an Ankara gown on her wedding day.
summary2:
In a bid to satisfy her desire and wish to represent African culture on her big day, Chioma Inyang set out to design an African wedding dress made with African prints fabric known as ‘Ankara’.
This was, to everyone’s dismay, sparking various kinds of reactions on social media.
Producer: Chimezie Ucheagbo
Video Journalist: Chiemela Mgbeahuru

headline: Sailors play with cats rescued from burning boat
summary: The four cats were spotted on the sinking boat by the navy in Thailand.
headline2: Thai navy sailors play with cats after rescue from sinking boat
summary2:
A group of Thai sailors has taken in four cats after rescuing them from a burning ship.
The navy sailors had been sent to inspect the sinking ship when they spotted the trapped felines and decided to enact a daring rescue.
Safely back on shore, the sailors got to know their new friends.
Read more: Thai navy rescue four cats from burning ship

headline: Bairstow & Stokes lead England to stunning victory - 2nd ODI as it happened
summary: Jonny Bairstow hits a century and Ben Stokes 99 off 52 balls as England level the one-day series against India.
headline2: Bairstow & Stokes lead England to stunning victory - 2nd ODI as it happened
summary2:
Bairstow's 124 helps England level series
Stokes hits brutal 99 off 52 balls - all-rounder went from 50 to 99 in 12 balls
England openers share quickfire 110 for first wicket
India put on 126 runs in last 10 overs to post 336-6
Rahul's classy 108 underpins India's total
Pant, who overturns two decisions via DRS, hits thrilling 77 off 40 balls

headline: Dyson: 'Brexit gives us freedom of spirt'
summary: The inventor tells the BBC that he believes leaving the EU was a good thing for the EU.
headline2: Sir James Dyson: 'Brexit gives us freedom of spirt'
summary2:
Brexit has given the UK back its independence, inventor Sir James Dyson has said.
"We've got our freedom, we can make trade agreements with other countries outside Europe," Sir James told the BBC.
He also defended moves to increase manufacturing overseas, saying: "We found suppliers here didn't want to expand. So we were forced to go abroad."

headline: Biden takes climate change advice from athlete, 14
summary: Anna Hursey,14, from Cardiff, who is a United Nations champion for climate change in sport.
headline2: Climate change: Biden takes advice from athlete, 14
summary2:
A young athlete said she was "excited and surprised" to be asked for advice on how to tackle climate change from the president of the United States.
Anna Hursey,14, from Cardiff, is a United Nations champion for climate change in sport after making history as the youngest-ever athlete to compete in the Commonwealth Games in 2018, aged only 11.

headline: 'The roar of the crowd shook my feet'
summary: Photographer Laura El-Tantawy looks back at her work documenting the 2011 revolution in Egypt.
headline2: Egypt's revolution: 'The roar of the crowd shook my feet'
summary2: Ten years ago, Cairo's central Tahrir Square was the focal point of protest against then Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and his government. Photographer Laura El-Tantawy was one of those who documented the demonstrations that grew in size and culminated with clashes between pro- and anti-government demonstrators and swept Mubarak from power.

headline: Race against time to save stranded whales
summary: Scores of whales have already died as conservationists begin a huge rescue operation.
headline2: Hundreds of whales stranded off the coast of Tasmania
summary2:
Scores of whales have died as conservationists begin a huge rescue operation at Macquarie Heads off the coast of Tasmania.
Approximately 270 whales were found stranded on two sand banks and a beach earlier in the week.
This unusual event is not unprecedented in this region as a similar number of whales were stranded nearby around a decade ago.

headline: Covid and dementia - 'let them see their families'
summary: Actress Ruthie Henshall is calling for more visiting access to family members in care homes.
headline2: Covid and dementia - 'let them see their families'
summary2:
Ruthie Henshall's mother has dementia and lives in a care home, with Covid restrictions meaning just one family member is allowed to see her in person.
The award-winning actress says her mother has deteriorated during the pandemic and has called on the government to loosen the guidance and grant more access for families of care home residents.

headline: Thousands attend funeral for Myanmar shooting victim
summary: Mya Thwe Thwe Khaing was shot in the head just before her 20th birthday by security forces.
headline2: Myanmar coup: Thousands attend funeral after deadly shooting
summary2:
Thousands attended a funeral for a young woman who was killed during a military coup protest.
Mya Thwe Thwe Khaing was shot in the head just before her 20th birthday by security forces and is one of at least three to die in the protests.
Candlelit vigils for the victims have been held as the mass protests continue.
Video courtesy of BBC Burmese

headline: India's debutants star as world champions humbled - relive the first ODI as it happened
summary: England slump from 135-0 to 251 all out in the first one-day international, to lose by 66 runs in Pune.
headline2: India's debutants star as world champions humbled - relive the first ODI as it happened
summary2:
England collapse from 135-0 to 251 all out
Bairstow (94) & Roy (46) put on rapid 135 for first wicket
India slip from 169-1 to 205-5, but recover to 317-5
Krunal Pandya, on debut, smashes 26-ball 50
Dhawan - dropped on 60 by Moeen - makes 98
Three wickets for Stokes; two for Wood
First ODI of three-match series; all matches being played at Pune

headline: Ball play: Tennis star's quarantine chain reaction machine
summary: Edouard Roger-Vasselin gets creative whilst stuck in his hotel ahead of the Australian Open.
summary2:
Tennis star Edouard Roger-Vasselin has been getting creative during his quarantine time ahead of the Australian Open.
The Frenchman has made and filmed two Rube Goldberg machines in his hotel room over the past week.
Players are required to stay in their rooms for 14 days, a small number testing positive for Covid after arriving in the country.

headline: Turnbull: 'Be careful what you wish for'
summary: Former Australian PM Malcolm Turnbull warns the UK against an Australian-style trading relationship with the EU.
headline2: Malcolm Turnbull: 'Be careful what you wish for'
summary2:
Speaking to BBC's Question Time, former Australian PM Malcolm Turnbull warned that the UK "should be careful what you wish for" in pursuing an Australian-style trading relationship with the EU.
Mr Turnbull described Australia's trade relationship with the EU, which is on WTO terms, as "pretty disappointing" and with "very big barriers" to trade.

headline: The lives changed by the Duke of Edinburgh's Award
summary: For pals James and Nathan, the awards are about more than hauling badly-packed rucksacks up hills.
headline2: Prince Philip: The Duke of Edinburgh's Award 'saved me from jail'
summary2: What does the Duke of Edinburgh's Award mean to you? For many it will conjure memories of hauling a badly-packed rucksack across rainy British countryside in the hope of adding some sparkle to their CV. Yet for some of the millions of young people who have taken on the self-improvement challenge, it has brought truly life-changing opportunities.

headline: 'Peas are a big hit with tadpoles'
summary: Stuck at home during lockdown, Richard Taylor-Jones swapped exotic creatures for garden wildlife.
headline2: Wildlife cameraman goes on backyard safari in Deal
summary2:
Richard Taylor-Jones travels the world as a wildlife cameraman for the BBC.
When lockdown arrived in March, his filming plans were abruptly cancelled and he found himself stuck at home in Deal, Kent.
Undaunted, he got out his camera and tripod, and made a film about the only wildlife he could get close to, the creatures living in his back garden.

headline: Fauci: Herd immunity an 'elusive concept'
summary: Dr Anthony Fauci, the top Covid adviser in the US, says a return to normality will be gradual.
headline2: Covid: Return to normality won't be a light switch moment, says Fauci
summary2:
Dr Anthony Fauci, chief medical adviser to President Joe Biden, has said that herd immunity is an "elusive concept" and there is no definitive percentage of the population that needs to be vaccinated to achieve it.
He told BBC Radio 4 Today that a return to normality would be gradual, and is "not going to be like a light switch going on and off."

headline: How Australia saved 70 stranded pilot whales
summary: Nearly 400 whales have died in Australia's worst stranding. Jools Farrell told the BBC how rescuers help those still alive.
headline2: Pilot whales Tasmania: Rescuing whales in Australia's worst stranding
summary2:
Nearly 400 whales have died in Australia's worst stranding, and rescuers are racing against the clock to save pilots whales who are beached on the west coast of Tasmania.
Whale rescue expert Jools Farrell, Vice President of ORRCA (Organisation for the Rescue and Research of Cetaceans in Australia), told the BBC how rescuers help those still alive.

headline: The wedding DJ who wants to stop migrant boats
summary: A growing band of campaigners is trying to push the government to stop migrants crossing from France.
headline2: The wedding DJ who wants to stop migrant boats
summary2: The migrants who drowned off the French coast this week were among thousands who have set off across the Channel in small boats this year - 8,000 had arrived in the UK by the end of September. A growing band of campaigners say they want to shine a light on the scale of the traffic, and to push the government into taking decisive action to stop it.

headline: 'I can’t wait to hug my family'
summary: Four staff from University Hospital Southampton reflect on the last year on their home and work lives.
headline2: Lockdown anniversary: Hospital workers on a year of Covid
summary2:
For a year we have all lived under Covid-19 restrictions. But how have hospital staff dealt with fighting the pandemic at work and living under lockdown at home?
Four staff from University Hospital Southampton tell the BBC about the impact of the last year on their home and work lives.
Filmed/edited by Rachel Price
Produced by Alexander Littlewood

headline: Hip-hop's iconic photos go on display
summary: The International Center of Photography is showcasing photos of hip-hop's greatest stars.
headline2: Hip-hop's iconic photos go on display
summary2:
The International Center of Photography in New York is showcasing photos of hip-hop's greatest stars.
Curator Vikki Tobak describes the exhibition as watching your favourite musical icons grow up in front of your eyes.
Included in the project is the photographer behind the famous image of The Notorious B.I.G. wearing a crown.
Producer: Mat Morrison

headline: How an outdoor centre inspired Duke of Edinburgh
summary: Set up in 1956 and based on a Welsh model, the award has now been completed by over eight million.
headline2: Prince Philip: Legacy of the Duke of Edinburgh's Award
summary2:
The Duke of Edinburgh's Award, set up by Prince Philip in 1956, was based on a Welsh model to inspire young people.
Currently more than eight million people have completed the award in more than 160 countries around the world.
When it was set up, the duke said he wanted to "give young people a chance to discover their own abilities for themselves".

headline: Myanmar protester: I am prepared to be killed
summary: Protester Thuta says he is prepared to die in the fight to restore democracy to Myanmar.
headline2: Myanmar protester: I am prepared to be killed
summary2:
A protester, Thuta, says he is prepared to die in the fight to restore democracy to Myanmar, also known as Burma.
Thuta told BBC World News that he has lost four friends in protests against the military coup, and how soldiers had opened fire on civilians.
“I’m prepared to be killed… live or die, I really want democracy, that's all I want," he said.

headline: Covid-19 vaccine hesitancy in Africa: Why the concern?
summary: Some African countries are witnessing Covid-19 vaccine hesitancy amidst the pandemic.
headline2: Covid-19 vaccine hesitancy in Africa: Your questions answered
summary2:
With Covid-19 vaccination programmes underway across Africa, great efforts are being made by countries to vaccinate as many of their citizens as possible.
However, there are concerns that a growing number of people are delaying or refusing the WHO recommended vaccines over their safety.
Produced and presented by Keisha Gitari
Edited by Josh Akinyemi

headline: 'Relief and excitement' over lifting lockdown
summary: Many business will be able to open for the first time this year.
headline2: Lifting lockdown: Businesses' 'relief and excitement'
summary2:
Under the government's "roadmap" out of lockdown, businesses face the prospect of being able to open their doors after months of closure, bringing with it a "huge sense of relief and excitement."
A barber, a B&B owner and a personal trainer told the BBC their feelings about the plans to lift coronavirus restrictions.
Video journalist: Stuart Maisner

headline: Chocolates and beer: Buying from Belgium after Brexit
summary: Companies that trade with the UK say higher prices and less choice are on the way.
headline2: Belgium after Brexit: How the change will affect popular exports
summary2:
The BBC has spoken to three companies that trade heavily with the UK, to find out what changes consumers can expect after Brexit.
These plant, beer and chocolate businesses say higher prices and less choice are on the cards as they grapple with the post-Brexit changes.
Producer: Sara Monetta
Reporter: Jean Mackenzie
Filmed and edited by: Andy Smythe

headline: The human cost of political inaction on Covid
summary: It was a battle against time for Tony Vargas, who put personal tragedy aside to do what he thought was right.
headline2: Tony Vargas in Nebraska: The human cost of political inaction on Covid
summary2: In Nebraska, which has some of the worst racial disparities when it comes to Covid-19 cases in the country, the state's sole Latino lawmaker tried to strengthen protections for meatpacking workers, all while confronting his own personal tragedy. It was a battle against time that revealed much about race, politics and workers' rights in the pandemic.

headline: Game, set, mattress: Australian Open isolation practice
summary: Some competitors must stay in their hotel rooms, following positive Covid cases on inbound flights.
headline2: Covid-19: Australian Open competitors practise in isolation hotels
summary2:
Competitors in the Australian Open are having to practise in different circumstances this year.
Some of them must stay inside, following positive Covid cases on inbound flights.
Artem Sitak, a doubles player, said: "It's not completely ruined but it's not the same now."
He added that after they come out of quarantine they'll be a "little bit rusty".

headline: 'I'd love to help other children'
summary: Cancer patient Connor is walking 20 miles in a month for charity
headline2: Northumberland teen raises thousands after cancer diagnosis
summary2:
A Northumberland teenager has raised almost £8,000 after being diagnosed with cancer last year.
Connor, from Cambois, decided to walk 20 miles over the month of March to raise money for charities which have supported him during his treatment.
The 14-year-old is undergoing chemotherapy during this challenge, but is determined to "help other children".

headline: Christchurch earthquake victims mourned 10 years on
summary: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern attends a service held in tribute to the 185 people who lost their lives.
headline2: Christchurch earthquake: Memorial held for victims 10 years on
summary2:
New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has attended a service held in tribute to the 185 people who died when a 6.3 magnitude earthquake hit Christchurch ten years ago.
The earthquake flattened buildings and destroyed homes in the city on New Zealand's South Island. It caused a huge amount of damage as the epicentre was just 5 km below the city.

headline: Dad-of-six charms the internet with meal tips
summary: Aboriginal man Nathan Lyons has found unexpected fame with videos inspired by "doing it tough".
headline2: Kooking with a Koori: How a Sydney father's simple meals have won hearts
summary2:
Sydney man Nathan Lyons does all the cooking for his family of eight.
When he began sharing meal tips on TikTok under the name Kooking with a Koori - a reference to an Aboriginal term he identifies with - Mr Lyons unexpectedly went viral.
He attributes much of his success to striking a chord with others who are "doing it tough".
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: The rapper's track that sparked a wave of killings
summary: Tensions have long existed between gangs in Tottenham and Wood Green - for 10 weeks in 2018 they boiled over.
headline2: The rapper's track that sparked a wave of killings
summary2: When a video of an attack on one of the UK's biggest rap stars went viral, three young people were murdered in the London borough of Haringey over the next 10 weeks. Tensions have long existed between rival gangs in Wood Green and Tottenham, but they rapidly escalated two years ago as tit-for-tat attacks were filmed and posted on Snapchat and YouTube.

headline: The pandemic's 'dramatic' effect on cancer care
summary: Experts predict a rise in serious cancers due to deferred screenings and treatments.
summary2:
Hundreds of thousands of Americans deferred their cancer screenings last year, and many who wanted care could not access it due to the pandemic's strain on hospitals. Now, experts predict that an excess of cases of serious cancers is on the horizon.
The BBC spoke to Dr Ned Sharpless, director of the National Cancer Institute, about the alarming trend.

headline: Could a banned film make the Oscars shortlist?
summary: Circus of Life tells the story of an elderly Muslim man who becomes vilified for dancing.
headline2: Circus of Life: Could banned film be on Oscars shortlist?
summary2:
A controversial film from Pakistan, which has been banned in the country, could make it onto the preliminary Oscars shortlist.
Circus of Life tells the story of an elderly Muslim man who becomes vilified in his community when a video of him dancing at a wedding goes viral.
Talking Movies Tom Brook reports.
Talking Movies can be seen on BBC World News.

headline: Brown: £22bn for Covid vaccines 'small price to pay'
summary: The US and Europe should each pay a quarter of the cost to help vaccinate poorer nations, says the former UK PM.
headline2: Covid-19 vaccines: Gordon Brown on G7 helping poorer countries
summary2:
The US and Europe should pay a quarter of the cost each to vaccinate poorer nations, a former UK prime minister has claimed.
Gordon Brown said the G7 and other wealthier nations "should pay their share” to help parts of Africa and Asia.
He said it should not be left to a "whip round" to deal with a "disease that has got be to be brought under control".

headline: Environment takes centre stage at games festival
summary: Climate change was on the agenda at the Now Play This festival, Cristina Criddle finds out more.
headline2: Environment takes centre stage at London games festival
summary2:
The Now Play This festival was a virtual event this year with a focus on games which looked at the environmental issues the world is facing.
Games included exploring a deserted Venice in the year 2089 and creating and maintaining a lake and the ecosystem around it, Cristina Criddle found out more for BBC Click.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: Australian Open: Nadal beats Norrie in straight sets
summary: Britain's Cameron Norrie is beaten by Rafael Nadal in the Australian Open third round - follow live text commentary.
headline2: Australian Open: Nadal beats Norrie in straight sets
summary2:
Day six of the Australian Open at Melbourne Park
Rafael Nadal beats Britain's Cameron Norrie 7-5 6-2 7-5
Ashleigh Barty beats Ekaterina Alexandrova 6-2 6-4 in third round
Stefanos Tsitsipas & Daniil Medvedev win
Sixth seed Karolina Pliskova is knocked out, Elina Svitolina advances
Click button at top of page for BBC Radio 5 Live Sports Extra commentary

headline: 'He really cared about promoting young people'
summary: In 1956 Prince Philip created The Duke of Edinburgh's Award to encourage young people to learn new skills and get active outdoors.
headline2: Prince Philip: How Duke of Edinburgh's Award motivated young Londoners
summary2:
Tributes have been paid to Prince Philip, who has died at the age of 99.
Many have come from those who took part in the Duke of Edinburgh's Award scheme, which was founded in 1956.
The scheme has provided thousands of Londoners with outdoor experience and new skills.
It was Prince Philip's aim to encourage young people from all backgrounds to take part.

headline: 'My 30-year struggle with racism in the Met'
summary: Former senior police officer Shabnam Chaudhri says she was unfairly treated, because of her ethnicity.
headline2: 'My 30-year struggle with racism in the Metropolitan police'
summary2: Shabnam Chaudhri rose to become one of the Met's most senior female Asian officers, but she says she was unfairly treated throughout her career because of her ethnicity. Her experience highlights concerns about the treatment of BAME officers in the UK that have persisted for years, write the BBC's Oliver Newlan and Home Affairs correspondent Danny Shaw.

headline: Pharmacist documents Covid working in hospital
summary2:
A pharmacist says they have been an "essential" part of keeping people safe during the pandemic.
Emily Wilkins has been helping the teams at Great Western Hospital, Swindon, deliver Covid-19 vaccines and cancer medicines safely to patients.
The hospital kept its cancer services running throughout the pandemic but Ms Wilkins said it has been "difficult".

headline: Salmond aims for independence 'supermajority'
summary: Former Scottish first minister Alex Salmond says his new party wants to build "a supermajority for independence".
summary2:
Former Scottish first minister Alex Salmond says his new party wants to build "a supermajority for independence".
Mr Salmond said he would be among the candidates who will stand for the Alba Party on regional lists in May's Scottish Parliament elections.
Other parties described Mr Salmond as "discredited" and questioned his suitability for public office.

headline: Secret filming exposes poor practice at testing lab
summary: A BBC undercover reporter has found evidence of poor practices and potential contamination at one of the biggest UK Covid testing labs.
headline2: Covid: Panorama undercover footage exposes potential contamination at testing lab
summary2:
A BBC undercover reporter has found evidence of poor practices and potential contamination at one of the biggest UK Covid testing labs.
Panorama's undercover footage shows a technician pushing a test swab back into a sample test tube, causing potential contamination.
The lab says it follows all necessary rules and regulations.
Reporter: Jacqui Wakefield.

headline: The fishermen swapping petrol for electricity
summary: Fishermen on Lake Victoria in Kenya have begun using some of Africa’s first electric fishing boats.
headline2: Fisherman in Kenya swap petrol outboard motors for electric engines
summary2:
Fishermen on Lake Victoria in Kenya have begun using some of Africa’s first electric fishing boats. A Kenya-based start-up is offering battery-powered engines to some of the tens of thousands of boats which go out onto the water each night, as a cheaper and greener alternative to petrol ones.
Producer: Leila Nathoo
Producers: Joe Inwood and Rachael Thorn

headline: US soldier faces guns and pepper spray in traffic stop
summary: A black army lieutenant is suing police after he was pulled over by two officers in Virginia.
headline2: US soldier faces guns and pepper spray in traffic stop
summary2:
A black US army lieutenant has filed a lawsuit against two police officers who pointed their guns at him and pepper-sprayed his face during a traffic stop.
Lt Caron Nazario was pulled over while wearing his uniform in December in Windsor, Virginia.
A police report says his car was stopped for not displaying a licence plate, but a temporary one is visible.

headline: Bringing an Australian wetland back to life
summary: Walker Swamp had been destroyed by 150 years of farming - now it is replenished and welcoming life.
headline2: Walker Swamp: The mission to restore an Australian wetland
summary2:
In the shadow of Australia's Grampians National Park lies Walker Swamp, a once-thriving wetland that was artificially drained and farmed for over a century.
But it is now welcoming new life once more, after a huge restoration project.
Its revival is one "message of hope" amid so much grim environmental news, ecologists tell the BBC.
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: World leaders pay tribute to Prince Philip
summary: Joe Biden called the duke "a heck of a guy", while Jacinda Ardern highlighted his awards scheme.
summary2:
World leaders including US President Joe Biden and New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern have paid tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.
Mr Biden called the duke "a heck of a guy", while Ms Ardern highlighted his awards scheme.
Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II's husband of 73 years, died on Friday.
Aged 99, he was the longest-serving royal consort in British history.

headline: Police step up crackdown in Myanmar
summary: Police have fired on protesters in Myanmar, on the deadliest day since rallies against the country's coup began.
headline2: Myanmar coup: Casualties rise as police step up crackdown
summary2:
Police have fired on protesters in Myanmar killing at least 10, according to medics, on the deadliest day since rallies against the country's coup began.
Deaths were reported in Yangon, Dawei and Mandalay.
Gunfire was heard on the streets of the city of Dawei amidst continuing protests.
Read more: Myanmar coup: Deadliest day of protests as police open fire

headline: What's the right price to pay for genocide?
summary: Germany is set to apologise to Namibia for a genocide more than 100 years ago - and to pay an as yet unknown amount of money.
headline2: Germany and Namibia: What's the right price to pay for genocide?
summary2: A deal that could set a precedent for former colonies all around the world is being thrashed out between Germany and Namibia, to heal the wounds of what's now widely regarded as a genocide by colonial forces. But how do you make up for destroying an entire society? In Namibia, descendants of both victims and colonisers are arguing fiercely about the talks.

headline: Oysters released to save species in north Wales
summary: More than 1,000 oysters are released in north Wales to try to stop the species dying out there.
summary2:
More than 1,000 oysters have been released in north Wales to try to stop the species dying out in the area.
The shellfish were once a major part of Wales' fishing industry.
Now they have been placed in nursery cages under the boardwalks of Conwy marina.
Conservationists hope they will help reverse the impact of over-fishing and water quality on the species.

headline: How the pandemic will change how we cast our votes
summary: The pandemic will mean an increase in postal voting and extra precautions at polling stations.
headline2: Local elections 2021: How Covid-19 affects polling stations
summary2:
With local elections taking place on 6 May, officials are preparing to make polling stations Covid-secure.
Changes will include one-way systems for voters, who will be asked to bring their own pens, and protective screens.
There are also important deadlines for anyone who wants to vote by post. The BBC's South East Political Editor Lauren Moss explains more.

headline: Debunking Africa's top coronavirus myths
summary: BBC Africa's Joice Etutu tackles myths around Covid-19 that are being shared online on the continent.
headline2: Coronavirus in Africa: Debunking fake news and myths around Covid-19
summary2:
As the Covid-19 pandemic continues, an outbreak of false information is spreading online.
Whether it's via WhatsApp messages or rogue Facebook posts, fake news always has a way of reaching people.
Keeping track of what’s real and what’s fake isn’t always easy, so BBC Africa’s Joice Etutu has debunked some of the most widely shared myths so you don't have to.

headline: Can apps help our relationships during lockdowns?
summary: Couples explain how tech has helped strengthen their relationships during the pandemic.
headline2: Lockdown and in love: Can apps help our relationships?
summary2:
Coronavirus lockdowns can bring stresses and challenges to relationships, particularly if we are separated from our loved ones or have to stay in each other’s company for longer than we are used to.
But can technology improve communication with our partners and help our relationships?
BBC Click’s Omar Mehtab reports.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: 'We decided to take the plunge together'
summary: Three friends who took up sea swimming during lockdown inspire a photography project.
headline2: Whitley Bay sea swimmers inspire photography project
summary2: When the UK first went into lockdown three friends living on the same street in a seaside town found themselves with time on their hands. Working from home meant no daily commute, so they came up with the idea of trying sea swimming. Little did they know how cold it would be or how it would change them and inspire a photographer searching for subject matter.

headline: 'I left my campervan in Argentina'
summary: Thousands of van-driving nomads were living the dream - until the coronavirus pandemic brought them to a sudden halt.
headline2: 'I left my campervan in Argentina'
summary2: Imagine breaking free. You sell your possessions, buy a van, pack it with what you need, and go. For months or years you live a frugal life, going wherever you want. But for thousands who made this dream a reality, coronavirus brought them to a sudden halt, writes Paula Dear, and left them stranded with a van and a vanload of kit on the far side of the world.

headline: PM announces plans for more UK made vaccines
summary: Boris Johnson says the UK will make 50-60 million vaccine doses in the North East of England.
headline2: PM announces plans for more UK made vaccines
summary2:
Boris Johnson has said the UK will make more vaccine doses in the North East of England.
Mr Johnson said alongside the vaccine rollout, the UK is "building up our own long-term UK manufacturing capabilities" for vaccines.
He said Novavax is going to make a jab at Fujifilm in the North East, and GlaxoSmithKline will also finish and bottle vaccines in the area.

headline: Ends of the earth love story that defied pandemic
summary: Andrew is moving thousands of miles from Australia to Torquay to meet Rosanna again.
headline2: Covid: Ends of the earth love story that defied pandemic
summary2:
A man is moving across the world to live with someone he hasn’t seen in nearly a decade.
Rosanna Wilson and Andrew Monck first met in 2011, but have got in contact again during the pandemic.
Andrew lives in Australia, but after being granted an exemption to leave the country permanently, is travelling more than 9,300 miles (15,000km) to join Rosanna in Devon.

headline: Meet the first pet getting the 'animal OBE'
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people have seen videos of a therapy dog called Max and his Lake District walks.
headline2: Meet the first pet getting the 'animal OBE'
summary2:
Hundreds of thousands of people have watched online videos of a therapy dog called Max and his walks in the Lake District.
Now he's going to be the first pet to be given the PDSA's Order of Merit, which the charity has previously awarded to police and search and rescue animals and calls the "animal OBE".
Read more: Max the Miracle Dog gets 'animal OBE' honour

headline: 'Did air pollution kill my daughter?'
summary: A new inquest into the death of Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah could list air pollution as a cause of her death.
headline2: Rosamund Adoo-Kissi-Debrah: 'Did air pollution kill my daughter?'
summary2: A fresh inquest into the death of an asthmatic nine-year-old girl starts on Monday, after a medical report suggested a direct link between her illness and poor air quality near her home, not far from a busy road. Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah could now become the first person in the UK - and possibly in the world - to have "air pollution" listed as a cause of death.

headline: Sinkholes eat up land in Croatian village
summary: They've been appearing in unusually high numbers after an earthquake hit the region in December.
headline2: Sinkholes appearing in Croatian village after earthquake
summary2:
Sinkholes have been appearing in the village of Mecencani, a village 40km away from Croatia's capital.
Their appearance isn't unusual, given that the region was hit by a 6.4 magnitude earthquake in December.
However, residents and geologists have noted the frequency of the sinkholes, stirring up significant concern in an area still rebuilding after the quake.

headline: 'Super rare' whale encounter on Great Barrier Reef
summary: A dive instructor has recorded his ‘special moment’ with a humpback whale.
summary2:
Scuba dive instructor Andrew Lomakin filmed an incredible 12-minute encounter with a juvenile humpback whale in the shallows of Lady Elliot Island.
Australia's east coast whale migration brings humpbacks to the warm waters of the Great Barrier Reef every year, but Mr Lomakin described the interaction in the shallow water as "super rare".
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: Nandy: Timing of China sanctions 'grubby and cynical'
summary: The foreign secretary “has not listened” to politicians from all sides over the need to take action against China, says Lisa Nandy.
headline2: Nandy on China's treatment of Uighur Muslims in camps
summary2:
The foreign secretary “has not listened” to politicians from all sides over the need to take action against China, Lisa Nandy has said.
The shadow foreign secretary said there had been “mounting evidence over several years” and claimed the sanctions announced by Dominic Raab action was designed to send a message to Conservative backbenchers, more than to China

headline: Myanmar coup: How did we get here?
summary: The people of Myanmar watched a coup unfold on 1 February. But why are they scared?
headline2: Myanmar coup: What led to the military seizing power?
summary2:
Many around the world were caught by surprise when the military seized power in Myanmar.
The Southeast Asian country was on the road to democracy having held an election just a few months ago.
The BBC's Flora Drury explains what events led to the coup, and how the military has dealt with opposition in the past.
Editing by Aimran Supardi
Produced by Saira Asher

headline: Man rescues stranded goose stuck in mud
summary: Footage shows a man wading through thick mud to help rescue a stranded goose stuck in a lake.
headline2: Trapped goose rescued from mud in Birmingham park lake
summary2:
Footage shared on social media shows a man rescue a stranded goose which had got stuck in mud in a Birmingham park.
The bird was trapped in Cannon Hill Park's boating lake, which is currently drained of water as essential work is being carried out.
The unidentified man waded through the thick mud to help the trapped bird which has now been released to freedom.

headline: The former WW2 ghetto falling into ruin
summary: There are concerns that historical evidence will be lost if Terezin's buildings are not maintained.
headline2: Terezin: The former WW2 ghetto falling into ruin
summary2:
The Czech town of Terezin – Theresienstadt in German – is best known as the site of a Nazi concentration camp and ghetto during World War Two.
But many of the buildings that once housed tens of thousands of Jews, not only from Czechoslovakia but from across Europe, are now falling into disrepair.
The BBC’s Prague correspondent Rob Cameron has been to the town.

headline: Sydney remembers Philip: ‘We feel more connected now’
summary: More than 500 people attended a church service in Sydney, Australia, where Prince Philip was remembered.
headline2: Sydney remembers Prince Philip: ‘We feel more connected now’
summary2:
Church services and prayers have been held around the world for the Queen after the death of her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh.
One of the biggest events was in Sydney’s St Andrew’s Cathedral.
With only minimal Covid-19 restrictions in place, more than 500 people attended - including Australia’s Prime Minister, Scott Morrison.
Video produced by Simon Atkinson

headline: 'The light's back on in my mum's eyes'
summary: Actor Ruthie Henshall says the improvement in her mum's condition has been "incredible" since she's been able to visit her.
headline2: Covid-19 and care homes: 'The light's back on in my mum's eyes'
summary2:
Actor Ruthie Henshall has spoken about her happiness at being able to see her mother, Gloria, again in her care home after restrictions were eased two weeks ago.
She can now go into the care home and feed her mother lunch, read to her, or sing her favourite songs. Speaking to BBC Breakfast, she said the improvement in her mum's condition had been "incredible".

headline: A year of violence on the road to peace
summary: On the anniversary of the US-Taliban deal, Afghanistan finds itself in a precarious state.
headline2: Afghanistan: A year of violence on the road to peace
summary2: A year ago this week, the Taliban signed a deal with the United States designed, in theory, to pave the road to peace in Afghanistan. It committed the Taliban to preventing attacks on US forces and the US to withdrawing its remaining troops from the country. It did not commit the Taliban to a ceasefire with respect to Afghanistan's government, or its citizens.

headline: How Piers Morgan's GMB exit unfolded
summary: The BBC's Colin Paterson gives the lowdown on Piers Morgan's departure from Good Morning Britain.
headline2: How Piers Morgan's GMB exit unfolded
summary2:
After six years on the show, presenter Piers Morgan stormed off the set of Good Morning Britain and later decided to leave the programme.
It followed the presenter's criticism of the Duchess of Sussex, saying he "didn't believe a word" Meghan Markle said in her interview with Oprah Winfrey.
The BBC's entertainment correspondent, Colin Paterson, breaks it down.

headline: 'We wouldn't have carriage driving without Philip'
summary: Prince Philip would relax with friends and be treated the same as everyone else, says a fellow driver.
headline2: Prince Philip: 'We wouldn't have carriage driving without the duke'
summary2:
The Duke of Edinburgh will be greatly missed by his friends in the carriage driving community, a fellow competitor has said.
Prince Philip was known for his love of the sport and has been credited with bringing it to the UK.
Rowena Moyse, from Gowerton, Swansea, competed at the same events as the duke and said if it was not for him, "we wouldn't have the sport".

headline: Australian Open: Barty races past Rogers to reach last eight
summary: Follow live text and radio commentary from the Australian Open as number one seed Ash Barty easily beats Shelby Rogers in the fourth round.
headline2: Australian Open: Barty races past Rogers to reach last eight
summary2:
Day eight of the Australian Open at Melbourne Park
Number one seed Ashleigh Barty beats USA's Shelby Rogers 6-3 6-4
2009 champion Rafael Nadal beats Fabio Fognini to reach last eight
Stefanos Tsitsipas through after Matteo Berretini withdraws
Karolina Muchova beats Elise Mertens 7-6 (7-5) 7-5
Use audio icon for BBC Radio 5 Live Sports Extra commentary from 07:00

headline: 'Why I don't want to live in a house'
summary: Stewart has been homeless for years He's slept on the street but also, he says, in some "great places".
headline2: 'I’m homeless but I find great places to live'
summary2: Stewart has been homeless for most of his adult life. He's slept in shop doorways, church porches and on railway platforms, but also - he says - in some "great places". He now lives on an abandoned allotment in North Yorkshire, and has no desire to live in a house or flat again. Although he has ambitious plans for the future, he's content with his life as it is.

headline: Bells toll in tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh
headline2: Gloucester Cathedral's bell toll 99 times for Prince Philip
summary2:
Cathedral bells across the country have tolled 99 times in tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh, following his death on Friday.
Members of the public paid their respects outside Gloucester Cathedral on Saturday afternoon.
Royal gun salutes have also taken place in cities across the UK including London, Edinburgh and Cardiff and at Hillsborough Castle in County Down.

headline: Cradle to grave: Religion in 21st Century Britain
summary: From birth, to coming of age, marriage and death, how do five religions celebrate these crucial moments?
headline2: Faith and ritual: Religion in 21st century Britain
summary2:
Through celebrations and rituals, different religions mark key stages in life.
A new series on BBC iPlayer, Being, explores what these ancient rituals mean to people in modern Britain.
From birth, to coming of age, marriage and death, how do five religions celebrate these crucial moments?
Producer: Harry Farley
Picture editors: Stephen Bulfield and Michael Latham

headline: 'Find people who complement your weaknesses'
summary: Amber Atherton, boss of tech firm Zyper, says you need staff who are good at things you might not be.
summary2:
Amber Atherton, boss of tech firm Zyper (recently bought by Discord), says you need staff who are good at things you might not be. A Brit running a San Francisco-based business, she adds that entrepreneurs also have to be resilient to change.
Ms Atherton was interviewed for a new mini-series called Paths to Success.
Filmed by Cody Godwin. Edited by Robert Miller.

headline: British racing drivers on show at Silverstone
summary: Photographer Indira Flack's portraits of British racing drivers.
headline2: British racing drivers on show at Silverstone
summary2: When Indira Flack started photographing British racing drivers, she wasn't sure who - if anyone - would get to see the pictures. Yet now 100 of them can be seen at The Silverstone Experience, which celebrates the past, present and future of British motorsport, and was recently officially opened by the Duke of Sussex and multiple F1 world champion, Lewis Hamilton.

headline: Time-lapse shows Indonesian volcano's huge ash cloud
summary: The Indonesian volcano's latest eruption sent ash up to 5km (3.1 miles) into the air.
headline2: Mount Sinabung: Time-lapse shows Indonesia volcano's 5km-high ash cloud
summary2:
An Indonesian volcano erupted on Tuesday, sending clouds of ash up to 5km (3.1 miles) into the sky.
Located in North Sumatra, Mount Sinabung first erupted in 2010 after being inactive for centuries, and has seen an increase in its activity over the last year.
There are no reported injuries but locals have been advised to stay 3km (1.9 miles) away from the crater.

headline: Brexit leaves bitter taste and mountain of clothes
summary: North East firms say they have hit hurdles since the Brexit trade agreement came into force.
headline2: Brexit leaves a bitter taste and a mountain of clothes
summary2: It is more than a month since the UK's new trading relationship with the European Union (EU) came into being but the transition has been far from easy for some businesses. From being told to set up operations in Europe, having goods stuck in port and facing increased costs to clear the border, three North East firms reveal the reality of adapting to the new rules.

headline: Nasa's Perseverance rover starts rolling on Mars
summary: The one-tonne robot wiggles its wheels before rolling forwards across Jezero Crater's dusty terrain.
headline2: Nasa's Perseverance rover starts rolling on Mars
summary2:
The US space agency's Perseverance rover has wiggled its wheels and undertaken its first Martian drive.
It didn't move far - just 6.5m (21ft) in total, but Nasa's deputy project scientist Katie Stack Morgan said it was a significant moment. This simulation describes the movements made in the first drive.
Read more: Perseverance rover begins its exploration of Mars

headline: Nomadland and Zhao scoop top Bafta awards
summary: Chloé Zhao became the second woman in Bafta history to win best director, for her film Nomadland.
summary2:
This video has been removed for rights reasons
Chloé Zhao became the second woman in Bafta history to win best director, at a socially-distanced ceremony.
Her film, Nomadland, won four Baftas, including Best Film - more awards than any other film this year.
Not all winners could make the event, and one only clocked he had won when he heard his neighbours cheering.

headline: Covid: 'We need a memorial to remember'
summary: Ellis Tustin, founder of Names not Numbers, explains why he thinks the UK needs a permanent memorial to those who have died of Covid-19.
headline2: Covid: 'We need a memorial to remember'
summary2:
The prime minister has said that "at the right moment" a permanent memorial would be built for people who lost their lives to Covid.
After his grandfather died last year, Ellis Tustin founded the group Names not Numbers to commemorate those who died.
He tells the BBC why he thinks it is important the country finds ways of remembering.
Shot and edited by Adam Walker

headline: Candidates clash in London mayoral debate
summary: Shaun Bailey and Sadiq Khan did not hold back in a head-to-head TV debate ahead of the 6 May election.
headline2: London elections 2021: Sadiq Khan and Shaun Bailey clash in London mayoral debate
summary2:
Labour's Sadiq Khan and Tory Shaun Bailey did not hold back in a head-to-head debate that got personal at times.
