The two leading candidates to become mayor of London set out their stalls on policing, transport and the capital's recovery from the pandemic.
The two are are among a number of candidates standing to become London's mayor on 6 May.
Video by Gem O'Reilly.

headline: Photographer takes key workers' portraits
headline2: Coronavirus: Leeds photographer takes key workers' portraits
summary2:
A photographer from Leeds is taking "social distancing" portraits of key workers.
George Coppock and his daughter Bella take the pictures of medical staff, postal workers, police officers, farmers and shop workers outside their homes at a distance of 6ft (2m).
Ms Coppock said the pictures highlighted "regular people in your community who are helping to save lives".

headline: The monks divided over Myanmar's coup
summary: Hundreds have been killed in deadly protests since the military took control of the country in February.
headline2: Myanmar coup: The monks divided over the deadly protests
summary2:
Thousands of people have been arrested, and hundreds killed, during protests in Myanmar.
Buddhist monks have a lot of influence in the country and some have joined the protests, while others support the military.
The BBC spoke to two monks on opposing sides, U Par Mauk Kha and U Sandar Thiri, and heard their thoughts on the violence, and how Myanmar can find peace.

headline: Brothers melt plastic into everyday objects
summary: Matt and Jonny Browning create YouTube videos in their spare time on how to recycle plastic.
headline2: YouTubers from Dorset create objects from melted plastic
summary2:
Two brothers have set up a YouTube channel to show people how they can safely melt and re-use plastic.
Matt and Jonny Browning, from Southbourne in Dorset, use their spare time to work on their channel Brothers Make.
Their videos show how they melt and use plastic items like milk bottle tops to create everyday objects like spoons, cheeseboards and more unusual toys.

headline: Onions, ironing and 'sex appeal'
summary: The gaffe-prone former prime minister is a polarising figure in Australia.
summary2:
He's been accused of sexism and homophobia. He's a sceptic of climate science. He ate a raw onion on live TV. He was also prime minister of Australia for two years.
Gaffe-prone Tony Abbott was a polarising figure in Australian politics, and now he's been appointed as the UK government's new trade adviser, he’s causing quite a stir here too.
Produced by James Wignall

headline: Starmer says NHS 1% pay offer is a 'real insult'
summary: The Labour leader says NHS staff and other public sector workers "need to be properly rewarded".
headline2: Keir Starmer on pay rise for NHS and public sector workers
summary2:
The Labour leader has said NHS staff and other public sector workers "need to be properly rewarded".
Sir Keir Starmer spoke after the Department of Health made a 1% pay increase recommendation to the independent panel that advises on NHS salaries in England.
He said that was “insulting” and they should get a pay rise, while a pay cut was "completely the wrong thing".

headline: 'I'm happy Cadet finally got recognition before he died'
summary: Krept reflects on Cadet's life and legacy more than a year since his death, as his debut album is released.
headline2: Cadet The Rated Legend: Krept on his cousin's life and legacy
summary2: On 9 February 2019, Blaine Johnson, better known as Cadet, was on his way to perform a gig at Keele University when the taxi he was in crashed, killing him and injuring the other passengers in the car. More than a year later, as his debut album Rated Legend is released, Cadet's cousin Krept reflects on their at-times complicated relationship. As told to Kameron Virk…

headline: Why I bought the Lil Nas X 'Satan Shoes'
summary: With art collective MSCHF, singer Lil Nas X created a pair of pricey and controversial trainers.
headline2: Why I bought the Lil Nas X 'Satan Shoes'
summary2:
In partnership with the art collective MSCHF, singer Lil Nas X created a pair of pricey - $1,018 (£740) - and controversial trainers.
MSCHF only produced 666 pairs of the shoes, which include a drop of human blood in the soles. Made using modified Nike Air Max 97s, they sold out in less than a minute.
The BBC spoke to two people on why they bought these pricey shoes.

headline: Why Australia-China row matters
summary: Ros Atkins explains why relations between the two countries are deteriorating fast.
headline2: Outside Source: Why Australia-China row matters
summary2:
China and Australia have always had their differences, but now relations between the two countries are souring at an unprecedented rate.
The BBC's Ros Atkins explains what has happened so far and why this is a departure from a regular diplomatic fall-out between two countries.
Instead, it points towards a bigger political game taking place between China and the West.

headline: 'Nothing escaped duke's eagle gaze' - Lumley
summary: Joanna Lumley shares her memories of attending dinners and events with Prince Philip.
headline2: Prince Philip: Joanna Lumley on duke's 'overlooked' kindness and 'eagle gaze'
summary2:
Actor and activist Joanna Lumley has shared her memories of Prince Philip, saying that his kindness was "quite often overlooked".
Ms Lumley told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show about the "great pleasure" of attending dinners and events with the Duke of Edinburgh.
She said "nothing escaped his eagle gaze" - as she discovered when she once turned up late to a charity event.

headline: Applause for 104-year-old who beat Covid - twice
summary: Carmen Hernandez was given a standing ovation as she left hospital in Colombia.
headline2: Covid: Applause for 104-year-old Colombian who beat coronavirus - twice
summary2:
A 104-year-old Colombian woman has received a standing ovation from hospital staff after recovering from Covid-19 for a second time.
Carmen Hernandez was first diagnosed with coronavirus in June 2020, and she was treated in her San Jose nursing home.
The second time, she was admitted to intensive care and spent 21 days in hospital - until she was discharged on Monday.

headline: 'No-one was willing to treat me during Covid'
summary: Lupus patients share their experiences of dealing with the autoimmune disease during the pandemic.
headline2: Lupus: 'No-one seemed willing to treat me during Covid'
summary2: Some people living with the incurable autoimmune disease lupus have had treatments delayed or cancelled during the coronavirus pandemic. But they also told Cambridge University researchers they now feel more understood by society, as everyone has had to protect themselves and adapt to a slower pace of life. The BBC has spoken to three patients about their experiences.

headline: A millionaire’s plan to create a local government
summary: Jeffrey Berns wants to build a tech oasis in the Nevada desert. Do others share his utopian vision?
headline2: Nevada smart city: A millionaire’s plan to create a local government
summary2: A radical experiment is being considered in the US state of Nevada. It would allow new local governments to be formed on land owned by tech firms. Jeffrey Berns, the cryptocurrency millionaire who proposed the idea, is convinced of its revolutionary potential. The challenge now is changing the minds of sceptics who are not. For some, one man's utopia is their dystopia.

headline: Covid and Crossrail - why TfL's finances are precarious
summary: The prime minister and London's mayor have clashed over TfL's finances. What is the bigger picture?
headline2: Why Transport for London's finances are far from healthy
summary2: Sadiq Khan has clashed with his mayoral predecessor Boris Johnson over claims made by the prime minister that Transport for London (TfL) was "effectively bankrupt" even before the Covid crisis. Mr Khan rejects this, and has called Mr Johnson a "liar". He insists he was balancing the books until the UK was crippled by the coronavirus pandemic. What is the bigger picture?
subsection: East London & West Essex Guardian Series

headline: Iceland shaken by 50,000 earthquakes in three weeks
summary: Geologist Helga Torfadottir takes a BBC team to an active volcano area.
headline2: Iceland shaken by more than 50,000 earthquakes in three weeks
summary2:
Iceland has recorded more than 50,000 earthquakes in the past three weeks.
This unusual activity indicates a volcanic eruption is on its way.
Scientists are baffled over when it will happen and Icelanders are learning to live with the shakes.
BBC Europe correspondent Jean Mackenzie visited the area.
Video produced by Kate Vandy. Filmed and edited by Xavier Vanpevenaege.

headline: ‘Time is of the essence’ to save our oceans
summary: Marine scientist Professor Jessica Meeuwig on her hopes for a new ocean monitoring system.
headline2: World’s largest ocean monitoring system BRUVS launched
summary2:
Professor Jessica Meeuwig, the Director of the Centre for Marine Futures at the University of Western Australia, has told the BBC about her hopes for a new ocean monitoring system.
The UK government funded project, known as BRUVS, will focus on monitoring marine life in ten British Overseas Territories including Pitcairn and Ascension Island.
Video produced by Anna Boyd

headline: Where are Cape Town's great white sharks?
summary: Barely a single great white shark has been spotted off the city's coast for two years, where once there were hundreds.
headline2: Where are Cape Town's great white sharks?
summary2:
For years, one of South Africa’s great tourist attractions has been the opportunity to see, up close, one of the world’s most fearsome predators - the great white shark.
But barely a single one has been spotted off the coast of Cape Town for two years now – where there used to be hundreds.
What’s going on?
Reporter: Andrew Harding
Camera and editing: Christian Parkinson

headline: Lib Dem leader wants UK to boycott China Olympics
summary: Sir Ed Davey calls for Team GB to boycott next year's Winter Olympics in Beijing over the treatment of Uighur Muslims in China's Xinjiang region.
headline2: Lib Dem Ed Davey wants UK to boycott China Olympics
summary2:
Sir Ed Davey has called for Team GB to boycott next year's Winter Olympics in Beijing over the treatment of Uighur Muslims in China's Xinjiang region.
The Lib Dem leader said it was a "genocide happening in front of our eyes".
Boris Johnson said it was a "longstanding position" of the UK government to "not normally" be in favour of sporting boycotts.
PMQs: As It Happened

headline: Getting Covid hospital patients ready to go home
summary: From intensive care to back home, occupational therapists like Louise and Eleanor are helping Covid patients back on their feet.
headline2: Covid diaries: Getting Swindon patients back on their feet
summary2:
Occupational therapists Louise White and Eleanor Woodley are helping Covid patients get back on their feet.
They have recorded diaries while working at Great Western Hospital in Swindon, Wiltshire.
They are also providing reassurance to patients, telling them they are aiming to get them home, as patients' loved ones are not there to do it.
Video journalist: Abigail Mobbs

headline: 'I know what it's like for your childhood to be stolen'
summary: Photojournalist Nelly Ating captures images and harrowing stories of those displaced by Boko Haram.
headline2: Nigeria: Making sure children displaced by Boko Haram get education is 'personal'
summary2:
Nigerian photojournalist, Nelly Ating, has been documenting the plight of displaced victims of Boko Haram since 2014.
Her work focuses on highlighting the impact of childhood trauma on Nigeria's next generation. Willing to make an impact, Nelly started crowdfunding to pay the school fees of some of the children orphaned by the insurgents.
Filmed and edited by Grace Ekpu.

headline: Doctor: One-in-three children are not leaving the house
summary: Only a third of children in Bradford had sufficient exercise during the first lockdown, a study shows.
headline2: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Study shows one-in-three children have rarely been leaving the house
summary2: A new study indicates that only a third of children in Bradford had sufficient exercise in the first lockdown, last spring - and that a similar proportion were rarely leaving the home. Dr John Wright, of Bradford Royal Infirmary, says this is contributing to a different kind of health crisis, one that began long before the pandemic, but risks becoming worse because of it.

headline: Duchess of Cambridge celebrates wildlife photos
summary: HRH The Duchess of Cambridge honours a stunning picture of a Siberian tiger.
headline2: Duchess of Cambridge celebrates wildlife photos
summary2:
The 2020 Wildlife Photographer of the Year award has been won by Sergey Gorshkov, who took a picture of a female Amur tiger rubbing against a tree. Her Royal Highness The Duchess of Cambridge announced the winning image during an online event streamed from London's Natural History Museum. Victoria Gill reports.
Read more: Hidden camera's hugging tiger wins top photo award

headline: Myanmar: BBC journalist 'taken by men in plain clothes'
summary: Aung Thura was taken away by men in plain clothes while reporting outside a court in the capital, Nay Pyi Taw, says BBC's Mary Hockaday.
headline2: Myanmar protests: BBC journalist Aung Thura detained
summary2:
A reporter with the BBC Burmese service has been detained in Myanmar as clashes continue between security forces and protesters.
Aung Thura was taken away by men in plain clothes while reporting outside a court in the capital, Nay Pyi Taw.
Mary Hockaday, controller of BBC World Service English, called on authorities to help locate him and confirm that he is safe and well.

headline: Crowds gather to watch pair boxing
summary: People gathered to watch two people boxing at the playing fields near Cannon Hill Park.
headline2: Covid: Crowds gather to watch pair boxing in Birmingham
summary2:
Footage showing two men in boxing gloves in a ring of onlookers was recorded during an event on playing fields near Cannon Hill Park on Tuesday evening.
The BBC understands a party had been arranged earlier in the day via social media and at the time there was no police presence.
West Midlands Police said officers had been sent there but "did not need to issue any fines".

headline: The crack that produced a new Antarctic iceberg
summary: A big iceberg breaks away from the Antarctic, close to Britain's Halley research station.
headline2: The Brunt crack that produced a new Antarctic iceberg
summary2:
A big iceberg approaching the size of Greater London has broken away from the Antarctic, close to Britain's Halley research station. There is currently no-one in the base, so there is no risk to human life. This video shows the crack that produced the berg. It was filmed by a team from the British Antarctic Survey.
Read more: Big iceberg breaks from Antarctica near UK base

headline: Coronavirus: Another 24 hours in lockdown
summary: A group of 24 photographers record one hour each of life under restrictions imposed because of coronavirus.
headline2: Coronavirus: Another 24 hours in lockdown
summary2: Seventeen years ago, a group of 24 photographers set out to document every hour of New Year's Day, every year, for 24 years. But during these unprecedented times, members of the collective have come together again, this time turning their attention and lenses to the Covid-19 pandemic, to document 24 hours in lockdown. This is the second set of pictures from the collective.

headline: Prince Philip 'loved humour and teasing people'
summary: The former Archbishop of York, Dr John Sentamu, pays tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.
headline2: Prince Philip 'loved humour and teasing people' - Dr John Sentamu
summary2:
The former Archbishop of York, Dr John Sentamu, has paid tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh, who has died at the age of 99.
Dr Sentamu told Huw Edwards that he remembered the duke fondly, especially for his sense of humour.
He said Prince Philip "loved humour, and he loved teasing people, and he loved speaking his mind".
Read more: Duke of Edinburgh dies aged 99, palace says

headline: 'Covid killed my wife - so I'm testing a new vaccine'
summary: The death of Nigel Demaline's wife, Pauline, of Covid-19, prompted him to help test a new vaccine.
headline2: 'Covid killed my wife - so I'm taking part in a vaccine trial'
summary2: While one Covid vaccine has been approved for use in the UK and two are awaiting approval, many more are still being tested. The UK has pre-ordered 60 million doses of the Novavax vaccine, which is currently undergoing phase three trials. Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary talked to one man about the personal tragedy that prompted him to volunteer for the injection.

headline: Listen: Australian Open - Shapovalov v Sinner
summary: Follow 5 Live Sports Extra commentary of day one of the Australian Open in Melbourne.
headline2: Listen: Australian Open - Shapovalov v Sinner
summary2:
Australian Open day one at Melbourne Park
Click button at top of page to listen to 5 Live Sports Extra commentary
Now: Denis Shapovalov v Jannik Sinner
Defending champion Novak Djokovic beat Jeremy Chardy 6-3 6-1 6-2
Serena Williams, Naomi Osaka, Simona Halep, Dominic Thiem & Alexander Zverev win openers
Britain's Katie Boulter loses 6-1 6-4 to Daria Kasatkina in first round

headline: Taking the T-cell test: Did a choir have Covid in January?
summary: A Bradford choir that coughed in January gets the gold standard T-cell test - and is surprised by the result.
headline2: Coronavirus doctor's diary: So, did the Bradford choir have Covid-19 in January?
summary2: Many people would feel happier if they knew they had already had Covid-19, but the antibody tests designed to answer this question are not 100% reliable. Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary was therefore pleased when a local choir, which had Covid-like symptoms as early as January, got the opportunity to take a T-cell test, the gold standard for prior Covid infection.

headline: The art of protest in Myanmar – and its wanted list
summary: From blind-folded protests to dressing like Aung San Suu Kyi, artists are concerning Myanmar's military.
headline2: The art of protest in Myanmar – and its wanted list
summary2:
Protests and strikes have continued daily in Myanmar, despite a crackdown by the military.
Their latest target is famous actors and actresses who have come out to protest.
Young demonstrators are now turning to art and creative dissent to spread their message.
From blind-folded protests to dressing like Aung San Suu Kyi, this is why artists are concerning the country's army.

headline: Golden Globes winners - in two minutes
summary: The Crown reigned over the TV categories and Chadwick Boseman's widow accepted a posthumous prize.
headline2: Golden Globes 2021 winners - in two minutes
summary2:
This video has been removed for rights reasons.
Your round-up of who won what at the Golden Globe Awards on Sunday night.
Chadwick Boseman's widow accepted a posthumous prize for the actor and The Crown reigned over the TV categories.
Chloé Zhao was named best director - becoming only the second female winner of the category in Globes history, after Barbra Streisand in 1983.

headline: In pictures: Two Metres of Separation
summary: The winning images from a photographic competition run by Equal Lens.
headline2: Coronavirus: Two Metres of Separation
summary2: As the coronavirus spread across the country, many industries have suffered and continue to do so. One of those was the photographic sector, where photographers found themselves without assignments, so the team at Equal Lens, a non-profit organisation that promotes the work of women and non-binary photographers, launched an online competition called Two Metres of Separation.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - Hosts on top after first day in Sydney
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day one of the third Test between Australia and India in Sydney.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - Hosts on top after first day in Sydney
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
22-year-old opener Will Pucovski hits maiden Test fifty on debut
Australia close 166-2 - Labuschagne 67* & Smith 31*
Pucovski trapped lbw by fellow debutant Navdeep Saini for 62
Warner edges drive to first slip for five on return from injury
Day interrupted by rain in Sydney
Four-Test series level at 1-1

headline: How much does climate change cost US economy?
summary: Last year saw a record numbers of costly extreme weather events.
headline2: Climate Change: How much did it cost US economy in 2020?
summary2:
The year 2020 saw a record number of costly hurricanes, wildfires, and storms, resulting in billions of dollars in damages.
Since records began in 1980, billion-dollar climate disasters have become much more frequent, and in total have cost the US economy $1.875tn over those four decades, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Video by Joaquim Salles

headline: Life in a fox den captured by camera trap
summary: The fox and her pups are filmed playing in Northumberland.
headline2: Northumberland fox skulk captured by camera trap
summary2:
A photographer has used a camera trap to capture the life of a fox and her pups in Northumberland.
David Dinsley said he was out for an evening walk looking for local wildlife when he encountered the vixen and her pups.
The following he morning he returned to set up a camera trap and left the area.
He said he was "delighted" to have captured nearly 80 clips of life in the den.

headline: Domestic vaccine passports 'not in our planning'
summary: But the UK's vaccine minister says certificates will be provided if people need them for international travel.
headline2: Zahawi: Domestic vaccine passports 'not in our planning'
summary2:
The UK government is not planning the domestic use of vaccine passports, Minister for COVID Vaccine Deployment Nadhim Zahawi has said.
"We don't yet have the evidence of the effect of the vaccines on transmission, it's much better... that you look at rapid testing," he said.
The issuing of certificates will be facilitated if people need them for international travel, he added.

headline: Where are the UK-EU trade talks getting held up?
summary: Time is running short for the UK and EU to agree a new trade when the transition period ends on 31 December.
headline2: Brexit: What are problem issues in UK-EU trade talks?
summary2:
Time is running short for the UK and EU to agree a new trade when the transition period ends on 31 December.
BBC Reality Check’s Chris Morris looked at where the two sides are struggling to agree on their future relationship, including state aid and Northern Ireland issues.
The UK left the EU in January, but agreed to stay within rules and regulation until the end of this year.

headline: Expanding phone can grow and shrink on demand
summary: The concept phone has a flexible display that rolls up inside the device.
headline2: Oppo's expanding phone can grow and shrink on demand
summary2:
A smartphone with an expanding display that can grow and shrink on demand has been demonstrated by Chinese phone-maker Oppo.
The device has a flexible display that rolls up inside the device, letting the screen expand from 6.7in (17cm) to 7.4in (18.8cm).
BBC Click's Chris Fox went hands-on with the concept phone to see what it was like.
See more at Click's website and @BBCClick

headline: Myanmar coup: Woman shot in protests dies
summary: Mya Thwe Thwe Khaing was shot during a demonstration, two days before her 20th birthday.
headline2: Myanmar coup: Woman shot in protests dies
summary2:
The woman shot in the head last week during protests against Myanmar's military coup has died.
Mya Thwe Thwe Khaing was injured two days before her 20th birthday when police tried to disperse protesters.
The police have denied using lethal force at the rally in the capital Nay Pyi Taw on 9 February, but her wound was consistent with one from live ammunition, rights groups said.

headline: A man who tried to help Syria - and was crushed by disinfo
summary: James Le Mesurier fell to his death in Istanbul in 2019 with a sense that Syrian and Russian disinformation had destroyed his reputation.
headline2: Mayday: How the White Helmets and James Le Mesurier got pulled into a deadly battle for truth
summary2: The British man behind the Syrian civil defence group, the White Helmets, found himself at the centre of a battle to control the narrative of the Syrian war. Russian and Syrian propagandists accused his teams of faking evidence of atrocities - and convinced some in the West. The battle for truth formed a backdrop to James Le Mesurier's sudden death in Istanbul in November 2019.

headline: The hospital hit by a coronavirus 'tidal wave'
summary: Northwick Park Hospital was overwhelmed with Covid patients. How did staff cope with the onslaught?
headline2: Coronavirus: The London hospital hit by a 'tidal wave' of patients
summary2: As the UK stared down the barrel of a coronavirus epidemic in early March, the biggest fear was that hospitals would be swamped and incapacitated by a tsunami of patients. It happened in Wuhan and northern Italy. The NHS largely pulled through, but there were still times hospitals became overwhelmed. One of those was when a London hospital became suddenly engulfed with victims.

headline: Covid-19: My year on the frontline
summary: Around a third of doctors and nurses working throughout the pandemic at Ealing hospital are recently qualified and under 30 years old.
headline2: Covid-19: My year on the frontline
summary2:
About a third of nurses and junior doctors working at Ealing Hospital are under the age of 30.
Many of them have just started their careers but have spent an entire year on the frontline treating patients with coronavirus.
One of those young nurses is Fathma Shabbir, who was born in the hospital and is now fighting to save lives there.
Video by Gareth Furby and Thomas Mackintosh

headline: 'Leaving pub trade to become welder was good for me'
summary: Connor Lilley lost his job when the Covid-19 pandemic began but has found a new career path.
headline2: Covid-19: 'Lockdown job loss led me to welding career'
summary2:
Connor Lilley lost his job as a bar manager in Newcastle upon Tyne shortly after the Covid-19 pandemic began.
One year later, after relocating with his girlfriend to County Tyrone, he has taken up a new career as a welder.
He says it has been the right move for him and believes others in the position in which he found himself could benefit from switching to an entirely new role.

headline: False vaccine claims debunked
summary: Misleading claims about the coronavirus vaccines have been spreading online - BBC Reality Check breaks down why they are wrong.
headline2: Coronavirus: False vaccine claims debunked
summary2:
As coronavirus vaccines are distributed across the world, misleading claims about them are also spreading.
There are concerns that false information shared online is fuelling hesitancy among some people about taking the vaccine.
BBC Reality Check's Jack Goodman looks at five viral claims and explains why they're wrong.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Produced by Soraya Auer

headline: Meet the real Jill - the inspiration for It's A Sin
summary: Jill Nalder's life in 1980s London helped inspire Richard T Davies' Channel 4 show It's A Sin.
summary2:
In the 1980s, when Jill Nalder was studying in London, she noticed young men were leaving and not coming back.
They would go home and "sort of disappear." Her friends were dying, often in secret, of AIDS.
Her story is the inspiration behind hit TV show It's A Sin, penned by friend Russell T Davies.
Now when the Channel 4 programme is broadcast #bemorejill trends on the internet.

headline: 'I was pretty sure it was something from outer space'
summary: A property in Gloucestershire was hit by the most valuable space rock ever to fall on the UK.
headline2: Winchcombe meteorite: Cotswold town reacts to space rock discovery
summary2:
Imagine hearing a thud and then discovering outside your home the most valuable space rock ever to fall in the UK.
Well, that's what happened to Rob and Cathryn Wilcock, and their daughter Hannah.
They, and the other residents of Winchcombe in Gloucestershire, react to being at the centre of a major scientific discovery.
Read more: A fireball, a driveway and a priceless meteorite

headline: Alone on an abandoned cargo ship
summary: Seafarer Mohammed Aisha has been living on an abandoned cargo ship for four years, part of that time completely on his own.
summary2:
For the past four years, Mohammed Aisha has been living on an abandoned cargo ship. In recent months, he's been completely alone.
The number of abandoned crews is on the rise, according to Lloyd's List, leaving seafarers in precarious situations.
The BBC’s Paul Adams has been in touch with Mohammed for weeks, learning about his isolated, off-shore life.
Video by Olivia Lace-Evans

headline: Retailers aiming to reduce plastic on Scotland's isles
summary: A new scheme aims to help reduce single-use plastic in shops on Scotland's islands.
headline2: Retailers aiming to reduce plastic on Scotland's isles
summary2:
Outlets on 12 Scottish islands are preparing to offer shoppers a more sustainable retail experience.
The scheme aims to reduce the amount of single-use plastic being transported to and from the islands.
Refillable and reusable containers will be introduced for goods such as milk, dried foods and toiletries.
Organisers say it will be beneficial for the economy and the environment.

headline: Chancellor: '£4.6 billion of additional business help'
summary: The Chancellor has announced further economic help following the government's national lockdown decision.
headline2: Rishi Sunak: '£4.6 billion of additional business help'
summary2:
Chancellor Rishi Sunak has set out £4.6 billion to help businesses as a result of the new national lockdown which was announced by the prime minister on Monday.
Mr Sunak also defended the government's thinking about closing schools, adding that it would save more lives.
The toughest coronavirus restrictions since the original lockdown in March are now in place across the country.

headline: Abbott for UK Board of Trade 'such a bad idea'
summary: Appointing former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott as a UK trade representative would be "awful" says a Conservative MP.
headline2: Caroline Nokes on Tony Abbott joining UK Board of Trade
summary2:
Appointing former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott as a UK trade representative would be "awful" a Conservative MP has said.
Caroline Nokes, who chairs Parliament's Women and Equalities Committee, told BBC2’s Politics Live said he was a "misogynist" with “poor” views on LGBTQ rights.
She added: “I just don't think this is a man who should be anywhere near our board of trade."

headline: 'Touchdown confirmed': Nasa rover lands on Mars
summary: There are celebrations as Perseverance completes its seven-month journey to the Red Planet.
headline2: Nasa Mars landing: Celebrations as Perseverance rover touchdown is confirmed
summary2:
The Nasa rover, Perseverance, has successfully landed on the surface of Mars, seven months after leaving Earth.
Its landing, on the Jezero Crater, means work can now begin on searching for evidence of ancient life on the Red Planet.
To do this, the robot will drill and collect samples of rock and soil for analysis at a later date.
Read more: Nasa's Perseverance rover lands on Mars

headline: One year of lockdowns across the UK
summary: It's a year to the day since the first UK-wide coronavirus lockdown was announced.
headline2: Covid-19: One year of lockdowns across the UK
summary2:
It's officially one year since Boris Johnson announced the first UK-wide coronavirus lockdown on 23 March 2020.
Since the first one was announced 12 months ago, we've had two further national lockdowns, and more than 120,000 people have died after testing positive for Covid-19.
We look back at some of the key dates and how restrictions became our new normal.
Produced by Nick Raikes

headline: Life under Antarctic ice 'shouldn't be there'
summary: Researchers hoping to collect mud samples deep beneath an Antarctic ice sheet were amazed to discover small creatures living in the dark, freezing water.
headline2: Life discovered deep beneath an Antarctic ice sheet 'shouldn't be there'
summary2:
Researchers hoping to collect mud samples from deep under an Antarctic ice shelf were amazed to find small creatures living in the dark, freezing water.
Experts from the British Antarctic Survey say the discovery of filter-feeding animals clinging to a rock was unexpected, because of the lack of food and sunlight.
Video produced by Trystan Young.
Listen to more stories on Newshour.

headline: Rescue efforts after Taiwan train derailment
summary: Watch: Rescue efforts are ongoing after the train derailment
headline2: Taiwan: Rescue efforts after train derailment
summary2:
Rescue efforts are ongoing after a train derailment in Taiwan killed dozens of people.
Up to 200 passengers remain trapped, with rescuers in Hualien County trying to access several badly damaged carriages inside the tunnel.
Local media say the eight-carriage train hit a construction vehicle that had slipped onto the tracks.
Read more: Dozens killed as train crashes in Taiwan tunnel

headline: Mother and son become tap-dancing lockdown stars
headline2: Mother and son become tap-dance lockdown sensation
summary2:
When the pandemic hit, choreographer and dance teacher Lizzi Gee found herself out of work.
In order to stay positive and keep busy, the mum-of-two from south London decided to use her new-found spare time to teach her son Rufus to tap dance.
Now the eight-year-old has become a dancing sensation. Their mother and son routines attract millions of hits online.
Video by Claire Brennan

headline: Why US is expecting an 'avalanche' of evictions
summary: As businesses reopen across the US, so are eviction courts with millions of lives being upturned.
headline2: Coronavirus: Why US is expecting an 'avalanche' of evictions
summary2: As hair salons, churches and restaurants reopened across the US, so did eviction courts. A federal moratorium on evictions has now expired and the politicians are not close to a deal on a new economic rescue package. Advocates and experts warn that an unprecedented crush of evictions is coming, threatening millions of Americans with homelessness as the pandemic continues to spread.

headline: 'Why I’m not alone in missing hugs during the pandemic'
summary: What does touch mean to us and how has the need for touch changed because of Covid-19?
headline2: 'Why I’m not alone in missing hugs during the pandemic'
summary2: When was the last time you felt the comforting touch of a loved one? Positive attitudes towards touch are linked with greater well-being and lower levels of loneliness, according to a new global study called The Touch Test, which took place mostly before the UK was in lockdown. Claudia Hammond looks at the results and asks how our need for touch has changed because of the pandemic.

headline: 'Since I had Covid, food makes me want to vomit'
summary: Many are finding things do not smell right after Covid - and that most foods smell and taste disgusting.
headline2: Parosmia: 'Since I had Covid, food makes me want to vomit'
summary2: Many people with Covid-19 temporarily lose their sense of smell. As they recover, it usually returns - but some are finding that things smell different, and things that should smell nice, such as food, soap, and their loved ones, smell repulsive. The numbers with this condition, known as parosmia, are constantly growing, but scientists are not sure why it happens, or how to cure it.

headline: Seaglass enthusiasts increased over lockdown
summary: We take a look at why Seaham seaglass is as popular and world-renowned.
headline2: Seaham seaglass collectors say lockdown "diminished" stock
summary2:
Seaglass collectors in County Durham say lockdown visitors have "diminished" the local stock.
Searching for the keepsakes at Seaham beach is a popular hobby for tourists, as the seaglass dates back to the 1800s and comes in various shapes and colours.
Senior lecturer in architectural glass at Sunderland University Cate Watkinson explains why the small pieces of glass are so special.

headline: From the 'world's worst sniffer dog' to NHS hero
headline2: How the 'world's worst sniffer dog' is helping the NHS
summary2:
Meet Dexter who was sacked from his drug sniffer job because he was "too sociable".
He used to be part of the Metropolitan Police's anti-drug squad but after failing their training programme they found him a new role as a "wellbeing dog".
Now, he helps officers relax following tough assignments and has been visiting hospitals to offer NHS staff a wellbeing break during the pandemic.

headline: 'I feel like I've regained six years of my life'
summary: Jody Lewis is one of about 80 people from Wales to have tried “revolutionary” drug Kaftrio.
headline2: Cystic fibrosis: 'I feel like I've regained six years of my life'
summary2:
Cystic fibrosis patient Jody Lewis said the effect of new treatment she is using has been like "regaining six years".
The 31-year-old is one of 80 people in Wales to have tried “revolutionary” drug Kaftrio.
It’s suitable for about 90% of patients over 12 and has been approved for UK use.
Jody, from Pen-y-Lan, near Wrexham, said: “Maybe I should start making plans for the future now.”

headline: The brain op described as ‘easier than curing a toothache’
summary: Tens of thousands of lobotomies were carried out in the UK and US in the 1940s and 50s. Should we condemn the surgeons?
headline2: Lobotomy: The brain op described as ‘easier than curing a toothache’
summary2: There was a time when people with severe mental illness might be given an operation to sever connections in the brain. Lobotomy became one of the most notorious surgical procedures of the 20th Century, writes Claire Prentice, but retired neurosurgeon, Henry Marsh, who once carried out a modified version of the operation, tells her it's wrong to divide doctors into heroes and villains.

headline: What impact has Covid had on global climate?
summary: Lockdowns around the world resulted in record drops of CO2, a greenhouse gas responsible for climate change. But is this change long lasting?
headline2: Coronavirus: What has Covid done for climate crisis?
summary2:
When Covid-19 sparked lockdowns around the world, emissions of one of the greenhouse gases responsible for climate change, atmospheric carbon dioxide, plummeted. But is this record drop a short-term effect of the 2020 pandemic or a 'new normal'? BBC Weather's Ben Rich explores the impact of coronavirus on the global climate.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Produced by Soraya Auer

headline: Asian massage worker: 'How can we not be scared?'
summary: Asian female massage workers in the US speak up about the stigma surrounding their profession and the sexual harassment they endure.
headline2: Inside the lives of Asian massage workers: 'How can we not be scared?'
summary2:
The Atlanta spa shootings have placed a spotlight on a part of the massage industry in the US. Asian massage workers say they often have to deal with the assumption that Asian spas provide sex services.
Two female Asian massage workers tell us about the stigma surrounding their profession and the sexual harassment they endure.
Reporting by Zhaoyin Feng
Filming and Editing by Xinyan Yu

headline: Why a famous Australian beach is disappearing
summary: Byron Bay's beach is eroding away, so how is the headland is to blame?
headline2: Byron Bay: Why a famous Australian beach is disappearing
summary2:
Byron Bay on the New South Wales north coast is a surfing and tourism hotspot.
But for the past six months its most popular attraction, Main Beach, has been steadily eroding.
Professor Rodger Tomlinson from the Griffith Centre for Coastal Management, explained to the BBC how his team had identified the cause of the erosion: a process called "headland bypassing".
Video by Isabelle Rodd

headline: 'This was a whirlwind and it's not a particularly good experience'
summary: Two journalists from different organisations left due to diplomatic tensions, Australian media report.
headline2: Australian reporters arrive home from China after 'standoff'
summary2:
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Bill Birtles has spoken to reporters in Sydney, calling his "whirlwind" departure from China "not a particularly good experience".
He was one of two Australian reporters removed from China over what local media say is a diplomatic standoff.
The other journalist is the Australian Financial Review's Mike Smith, who also reached Sydney on Tuesday.

headline: Coronavirus: The babies and children in Brazil's Covid ICU
summary: Looking after the babies and children in Brazil's Covid ICU
headline2: Coronavirus: The babies and children in Brazil's Covid ICU
summary2: As Brazil's coronavirus epidemic races out of control, the disease is killing not just adults, but babies and children. Since the beginning of the pandemic, 1,300 babies under the age of one have died from the virus. With exclusive access to one children’s ICU in the northeast of the country, BBC Brazil’s Nathalia Passarinho speaks to staff about caring for these critically ill children.

headline: Balmoral locals remember the Duke of Edinburgh
summary: Tributes have been paid in Scotland to the Duke of Edinburgh following his death at the age of 99.
headline2: Prince Philip: Ballater locals remember the Duke of Edinburgh
summary2:
Locals in Ballater, near Balmoral Castle, have been reacting to the news of the Duke of Edinburgh's death.
Prince Philip has died aged 99, Buckingham Palace has announced.
The duke and the Queen were regular visitors to the Balmoral estate in Royal Deeside for many decades, and people who lived nearby have shared their memories - including one couple who met the duke while out on a walk.

headline: 'My mother's fertility doctor is my father'
summary: When a DNA test revealed a decades-old family secret, Maia’s life was turned upside down.
headline2: 'My mother's fertility doctor is my father'
summary2:
When a DNA test revealed a decades-old family secret, Maia’s life was turned upside down. What she learned next was even more disturbing.
Maia and her sister now believe a fertility doctor used his own sperm to artificially inseminate their mother - and he may be the biological father to many others. This is how her family's life has changed since the discovery.
Video by Angélica M Casas

headline: The 'LitterCam' that's watching you
summary: AI software can now match footage of motorists throwing rubbish with their car's number plate and issue an automatic fine.
headline2: The 'LitterCam' that's watching you
summary2:
CCTV cameras will soon have a new target - litter louts.
AI software can now match footage of motorists throwing rubbish to their car's number plate and issue an automatic fine of £90.
The first trial of the potentially controversial new system will begin in Maidstone in Kent in a few weeks with other councils expected to follow.
Our chief environment correspondent Justin Rowlatt reports.

headline: Long-distance love story couple united at last
summary: Andrew Monck has flown from Australia to join Rosanna Wilson in her Devon town.
headline2: Covid: Long-distance love story couple united at last
summary2:
A man has moved across the world to be with a woman he first met 10 years ago, but only really got to know online during the coronavirus pandemic.
Andrew Monck from Sydney, Australia, flew to the UK and has moved to Torquay, Devon, to live with Rosanna Wilson.
He was granted an exemption to leave Australia permanently, and so travelled more than 9,300 miles (15,000km) in the name of love.

headline: Paraglider pilot plunged 200ft into tree
summary: A paraglider pilot suffered head, leg and pelvic injuries after falling 200ft (60m) and becoming trapped in a tree.
headline2: Powys crash paraglider plunged 200ft into tree
summary2:
A paraglider pilot suffered head, leg and pelvic injuries when he plunged 200ft (60m) and became trapped in a tree.
He was airlifted to hospital after crashing at Hundred House near Llandrindod Wells in Powys.
Firefighters, paramedics and mountain rescue teams were called to the scene on Sunday at about 14:00 BST.
The pilot was taken to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for treatment.

headline: Are Britain's bosses up to the job?
summary: The shortcomings of managers are being targeted as part of the Covid recovery.
headline2: Are Britain's bosses up to the job?
summary2:
The shortcomings of British managers are being targeted in the Budget and also by a senior adviser to the Scottish government.
There is a push to get them learning about business skills they lack, and to understand better how to use technology.
Brexit has lowered expectations of the boost to productivity from inward investment, so there's a need for home-grown business to learn for itself.

headline: Impostor syndrome: 'I don't deserve my success'
summary: An influencer and a corporate professional from India share their experiences of impostor syndrome.
headline2: Impostor syndrome: 'I feel like I don't deserve my success'
summary2:
What's it like to live with the feeling that despite your achievements you're not enough? How do you cope with the voice in your head that keeps holding you back?
A social media influencer and a corporate professional share their stories of overcoming impostor syndrome in India, a country where it is often seen as "taboo" to seek help.
Video by Medhavi Arora, Shaad Midhat and Saraskanth TK

headline: Pharmacist says get vaccinated despite brother's death
summary: Alison Astles encourages vaccine uptake despite brother's death from blood clot, saying he was "extraordinarily unlucky."
headline2: Pharmacist says get vaccinated despite brother's death
summary2:
A pharmacist whose brother died after having the AstraZeneca vaccine has told the BBC she still feels strongly that people should continue have their jabs.
Alison Astles' brother Neil, 59, died of a blood clot on the brain on Sunday, after having the vaccination on 17 March.
She said he was "extraordinarily unlucky" and that "more lives will be saved by people having the vaccine than not."

headline: Polarstern research ship investigates mega-iceberg
summary: The German science vessel studies Antarctic seafloor life uncovered by the calving of a big iceberg.
headline2: Polarstern research ship investigates mega-iceberg
summary2:
When the giant iceberg A74 calved from Antarctica's Brunt Ice Shelf, it exposed seafloor that had been covered over for five decades. The German research vessel Polarstern managed to get between the berg and the ice shelf to image the animals living on the seabed. This drone footage shows Polarstern in the narrow gap between A74 and the Brunt.
Image courtesy of the Alfred Wegener Institute

headline: Stocks explained: What's going on with GameStop?
summary: Chris Fox explains stocks, short-selling and what has been happening with GameStop shares.
headline2: Stocks explained: What's going on with GameStop?
summary2:
There has been a lot of interest in the stock market this week after investors from the Reddit message board managed to give shares in GameStop a huge boost.
Here's a look back at the story so far, with an explanation of stocks, short-selling and what has been happening with GameStop.
Video journalists: Chris Fox and Fahima Abdulrahman
Read more: GameStop: What is it and why is it trending?

headline: 'He understood us' - NI tributes to Prince Philip
summary: Politicians and public figures from NI pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.
headline2: Prince Philip: Tributes paid by NI politicans and public figures
summary2:
Politicians and public figures from across Northern Ireland have paid tribute to Prince Philip.
First Minister Arlene Foster said he had a "profound and positive impact" on thousands of young people from Northern Ireland.
Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill offered her condolences to the Royal Family saying that while they may be public figures, "they are also a family that are hurting".

headline: A change of view for David Bailey
summary: Iconic photographer David Bailey is all about 'thinking outside the box' for a new exhibition of his 'unseen' oil paintings
headline2: David Bailey creates his own street art with new exhibition of paintings
summary2:
He was the face of swinging London and created some of the most iconic images of the sixties.
Now 82, David Bailey's work is returning to London on a massive scale.
David Bailey Unseen is a new exhibition of his paintings, which will share space amongst the clothes of Flannels, an Oxford Street shop, as well as being superimposed across the building.
The BBC's Alex Stanger went to meet him.

headline: Teen discovers badger watching during pandemic
summary: Thomas is 14 and loves to watch badgers, it's a hobby he picked up at the start of the pandemic.
headline2: Badger-watching teen shares love for new hobby during pandemic
summary2:
When the pandemic hit last year, Thomas wanted to find a way to get outdoors and learn more about wildlife.
Fast forward a year and the 14-year-old from Hampshire has discovered a love for watching badgers.
Thomas observes the animals at his local woodland and has written a self-published book about his discoveries.
Now he wants to share his love of wildlife with others.
Video by Simon Marks

headline: Prisoner served 10 years for street phone theft
summary: Martin Tawton was given an imprisonment for public protection sentence, which have no fixed term.
headline2: How one man spent 10 years behind bars for stealing a mobile phone
summary2:
Martin Tawton was jailed for a minimum of three-and-a-half years for stealing a mobile phone.
He was handed an imprisonment for public protection sentence - or IPP.
Unlike other sentences, IPPs have no fixed term, so prisoners have no idea when they will be freed.
The offender, from Cardiff, eventually served 10 years and has been recalled to jail three times.
IPP sentences are now scrapped.

headline: Furlough fraud: Whistleblower describes 'impossible situation'
summary: The Government’s hotline for furlough fraud has received more than 20,000 tips since it was set up.
headline2: Furlough fraud: 'Impossible situation' of breaking the law or being sacked
summary2:
The Government’s hotline for furlough fraud has received more than 20,000 tips since it was set up.
The scheme has paid the wages of more than 9m workers at a cost of £46 billion.
Now a committee of MPs has called for the names of all firms getting the money to be published as a way of rooting out fraud.
'John' (not his real name) was asked to work while on furlough and refused, he was sacked.

headline: Why are so many babies dying of Covid-19 in Brazil?
summary: As the pandemic rages in Brazil, hundreds of babies and young children are dying of Covid.
headline2: Why are so many babies dying of Covid-19 in Brazil?
summary2: More than a year into the pandemic, deaths in Brazil are now at their peak. But despite the overwhelming evidence that Covid-19 rarely kills young children, in Brazil 1,300 babies have died from the virus. One doctor refused to test Jessika Ricarte's one-year-old son for Covid, saying his symptoms did not fit the profile of the virus. Two months later he died of complications from the disease.

headline: ‘How are you out of ten?’
summary: The BBC's Laura Foster gets tips from those working in the profession.
headline2: Coronavirus: How to help health workers' mental health
summary2:
The coronavirus pandemic has had an impact on everyone's mental wellbeing but those on the front line of dealing with it have suffered more than most.
BBC Health reporter Laura Foster talks to three doctors from the mental health charity 'You Okay, Doc?' for their tips on how you can help support health and care workers with their mental health and well-being.
Video by Laura Foster and Mel Lou

headline: Journalist's 'whirlwind week' after China 'standoff'
summary: Bill Birtles shared his experience after Chinese authorities banned him from leaving the country.
headline2: Australian journalist's 'whirlwind week' after China 'standoff'
summary2:
Bill Birtles was one of two Australian reporters removed from China over what local media say is a diplomatic standoff.
The other journalist is the Australian Financial Review's Mike Smith, who also reached Sydney on Tuesday.
Chinese authorities questioned both men before their departure.
Bill Birtles, who works for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, spoke to the BBC about his experience.

headline: Colourful choices: Peru's presidential candidates
summary: Eighteen presidential candidates are trying to convince Peruvians tired of politics to vote for them.
headline2: From 'Porky' to goalie: Peru's presidential candidates
summary2: Peru's presidential contenders are nothing if not colourful. A former goalkeeper with the national football team; an ultra-conservative Catholic businessman nicknamed "Porky" after a Looney Tunes character; a populist with an anti-corruption message; and a veteran presidential contender whose father is a disgraced former head of state are among the 18 people running for the top job on 11 April.

headline: Ed Accura: Tackling myths around race and swimming
summary: Parents need to understand the importance of their children learning to swim, the film-maker says.
headline2: Ed Accura: I want to tackle myths around race and swimming
summary2:
Film-maker Ed Accura's second film, Blacks Can't Swim: The Sequel looks at the issues of racial stereotypes and barriers to swimming.
Figures from 2020 show that 95% percent of black adults and 80% of black children in England do not swim.
He tells BBC World News why he made the film and what he wants to achieve.
Blacks Can't Swim: The Sequel will be released as a digital download on 10 May 2021.

headline: 'A picture can kill you or save your life'
summary: For years Abood Hamam sent war photos out of Syria anonymously. Now he's using his name, and urging exiles to return.
headline2: Abood Hamam: 'A picture can kill you or save your life'
summary2: For years Abood Hamam chronicled the war in Syria for news outlets all over the world without ever revealing his name - and despite being employed by different warring parties. He began as photographer to the presidential couple - Bashar and Asma al-Assad. Later he filmed Islamic State's victory parade. Now, finally, he's broken cover, to encourage exiles to return to his beloved hometown, Raqqa.

headline: Actors 'jaded' by Covid pandemic experience
summary: Actor Jennifer Ruth Adams was "so panicked" when work was cancelled as coronavirus took hold.
headline2: Covid: Actors left 'jaded' by pandemic experience
summary2:
After a challenging year, TV and film professionals are wondering what lies ahead.
Actor Jennifer Ruth Adams said she was "panicking like mad" when work was cancelled as Covid-19 took hold last April.
She and boyfriend Oliver Morgan-Thomas, also an actor, said the following months were "extremely difficult".
“I know lots of actors that have become quite jaded by this whole experience,” said Ruth.

headline: Listen: State of Origin - Queensland v New South Wales
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary of Queensland v New South Wales in the first State of Origin match.
headline2: Listen: State of Origin - Queensland v New South Wales
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
FT: Queensland 18-14 New South Wales
First game of the 2020 series
The State of Origin series is an annual best-of-three rugby league series between two Australian state representative sides
Former England coach Wayne Bennett in charge of Queensland
NSW won the 2019 series after James Tedesco's final-minute try in game three

headline: Almost 100 and still dancing
summary: Dinkie Flowers ran her own dance school until last year's lockdown.
headline2: Almost 100 and still dancing
summary2:
A dancer who is on the verge of turning 100 is putting her skills to use to raise money for NHS charities.
Dinkie Flowers, from Shoreham, West Sussex, ran her own dance school right up until last year's lockdown. Now she is fundraising by taking part in workout sessions three times a week.
The dancer, who has performed "all over the world", thinks it is important "not to sit on your bum all day".

headline: NI walkers urged to stick to mountain paths
summary: Path creep, where walkers leave the trail, has caused extensive damage at popular beauty spots.
headline2: Northern Ireland walkers urged to stick to mountain paths
summary2:
People have been urged to stick to paths at popular NI beauty spots to stop damage to the trails.
The National Trust said more than 200,000 people had visited Divis and Black Mountain in 2020.
It has spent £60,000 repairing a small portion of the route which had been damaged by "path creep".
Path creep is when visitors leave the trail, causing erosion and harming the mountain's delicate ecosystem.

headline: Listen: Australia v India - Tourists lose both openers in reply to 338
summary: Listen to ABC Grandstand commentary from day two of the third Test between Australia and India in Sydney.
headline2: Listen: Australia v India - Tourists lose both openers in reply to 338
summary2:
Use audio icon at top of the page to listen to ABC Grandstand commentary
Rohit c & b Hazlewood for 26 after 70-run opening stand
Gill (50) caught at gully after making maiden Test fifty
India replying to Australia's 338
Smith scores 131 from 226 - his first hundred for 16 months
Labuschagne makes 91 but hosts lose last seven wickets for 106
Four-Test series level at 1-1
Third Test, day two, Sydney

headline: Japan lights Olympic torch
summary: It was all supposed to happen in 2020, but Japan has finally kicked off its Olympic torch relay.
headline2: Japan lights Olympic torch after one-year Covid delay
summary2:
A year later than expected, Japan has finally kicked off its Olympic torch relay.
Athletes will now carry the flame across all of the country to arrive in Tokyo for the opening ceremony on 23 July.
The global pandemic forced the Games to be postponed from last year to this, and the torch relay had to go under way without any fans cheering at the sides.
This video has been removed for rights reasons

headline: Perseverance rover goes for a short drive
summary: The one-tonne robot wiggles its wheels before rolling forwards across Jezero Crater's dusty terrain.
headline2: Perseverance rover goes for a short drive
summary2:
The US space agency's Perseverance rover has wiggled its wheels and undertaken its first Martian drive. It didn't move far - just 6.5m (21ft) in total, but Nasa's deputy project scientist Katie Stack Morgan said it was a significant moment. The four images in this sequence show the end part of the drive, as the rover reverses a short way.
Read more: Perseverance rover begins its exploration of Mars

headline: The rise of Turkish investment in Rwanda
summary: Rwanda has seen a rise in direct investment from Turkish firms over the last decade.
headline2: The rise of Turkish investment in Rwanda
summary2:
Rwanda is ranked by the World Bank as being the second easiest country in Africa to do business.
The UK, Portugal, India and the UAE are Rwanda's main investors, but Turkey is now starting to drive more investment into the country.
In the last decade, Turkish firms have invested $400m (£293m) into Rwanda's industries.
You can tune into In Business Africa every Friday at 18:30 GMT on BBC World News.

headline: Racing to screen the ‘fake heiress’ story
summary: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.
headline2: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
summary2: It was an elaborate, truth-is-stranger-than-fiction scam that went on for years under the radar, but when word finally got out that a young woman had been conning people in New York by faking it as a millionaire heiress, social media went wild. Now that Anna Sorokin - aka Anna Delvey - has served her time in prison, here is the story of Netflix's race to tell the tale and her life on the other side.

headline: A 'safe space' for female and non-binary artists
headline2: Ladies of rage: 'Safe space' for female and non-binary artists
summary2:
The Ladies of Rage music collective began in Cardiff and now has 400 members across Wales.
Its aim was to provide a "safe space" for female and non-binary artists in the industry.
Focusing mainly on urban and Mobo (music of black origin) genres, it encourages greater racial and gender diversity.
During the pandemic, the group's members have supported each other with online gigs, playlists and chats.

headline: Covid-19: The disinformation tactics used by China
summary: A look at events that have shaped Beijing’s experiment with global misinformation since the virus was first detected in Wuhan.
headline2: Covid-19: The disinformation tactics used by China
summary2:
China’s response to the Covid-19 outbreak has been scrutinised since the virus was first detected in Wuhan.
In response, Beijing has tried to take greater control of what is said about its role in the pandemic - sometimes with questionable tactics.
Radio 4 and BBC Monitoring’s Krassi Twigg look at events that have shaped Beijing’s experiment with global misinformation.
Video produced by Suniti Singh

headline: 'I live in constant fear for my children'
summary: More than half the children locked up in Australia are indigenous, despite making up only 3% of the population.
headline2: Calls to change justice system 'stacked against' indigenous Australians
summary2:
Successive governments have struggled to narrow the chasm between indigenous and non-indigenous people in Australia.
The gap has been called a national shame – and nowhere is it more pronounced than in youth detention.
More than half the children locked up are indigenous – despite Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people making up only 3% of the population.
Produced and edited by Simon Atkinson.

headline: Who gets the Covid vaccine after the over 50s?
summary: After phase one is complete by mid-April, in what order will all other adults get the jab?
summary2:
All over 50, as well as front-line health and care workers, and those with certain underlying health conditions, have been offered their first dose of the Covid vaccine by mid-April.
Each of the vaccines has been rigorously tested and determined to be safe by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.
Health correspondent Laura Foster explains where you are in the order.
Graphics by Mel Lou

headline: From Sea Shanty TikTok to a record deal
summary: Scottish postie Nathan Evans has quit his job and signed to a record label after storming TikTok with sea shanties.
headline2: From Sea Shanty TikTok to a record deal
summary2:
Scottish postie Nathan Evans has quit his job and signed to a record label after storming TikTok with sea shanties.
Nathan said the singalong craze for his The Wellerman rendition exploded in just a matter of weeks.
And Friday sees an official release of the shanty, after he was picked up by Polydor records.
The 26-year-old from Airdrie said it goes to show that if you keep going anything can happen.

headline: Volcano blankets island in layer of grey
summary: La Soufriere, on the island of St Vincent, has been erupting for the past five days.
headline2: St Vincent volcano: Island covered in layer of grey as La Soufriere erupts
summary2:
The Caribbean island of Saint Vincent has been coated in a layer of grey, caused by ash from the volcano La Soufriere mixing with rain.
Before it started erupting on Friday, La Soufriere had been inactive for decades.
Tens of thousands of people have fled their homes, but efforts to shelter them from the eruption have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. There have been no reported injuries.

headline: Queen’s Gambit: 'It's old-fashioned storytelling'
summary: Series producer Allan Scott explains how Netflix’s format allowed the story to be a success.
headline2: Queen’s Gambit: 'It’s like old-fashioned storytelling'
summary2:
Netflix hit Queen’s Gambit has been a success because of the way the platform allows you to tell a story in much more detail over six or seven episodes, the series producer Allan Scott has said.
Speaking to BBC World News he said it took him 30 years to get it onto the screen, with earlier film studios feeling that chess did not sell.
The chess drama has been nominated in two Golden Globe categories.

headline: A look back at Prince Philip's legacy in Wales
summary: His Royal Highness Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, has died at the age of 99.
headline2: Prince Philip: A look back at the Duke of Edinburgh's legacy in Wales
summary2:
When his Royal Highness Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, married Princess Elizabeth - the future Queen - he was given the title Earl of Merioneth.
He was made chancellor of the University of Wales in 1949 and also visited Aberfan after the 1966 mining disaster.
BBC Wales takes a look back at the role the duke has played in Welsh history, as the news of his death is announced by Buckingham Palace.

headline: Privacy Notice: Disability and Covid: The Hidden Impact
summary: Details of the BBC's privacy notice for the survey Covid: The Hidden Impact.
headline2: Privacy Notice: Disability and Covid: The Hidden Impact
summary2: The BBC is carrying out a survey to understand how Covid-19 has affected disabled people. We are trying to reach as many people as possible to get the biggest, most detailed picture we can. We know that Covid-19 has had such a disproportionate effect on disabled people. The survey is completely anonymous but if you want to share your experiences please see below to understand how we process your data.

headline: Why cutting down trees can be good for the climate
summary: Tree felling is helping to restore an ancient ecosystem which can store even more carbon than trees do.
headline2: Why cutting down trees can be good for the climate
summary2:
A massive tree felling operation has been going on in the vast Kielder Forest of Northumberland for the last few weeks.
Thousands of trees have been cut down as part of a project that claims to be improving the environment and tackling climate change.
The BBC's chief environment correspondent Justin Rowlatt reports on work to restore an ancient ecosystem which can store far more carbon than trees can.

headline: Astroscale to showcase space debris removal
summary: The international company will fly a demonstration of the technology it hopes can help clean up space.
headline2: Astroscale to showcase space debris removal
summary2:
The Astroscale company is about to fly a demonstration of the technology it hopes can help clean up space.
Two satellites will showcase how a future service could capture redundant hardware and bring it out of orbit.
This video illustrates a "servicer" spacecraft tracking and grabbing a "client" object, even when it is tumbling.
Courtesy of Astroscale
Read more: Space debris removal demo set for launch

headline: 'I held my pregnancy bump to keep it from stabber'
summary: Natalie Queiroz recalls her partner's attack five years ago in which her unborn child was feared dead.
headline2: Sutton Coldfield mum recalls being pregnant and stabbed
summary2: On 3 March 2016, Natalie Queiroz shared a picture on social media of her rapidly growing baby bump. She was eight months pregnant and looking forward to the birth of her daughter and life with partner Babur "Bobby" Raja. Twenty-four hours later she was being flown by air ambulance to hospital. She had been stabbed more than 20 times, and paramedics feared for the lives of both her and her unborn child.

headline: 'Can you help me?': Boy found alone at the border
summary: A 10-year-old from Nicaragua woke up to find he had been abandoned by his group.
headline2: 'Can you help me?': Boy in tears found alone at US-Mexico border
summary2:
The 10-year-old boy from Nicaragua had woken up to find he had been abandoned by his group.
He was travelling without his family and was taken to a Customs and Border Patrol facility.
Migrant detention centres are over capacity as US authorities struggle keep up with a rise in unaccompanied minors crossing the southern border. Over 18,500 children crossed the border in March, shattering previous records.

headline: Should I buy an electric car?
headline2: Electric Cars: Is it time to buy one?
summary2:
Electric cars are increasingly taking to our roads but many people still have reservations. Common worries include the price of the vehicles, where you can charge, charging times and the wider environmental costs of manufacturing them.
Reality Check looks at how valid these concerns are.
Motion graphics by Jacqueline Galvin
Presented by Ben Butcher
Research by Lora Jones
Edited and produced by Nadeem Shad

headline: How to photograph wildlife in your back garden
summary: BBC cameraman Shaun Whitmore shares his top tips for getting great shots without leaving your house.
headline2: Coronavirus: Top tips on how to photograph wildlife in self-isolation
summary2:
You don't need to head out into the countryside to photograph wildlife, says BBC cameraman Shaun Whitmore.
He has shared his top tips for getting some fantastic shots without leaving your house which include being patient, practising and enjoying it.
"I only have a small garden... but it still attracts a good variety of birds," said Mr Whitmore.
"Watching nature is meant to be relaxing and fun," he added.

headline: AZ vaccine risks 'more finely balanced' in under-30s
summary: The MHRA says side effects should be taken in to account when offering the vaccine to younger people.
headline2: Covid-19: Risks should be 'taken into account' when offering younger people AZ vaccine
summary2:
The UK's medicines regulator says that the risks and benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine are "more finely balanced" in younger people, and should be taken into account when offering them the jab.
Chief Executive of the MHRA Dr June Raine added that the risk of blood clots "remains extremely small".
As a result, under-30s in the UK are to be offered an alternative coronavirus vaccine, if they would prefer.

headline: Mauritanian star Tahar Rahim on his Bafta nomination
summary: Tahar Rahim has been nominated for his part in The Mauritanian.
headline2: Baftas 2021: The Mauritanian star Tahar Rahim on 'reassuring' nomination
summary2:
This year’s Baftas are being called the most diverse ever, with two-thirds of the nominees for acting awards coming from minority backgrounds.
Among those is French actor Tahar Rahim, who is up for best leading actor for his role in The Mauritanian.
Rahim will be familiar to many for his leading part in TV drama The Serpent.
He spoke to the BBC's Sophie van Brugen about getting recognition for both roles.

headline: How this Mars landing will be different to before
summary: Nasa’s Perseverance rover is preparing to land in the Jezero crater, an area considered “too dangerous” for previous spacecraft. New technology will help it avoid hazards.
headline2: Nasa Perseverance rover: How this Mars landing will be different
summary2:
Nasa's Perseverance rover is attempting to land on Mars on 18 February 2021.
Katie Stack Morgan, the mission's deputy project scientist, explains how the spacecraft will navigate hazards in Jezero Crater, an area considered "too dangerous" for previous rovers.
Video by Jennifer Green, interview by Roland Pease and Deborah Cohen.
For more on the Mars landing, listen to Science in Action on BBC World Service.

headline: Robert Downey Jr: Planet faces existential crisis
summary: The Hollywood star says his role as Iron Man led him to think about climate change.
headline2: Robert Downey Jr: Planet faces existential crisis
summary2:
Hollywood star Robert Downey Jr is leading an investment fund that will try to spot fast-growing green technology businesses to help tackle climate change.
The Footprint Coalition fund has already invested in businesses such as Cloud Paper, which makes toilet paper out of bamboo and has a mission to save a billion trees.
In an interview with Rory Cellan-Jones, he said the planet faces an existential crisis.

headline: Mural is 'Butetown's Mona Lisa'
summary: The mural's subject Maimuna Indjai says taking part in the project means a lot to her.
headline2: My City, My Shirt: Cardiff mural 'Butetown's Mona Lisa'
summary2:
A mural of a pregnant woman wearing a Cardiff City shirt is "Butetown's Mona Lisa", one of the project's organisers has said.
The My City, My Shirt project was launched to celebrate Cardiff's diversity.
One of the project's organisers Sawqi Hasson said it aimed to "bridge the gap between the local club and BAME communities".
Maimuna Indjai, who features in the mural, said seeing her image meant a lot to her.

headline: How can I stop my houseplants dying?
summary: With houseplant sales booming, expert Giacomo Plazzotta offers tips for keeping them healthy.
headline2: How can I stop my houseplants dying?
summary2:
Houseplant sales were already increasing before the coronavirus pandemic.
But they've risen further in lockdown, with the Royal Horticultural Society reporting an 80% increase sales of foliage houseplants in 2020.
But how many are ending up dried out and dead?
Plant expert Giacomo Plazzotta offers his advice on how to keep your houseplants alive and thriving.
Filmed and edited: Tom Beal
Producer: Anisa Subedar

headline: Comics to set up 'HR service' to keep women safe
summary: Kiri Pritchard-Mclean said harassment can range from "microaggressions" to "criminal activities."
headline2: Comics to set up 'HR service' to keep women on the circuit safe
summary2:
Comedians Kiri Pritchard-McLean and Nina Gilligan are setting up an "HR service" to keep women comics safe on the circuit.
The idea is venues will pay into the scheme to provide support and protection for workers and venues.
Ms Pritchard-McLean said harassment could range from “microaggressions” to “criminal activities”.
The plan is for the scheme to provide venues with training and a sexual harassment policy.

headline: 'It was anyone's match' - Djokovic battles past Zverev in four sets
summary: Relive how Novak Djokovic beat Alexander Zverev in four tough sets to reach the Australian Open semi-finals.
headline2: 'It was anyone's match' - Djokovic battles past Zverev in four sets
summary2:
Novak Djokovic beats Alexander Zverev in men's quarter-finals
Eight-time Australian champion wins 6-7 (6-8) 6-4 6-2 7-6 (8-6)
Qualifier Aslan Karatsev beats injured Grigor Dimitrov in four sets - will face Djokovic on Thursday
Serena Williams beats Simona Halep in straight sets to reach semis
Naomi Osaka eases past Hsieh Su-wei - and will face Williams on Thursday
GB's Hewett & Reid win wheelchair doubles title

headline: Couple's house swept away in floods near Sydney
summary: Their home was carried away by flash flooding, on what should have been their wedding day.
headline2: Australia floods: Couple's house swept away near Sydney
summary2:
A young couple in Australia's New South Wales state have seen their house swept away by flash floods on what should have been their wedding day.
Neighbours filmed the cottage being carried by the river after it burst its banks following heavy rain.
Thousands more people in low-lying suburbs of Sydney have been told they may have to leave their homes.
Australia floods: Young couple's house swept away near Sydney

headline: Fireball fragments recovered in Gloucestershire
summary: Pieces of a meteorite that fell to Earth last month have been found in Winchcombe in the Cotswolds.
headline2: Fireball fragments recovered in Gloucestershire
summary2:
Several rocky fragments have been recovered from the fireball that lit up the sky above southern England just over a week ago.
They came down in the Winchcombe area of Gloucestershire.
A householder first alerted experts after noticing a pile of charred stone on his driveway.
Video of the fireball had allowed researchers to narrow the likely drop zone.
Read more: Winchcombe meteorite is first UK find in 30 years

headline: Thermal camera captures elephant selfies
summary: The camera is being developed to help conservation efforts of African and Asian elephants in the wild.
headline2: Elephants pose for thermal pictures at Whipsnade Zoo
summary2:
Elephants at Whipsnade Zoo have been photographed by a thermal camera as part of a project hoping to help the conservation of elephants in the wild.
Thirty-thousand pictures were taken over two years as part of Zoological Society of London's research to develop technology to address human-wildlife conflict.
Human-Elephant Alert Technologies (HEAT) uses thermal cameras to spot elephants using their heat signature.

headline: Duke praises 'Wales' wild beauty' in 1954 speech
summary: As he received the freedom of Cardiff, Prince Philip said every visit to Wales was a delight.
headline2: Prince Philip: Duke of Edinburgh praised 'Wales' wild beauty'
summary2:
"Here in Wales there's a strange, wild beauty which makes every visit a delight."
The Duke of Edinburgh shared his fondness for Wales as he became the 48th person to receive the freedom of Cardiff in 1954.
He also paid tribute to the "very genuine kindness and hospitality of the people of Wales to myself and, indeed, to all visitors".
The duke's death at the age of 99 was announced by Buckingham Palace on Friday.

headline: Kids' drawings depict lockdown feelings
headline2: Mental health: Schoolchildren's pictures depict lockdown feelings
summary2:
One and a half million under-18s will need support with their mental health as a result of the pandemic, the National Association of Headteachers has said.
BBC London visited the Orion Primary School in north London to find out how children there have been coping.
The pupils drew pictures describing their experiences of lockdown and said being able to attend school and see their friends again had made them happy.

headline: Dog ear cropping: 'It's affected him in so many ways'
summary: The practice, which the RSPCA says is on the rise, involves cutting off part of the animal's ear.
headline2: Dog ear cropping: 'It's affected him in so many ways'
summary2:
Ear cropping on dogs, where part of the animal's ear is cut off, is banned in the UK.
But the RSPCA says there's been a 621 percent increase in cases in the last six years, with 101 cases reported last year compared to 14 in 2015.
The charity is blaming Premier League footballers and reality TV stars who have dogs with cropped ears and then promote them on their social media accounts.
Report by Charlotte Gallagher

headline: 'My brother never told us he was struggling'
summary: Ex-Love Island star Dr Alex George on his new role as youth mental health ambassador, and losing his brother.
headline2: Dr Alex George: 'My brother never told us he was struggling'
summary2:
A&E doctor and ex-Love Island star Alex George has been speaking about his "overwhelming week" following his government appointment as youth mental health ambassador.
Last year he lost his brother, Llŷr, to suicide, at he age of 19.
He told BBC Breakfast his family had not been aware his brother had been struggling - and said he hoped to change perceptions about the stigma surrounding mental health in his new role.
